HEADLINE: A Spaghetti Dress for World Peace 

BYLINE:  By Lynn Hirschberg; Lynn Hirschberg is a contributing writer for the magazine.

 BODY:
Miguel Adrover, who has the sad knowing eyes and long flowing hair of Jesus, is hoping to be resurrected. Two years ago, he was the darling of the fashion world, the brightest design star anyone had seen in years. Now he is on the verge of burning out. Back then, the media and buyers alike were dazzled by his sophisticated tailoring paired with witty takes on famous labels. He took a Burberry raincoat, turned it inside out and reconceived it as a dress; a torn and artfully dirty INY T-shirt was augmented with puffy sleeves. It was the familiar made absurd and, somehow, beautiful.
 Shown in 2000, Adrover's breakthrough collection -- which was only his second collection altogether -- was the kind of brand-name commentary that excites the fashion world. It loved the hip, in-joke streetiness of the clothes, the idea that it had discovered somebody who was saying something new about fashion (although it wasn't entirely clear what, exactly, he was saying). And though Adrover is Spanish, he showed in New York, not Paris or Milan. With an immigrant's gaze, he was making clothes that both mocked and embraced America. 
 "Everybody was in love with me," Adrover says, standing next to a rack of clothes in his fourth-floor walk-up loft on the edge of Chinatown. It's a crisp October day, and Adrover is dressed in carefully assembled layers, all in shades of navy blue, which is his favorite color. His jeans ride low on his hips, exposing the elastic top of his boxers. His slightly shrunken navy-and-white-striped shirt is covered by a cashmere sweater-vest the color of faded denim. Adrover's hair is braided halfway down his back, and his hands, which are long and expressive, are accented by inch-long nails on both pinkies. "It's a gypsy thing," he explains. Like the clothes Adrover designs, his look is a mixture of the rough and the classic.
"I'm interested in clothes, not fashion," Adrover says, lighting a Marlboro Light. "Fashion is superficial, momentary. For me, clothes need to be timeless. Fashion says, Here is something for the next six months. Why? When somebody makes something for only the next six months, they don't have anything to say. They just want people to consume."
This sort of talk helps to explain why the fashion world has turned on Adrover; he is decrying the foundation of their business. Designers are expected to create at least two collections every year to fulfill the latest desires of fickle consumers. Some shops want new merchandise every eight weeks. Jeffrey Kalinsky, who owns Jeffrey, an upscale store in Manhattan, says: "We're in the fashion business. People are attracted to the new."
Adrover's ascent to the heights of fashion was followed by an equally rapid descent. During his up period, Women's Wear Daily put him on its cover, calling him "New York's New Star." He signed a multi-million-dollar deal with the Pegasus Apparel Group to produce and distribute his clothes. And he moved from his dank basement apartment to a lavish loft on the Bowery, where he hired 30 people. He drove around Manhattan (without a license) in a Jaguar that Pegasus paid for. "It was dark gray," Adrover says, sounding delighted. "Now, I am back to my bike." He laughs softly. "But what was important to me then and what is important to me now is the same: the clothes. I want my clothes to lead a revolution. I'm trying to see society in different cultures and incorporate that into my clothes."
It was in September 2001 that Adrover's star fell. Pegasus refused to commit any more money and then dropped him. On Sept. 9 he had presented a show, grandly titled the Utopia Collection, that many critics found politically troublesome. Just as Adrover had offered riffs on iconic Western fashion, he was now embracing another silhouette -- that of Islamic culture. The drapey clothes had an almost ecclesiastical elegance, but they also evoked the strict dress code of the Taliban. Adrover's timing could not have been worse. Two days later, the twin towers were struck. The designer's enthusiasm for Islamic dress made him seem politically obtuse or, worse, sympathetic to the enemy. Adrover's creative inspiration appeared to be the same Islamic regime that fostered terrorism. 
Politics and clothes can be awkward companions. Of course, many fashion trends have grown out of politically charged cultural movements: think of hippie chic in the 70's and grunge in the 90's. Clothes are a handy way for like-minded people to identify one another. But Adrover was engaged in a knottier project. He was trying to educate the Western consumer about the third world. He had been inspired by trips to Egypt and photographs of Arab villages, which he put on the wall of his studio. "They were still there on Sept. 11," Adrover recalls. "In Spain, the papers wrote that my studio was connected to bin Laden." He shakes his head. "But look at this," he continues, taking a coat from the rack. "Does this look like the clothes of a terrorist?"
The coat is simply cut with geometric pieces of colored cotton hand-appliqued in a mosaic pattern. It looks like a stained-glass window from a mosque transposed onto a dress. Adrover pulls out another coat, made of white pique. He rubbed an aquamarine dye into the fabric and matching dress, adding more color into the pocket area (where it would normally show more wear and tear). The effect is watery -- the crisp pique is softened by the irregular stains of pale blue. He then dismisses a long silk gown ("We made the spaghetti dress to sell more") and shows off a gauzy peasant skirt that is sewn in intricately constructed layers. "We washed this in ashes and water," he says, showing off the subtle brown stains that make the skirt look antique. "This was all sewn by hand." Another skirt, which was made out of a donkey's saddle, is embroidered in a diamond pattern and hemmed in heavy tassels. "The construction on this one is crazy," Adrover says. "I'm not sure we could copy this one. We could, maybe, make 30 of the mosaic coats. But that is not bad. It's not necessary to mass-produce clothes. They should be special."
Despite an order of $1.5 million from a Japanese company, the Utopia Collection was never produced. The clothes are beautiful, if too restrained for America's sexed-up taste. The dresses are caftanlike, and the skirts are long and loose. There are touches in Adrover's clothes that you only see on couture garments: hand-sewn labels, silk linings, bone buttons. There is enormous attention to small details. One flouncy, Jamaican-style dress took three weeks to construct: where another designer might have used rickrack, Adrover's team painstakingly folded fabric into triangles to decorate the bodice of the dress. The care in creation is evident. True to Adrover's philosophy, these clothes seem timeless.
To others, they seemed foolhardy. "Miguel is a great designer, but he has no idea about business," says a former Pegasus employee, who, like most of the fashion community, insists on being anonymous on the subject of Adrover. "Pegasus wasn't a patron of the arts. They were not putting up a museum wing for Miguel Adrover. We needed him to listen, to be responsible. The fashion world is one part art and one part business. Without one, you don't have the other. Unless Miguel wants to make clothes to hang on his walls, he needs to think about business too. And that doesn't mean political statements. It means clothes that people want to wear at a price they can afford. For Miguel, as brilliant as he is, that may not be possible."
Adrover walks into the living-room area of the loft followed by Peter Hidalgo, one of his unpaid design assistants. The room, like the rest of the loft, is decorated with mismatched furniture that somehow fits together. There are velvet couches that Adrover found on the street and a piano that came with the apartment. Large plants stand in the corners, and a richly detailed Egyptian coat hangs from the ceiling. Hidalgo, along with 30 or so other disciples, worked on Adrover's most recent collection, titled Citizen of the World, which he showed this September in New York. It was a remarkable show that incorporated Adrover's multicultural themes with his usual expert tailoring. Hidalgo worked on one bias-cut 1940's-style dress for almost four months. "It took three days to drape the dress," he says, "a week to sew stripes on each piece of the dress and then another week to connect the pieces." 
Adrover lights another cigarette. "We can only make one or two of those," he says. 
Hidalgo nods. "Miguel is inspirational," he says. "No one works this way any more."
Whether he's been rich or poor, Adrover has always been surrounded by a devoted throng. For this collection, on which he spent $50,000 of his own money, the last of his Pegasus savings, assistants slept underneath the design tables in the other room. Sebastian Pons, Adrover's longtime business partner and design director, moved into a cubbyhole and worked around the clock. 
Last summer, Mei Zou, a pattern maker, worked for Adrover for free each night after working for pay all day with Narciso Rodriguez. "Have you noticed that Narciso's clothes are much better now?" Adrover says. "That's because of Mei. When I lost my money, Narciso took my pattern makers and sewers too." Rodriguez, for his part, says he is pleased to work with Zou, but dismisses the idea that he stole her.
"The same thing happened with Zac Posen, who's now everybody's favorite new designer," Adrover adds. "Actually, most of my people came here after they worked with those others. It's like a refugee camp here. We were all refugees from fashion." Adrover pauses as Hidalgo listens. "People get afraid when the vocabulary changes," he says. "I wanted to say something about the situation in the world right now. A lot of people tell me it's not time for philosophy; it's time for business. But I think they are wrong. Our clothes can give people hope."
While it is easy to embrace the beauty of Adrover's clothes, it is difficult to see what a $2,500 dress illuminates about racial inequality or global unrest. Yes, Adrover's latest collection showed a woman draped in the United Nations logo, and yes, his clothes often feature religious totems. But Adrover's work is strongest when he incorporates motifs from other cultures into his own aesthetic -- just as Yves Saint Laurent did with Morocco. When his approach becomes too literal, his clothes became polemical costumes.
"I want this to be a revolution," he repeats. This is his mantra, and it seems to inspire his troops. "With clothes, you have the power to affect society. People see what you're wearing, and they say, I want to be like that. I see other designers' ad campaigns, and I think, Is this a philosophy? Is it a philosophy to show a girl on her knees before a man? Is this intellectual? I don't want to say it's not good to show a miniskirt with long legs, but sex is so exploited. Sex isn't exciting anymore. Designers need to show people how to feel something again, how to see the world."
Not only does Adrover dislike his colleagues' advertising, he questions their goal of selling to the masses. "I want my clothes to be produced," he says. "But some of them will probably be expensive. People say to me, 'People without money cannot buy your clothes.' But it doesn't matter. People don't have to own them. When people just look at my clothes, they are changed. These big companies, with their multi-million-dollar businesses, are just trying to make a profit. They are trying to manipulate people by saying, If you don't have that bag, you will not be in fashion."
Adrover looks up at the coat hanging on the wall. He found the fabric, a painted tarp, on a trip to Luxor. Adrover fashioned it into an elegant but tattered robelike coat. "That coat shows you something of the world," he says. "That is what clothes can do."
It was another coat that made Adrover famous. Soon after Quentin Crisp, the bohemian humorist, died in 1999, Adrover, who lived nearby, took the ticking off Crisp's mattress and tailored it into a town coat. The stains on the mattress entranced him. "Life is hard," he shrugs. "You have to make that beautiful." Although everyone who worked on the coat developed a rash, the Quentin Crisp Invention made clear that Adrover was a daring talent. 
The coat was shown in his attention-grabbing February 2000 show. Adrover seemed to have sprung out of nowhere. The son of an almond farmer from Majorca, Adrover, who is now 36, had no formal training. He hadn't apprenticed with a more experienced designer, and he hadn't attended any sort of college. In 1991, when he was 25, he moved to New York and started selling T-shirts under the label DUGG, and by 1997, he and a partner opened a boutique in the East Village called Horn.
"I fell into fashion by accident," Adrover says. "But I always had a passion for clothes." In 1999, Adrover decided to show his first collection. He described it as "the story of a Brazilian woman who is kicked out of her rain-forest home by loggers. She migrates to Mexico, where she joins the Zapatista rebels, and then to New York, where she winds up homeless, wearing a resewn American flag."
The show opened with a naked girl, standing in a field of bamboo. She then dresses, but barely. In the show's most alarming moment, a model, outfitted in a simple white blouse, carried a shotgun slung across her body, her face half-covered by a paisley scarf. "Circumstances can make people violent," Adrover explains.
Few people saw this first collection, but it was the next one, which featured the Quentin Crisp coat and the Burberry dress, that turned Adrover into a sensation. Stephen Ruzow, the former president and C.O.O. of Donna Karan International who was then heading Pegasus, signed Adrover up immediately. Pegasus also had deals with the designers Pamela Dennis (known for her evening wear) and Daryl K (known for her pants). The company was modeled on conglomerates like LVMH, which own several fashion houses, including Givency, Christian Dior, Christian Lacroix and Louis Vuitton. It was formed in early 2000 with the backing of a $300 million equity fund. "The idea was to acquire businesses with great possibilities for expansion," says a former Pegasus employee, who, like all top Pegasus employees (including Adrover), has signed a confidentiality agreement. "Pegasus would have separate showrooms for each designer, but the back of the house -- manufacturing, distribution, advertising -- would be the same. That saves money." LVMH and the Gucci Group had used this approach, but virtually no one had done it with American brands. 
For fashion, especially high-end fashion, to be successful, it has to be produced and sold in volume. The economics are simple: if Adrover hopes a dress will sell at retail for $2,500 (and many of his dresses cost more), he will offer it to the store for $1,100. If the dress costs him $400 to produce in terms of fabric and labor, he will make $700 in profit. If Adrover produces 100 dresses -- an output that would not be easy to achieve on his own, considering his methods -- the yield will still be only $70,000. After paying for rent and other expenses, he could easily be left with nothing.
When he signed with Pegasus in April 2000, Adrover was eager to bring his production costs down and sell more clothes. "I thought, We are going to make money out of the dream," he recalls. "I was naive."
A few months later, Adrover showed his Bank Collection, which featured uniforms, some accessorized with the badges of a Vietnam veteran. His most accessible collection, it was entirely saleable. Pegasus pushed the stores to buy. "We may have pushed too hard," a former Pegasus executive says. "But Miguel was being heralded as the Yves Saint Laurent of American fashion. We wanted to capitalize on that enthusiasm."
Unfortunately, customers didn't know Adrover's name, and the merchandise lingered. The reception of his next collection, Meet East, further underscored the capriciousness of the fashion world. The show was held at the Essex Street Market on the Lower East Side on a freezing Sunday night in February 2001. Things did not run smoothly. The show was disorganized, and Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue, saw the throng waiting to get in and decided not to bother.
Inspired by his trip to Luxor, the show was styled to look authentically Egyptian. Individual pieces were lovely, but Adrover's models looked as if they were trapped in a repressive culture. Their heads, and sometimes their faces, were covered by shawls and scarves; their bodies were swathed in layers of clothing. One model was supposed to walk a sheep down the catwalk, but the sheep stumbled off the runway. "I don't know why Miguel messed with that sheep," Jeffrey Kalisnky sighs. "That evening was disturbing. When you're as talented as Miguel, you don't need to make a statement with a sheep."
Discussing the show, Adrover restates his view of fashion as an educational tool. "I wanted people to learn about other cultures," he says. "That was the first time people mentioned the Taliban in connection with my clothes. The American fashion world was comfortable with these references. It's interesting -- you can show some things and not others."
Pegasus was quickly becoming disenchanted. "That Messiah thing he's got going does not translate into business," an executive says. Some fashion insiders claim that Pegasus was mismanaged, that it did not have a solid financial plan. It was too hasty in trying to convert Adrover's press into profits. Says Sebastian Pons, who handles Adrover's business: "They only talked about selling. We had a philosophy, and they didn't want to talk about that."
Shortly after the Utopia show in September 2001, Pegasus told Adrover that it was ending their relationship. "Everything went down the sink," Adrover recalls. "I would have preferred to grow much more slowly, but Pegasus wanted to go fast, like Coca-Cola. And then I showed Utopia, and things only got worse. They called me a terrorist. It was a nightmare. This city is so racist -- they didn't look at what we were trying to achieve with the clothes, what we were trying to say about understanding other cultures."
Adrover pauses. "Some people get confused by the political side of my clothes. But clothes should be like art -- they should surprise you, educate you. People shouldn't get upset if I say that. They should just see the clothes. Then they'd understand: fashion will fail you, but a message will give you power."
Adrover and Hidalgo are eating paella and tapas at La Nacional, a restaurant on 14th Street. "When you come to America," Adrover says, "Spanish people give you this address. Only Spanish people know about this place." The restaurant has simple wood plank tables and a television is turned to a Spanish-language station.
"I am back to being broke," Adrover says. "I am two months behind on my rent. We were so hot -- life is unfair. People have millions of dollars out there, and they don't want to support our company." He takes a bite of octopus. "I'm a little angry about it."
After Sept. 11, Adrover moved out of his plush Bowery apartment, put his stuff in storage in Brooklyn and spent three months in a country few Americans were then visiting: Egypt. He bought a house and a horse there. "I was thinking how to continue after the attack. In Egypt, I realized I needed to go back to work. I wanted everyone to realize how wrong they were."
Back in New York, he reunited his team and began designing the Citizen of the World show. "It wasn't easy," Adrover says. "Big people closed the door in my face. They think I'm difficult! The fashion business has a lot of stupid attitude. Creativity is less important to them than whether or not you show up at their stupid parties."
Adrover's grandiosity is both compelling and frustrating. His belief in clothes as a tool for political change is appealingly heartfelt, but his reluctance to accept the practical aspects of the business is exasperating. Citizen of the World features stunning clothes that many women, of all ages, would love to wear. There are sinuous beaded dresses, crisp sharkskin suits and a wonderful striped skirt that flounces from the hip. Yet Adrover still lacks financial backing, and as of early November, no stores have purchased the clothes.
Adrover pours a glass of wine. "Do you know this comic named Messing?" he asks. "She's hosting the VH1/Vogue Fashion Awards. Debra Messing." Adrover says this as if the name of the "Will and Grace" star is not worth his breath. "Vogue called and wanted her to wear one of my suits for the award show. I don't have a TV so I looked her up. And I thought, No, she cannot wear my suit. It's not as if she's Charlotte Rampling. She could wear the suit."
Adrover doesn't seem to care that his message, be it sartorial or political, could be communicated to millions of people through the person of Debra Messing or that cooperating with a Vogue request when you're dead broke might be a smart move. "Not the suit," he repeats. "That is my trademark piece from the collection. Not on that . . . comic."
In two days, Adrover says, he is going to Majorca to meet representatives of Lottusse, a Spanish shoe and accessories manufacturer. He hopes it will provide some of the needed capital for production. Adrover is also meeting with the Museum of Modern Art in Barcelona, which wants to do a retrospective of his work. "Six rooms with 10 or so pieces in each room," Adrover exclaims. "That's very exciting. It opens the door to Europe."
More than exhibits, what Adrover really needs is a strong business partner. Most successful designers are teamed with equally passionate and committed businessmen. Marc Jacobs has Robert Duffy, Tom Ford has Domenico De Sole and so on.
"We are rebuilding," Adrover says. "This show was not just about a fashion show. It was about a change in perspective, about believing in the collection and in New York."
Hidalgo, who has been silent, says, "You could always take another fashion house."
Adrover shakes his head. "I find that kind of funny. When you're trying to keep alive something that is dead, it's wrong. Why don't people embrace new designers? People ask me who is going to be the next Calvin Klein, and I say, I don't think we need more underwear advertising. Society needs something else."
Adrover's impracticality and stubborn idealism would be insufferable if he were not so talented. His clothes redeem his self-righteousness, although clothes should be worn. Adrover would like a global business, but he has to first find a backer who will believe in him the way he believes in himself. "I would like my philosophy to be all over the world," he says. "That is my dream."
He looks up at the television. It is showing highlights from John Galliano's spring collection. Adrover is riveted; his expression changes from childlike fascination to mild disgust. "Look at those skirts," he says, noting how short they are. "It's just more fashion. Where is the philosophy? Where are the ideas?" Turning his back on the TV, Adrover takes a bite of paella. "I am needed," he says. "The world needs me."

Right: An outfit from his 1999 show. (Left, Dan Lecca. Right: from Miguel Adrover.); Left: The coat made from Quentin Crisp's mattress ticking. SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 86

HEADLINE: How the Disposable Sofa Conquered America 

BYLINE:  By John Leland; John Leland is a Style reporter for The Times.

 BODY:
Sitting in a modern, uncluttered office in Almhult, Sweden, earlier this year, a woman named Josephine Rydberg-Dumont advanced a global theory of home. "We're ready for modernism now," she said. "When it first came, it was for the few. Now it is for the many. You value things that don't bog you down, that are easy to take care of." Rydberg-Dumont, 47, is the managing director of Ikea of Sweden, the creative nexus for what has grown to a $10.8 billion worldwide operation. Her office had no desk or computer, just a big Ikea table and a set of blond bentwood chairs that are the stuff of deep decor envy. 
 She was heading toward a vision of material utopia in which products are the problem and more products are the solution. "When you think of your own life, there's a time for several different lifestyles. That old, traditional stuff is making us feel the other way, that things can't change, that taking responsibility for your things is more important than taking responsibility for your life. It's O.K. to replace them, to get rid of them. We don't think we're going to live one way always. Our feeling is: It's just furniture. Change it." 
 Of all the paths by which design travels in America, few have been as tricky and as revealing as the relationship between America and Ikea. Last year, 29.3 million people worked their way through the directed Habitrail of an American Ikea store. In the slog of recession, Ikea sales for the year that ended in August were up 5 percent over the previous year. Such success says a lot about the evolution of the company. "If you look at the history of Ikea, in the early years their design was quite horrible," said Alexander von Vegesack, director of the Vitra Design Museum in Weil am Rhein, Germany, who in 1999 mounted an exhibit on the history of the company. But in the last decade, he said, the company has pushed a more ambitious aesthetic. "They became more and more interested in design. Today if you go to Ikea, you always will find some pieces which are good designs and very reasonable in pricing."
But more interesting is what that success says about America. In a short stretch of time, and for reasons that were almost completely coincidental, the country changed in ways that made it much more amenable to the transient, plastic modernism of Ikea. Those broad changes also served to dress the company in precisely the mythologies it needed to get over. With a nod to the economic theories of Ronald Reagan, Ikea practiced a sophisticated brand of demand-side aesthetics. By keeping a close eye on its market, and responding astutely as it changed, a company went from building ugly, inferior furniture for a backwater region to becoming a chic, smiling fixture within millions of American homes, quite possibly including yours. 
The train ride to Almhult from Copenhagen, the nearest major city, passes through an unattractive grind of rocky forests, broken incongruously by a tiny Wild West theme park called Amerika. The theme park, gone in the span of a train whistle, is a small gesture in the way of cultural translation and tribute, like the American programs that cycle through Swedish TV. 
America is here and not here. In the 19th century, much of the region's population immigrated to places like Minnesota and Nebraska, leaving those who stayed behind to squeeze a slender living from crafts and small farming. In 1953, Ingvar Kamprad opened a furniture showroom here. He combined his initials with those of Elmtaryd, the farm where he grew up, and the village of Agunnaryd, his hometown, to form the name Ikea. Today, the United States -- with its shifting economies, its eager trendiness and its unique demographics -- may control a good deal of the future fortunes of Kamprad's company. It's certain that his company has anticipated a good deal of the future of the United States.
To peer into the world of Ikea for any time is to dive into the thorny bramble of class, in particular the twisted course of class during the 1990's. In the peculiar rites of the company culture, from Almhult outward, class is always in the foreground. The company's 70,000 employees are called "co-workers"; the target customers are referred to as "the many," or sometimes "people with thin wallets." Private offices are rare; everyone is on a first-name basis. Bill Agee, an American who transferred to Almhult five years ago, said he had to adjust upon entry. "It's a little religious or missionary in a sense," he said, "but it's who we are." The overt goodyism of it meshed with his experiences of Sweden as a whole. When he first arrived, he made a wrong turn down a one-way street. Instead of screaming at him, people on the street wagged fingers -- "as if to say, 'You're not doing your part to support a better Sweden,"' he said. "That bothered me more than someone giving me the finger."
The office chatter has a benevolent "Star Trek" vibe: the answer is always design, and the reward for such answers is world domination. The most basic products come packaged as a mission, rendered under the slogan "democratic design." Even the company's newsletter includes articles on the effectiveness of the newsletter: a recent issue cited a study showing that "three out of four Ikea co-workers read the magazine regularly." Peter Fiell, who researched the company for his book "Industrial Design A-Z," described the ethos as a kind of moral humanism played out in chairs and shelving units. "It goes back to Charles Eames -- how to get the most quality to the greatest number of people for the least money," Fiell said. "That's the nucleus of modernism. It's inherently optimistic."
As certain as it now seems, Ikea's path in America has been one of error and recovery. In early surveys of American consumers, the company found that Ikea buyers were likely to be people who had traveled abroad, who considered themselves risk takers, who liked fine food and wine. They bought the first Walkmen, laptops and cellphones. The most likely people had frequent-flier plans. The least likely were those who collected guns. The company then chose sites for new stores based on the distribution of such values. The results looked like the red and blue maps from the last presidential election, with stores chasing Al Gore's blues and avoiding the Republican reds. Kent Nordin, until recently Ikea's sales and marketing manager for North America, looked at the numbers this way: "There's more Buicks driven in the middle than on the coasts." The company went to the coasts. 
But if the company was in the right place, it was the wrong time. Shortly after the first store opened in 1985, the dollar began to drop against the Swedish kroner, forcing the company to raise prices and cut profit margins. Moreover, America did not like the goods. The company stubbornly refused to size its beds and kitchen cabinets to fit American sheets and appliances. Nordin remembers following shoppers in a store in Houston, when a woman said to him, "I like this bed, but what is 160 centimeters?" When he tried to explain, she said, "Young man, why do you do this?" Other things were wrong as well. There were no glasses large enough to meet American big-gulp thirsts. "People told us they were drinking out of the vases," he said. In spring 1992, the Ikea board met to consider closing its operations in the United States and adding its corpse to what Nordin calls "the graveyard for European retailers." He says now, "If we'd been a public company, we would not be here today." Eventually, the company changed the size of its mattresses and cabinets, softened the sofa cushions and added big, cheap glasses. If you have ever owned these, chances are they are all broken now.
The greatest problem, however, was one of class values. Taken at its word, Ikea was addressing the people who could not afford other options, and that market was not enough. These were not the people who liked foreign travel and wine and not the early adopters who make American consumer taste. In the course of its market research, however, the company identified a change in the way postboomer Americans view their material possessions. It seemed that the line between durable goods (things like refrigerators or furnaces, which are expected to last forever) and soft goods (things that turn over at the speed of fashion) was blurring. The popularity of car leasing has made it possible for more Americans to switch wheels as rapidly as they change hemlines. The Swatch watch, similarly, made quality timekeeping disposable. And the status glow on a BlackBerry or an iPod lasts only until a newer, more powerful model comes out. 
The next step, according to Christian Mathieu, external-marketing manager for Ikea North America, was for furniture, the mother of all durable goods, to cross to soft. This involves a greater leap. "Americans change their spouse as often as their dining-room table, about 1.5 times in a lifetime," he said. As he saw it, this was a habit that no longer made sense. People no longer died in the home they were born in; why were they lugging their grandmother's chintz from one house to the next to the next?
In a rather substantial American market research program begun in the mid-1990's, Ikea posed questions not just about housewares but also about values, asking people whether they agreed with statements like "I like to take risks," "I am spiritual" or "Protecting the family is important to me." It found that much of the country was frozen by decor fear, Nordin said. The reason many Americans, especially older Americans, "keep a sofa longer than a car," he said, is that they believe "it's going to be the icon of the living room. And if you fail, you have to apologize to everyone who comes into the home." This was not necessarily the case, however, among a younger group, particularly one attuned to a more entrepreneurial, more risk-taking business culture. The company has long shown a knack for tweaking consumer desires ahead of its competition (well before gay characters became a staple of American television, for example, a 1994 Ikea ad featured two gay men shopping for furniture), and a decision was made to exploit this new development. 
The company's latest ad campaign is a result of that decision. It can be seen as a kind of curriculum by which to teach this new group how to take a more commitment-free approach to furniture. It was directed by Spike Jonze, best known for his film "Being John Malkovich." In the campaign, coyly dubbed Unboring, we see a discarded lamp, forlorn and forsaken in some rainy American city. A man turns to the camera sympathetically. "Many of you feel bad for this lamp," he says in an exaggerated Swedish accent. "That is because you're crazy." 
On the surface, this is a peculiar message for a company identified with a social-welfare state to send to a nation of ravenous, wasteful capitalist consumers -- or at least an odd one to cast in such specifically national terms. But regardless of the apparent contradiction, this new campaign has become a part of the Ikea gospel, and a part of the way the company and America see each other. 
Among the many repercussions of the technology boom of the 1990's was that it flipped the compass points of American class. Suddenly new money was more dynamic, more mesmerizing than old money. It made for juicier magazine spreads and gawking television news features. Old money represented fading values; new money was the future: plastic, high-tech, fungible, voraciously evanescent. Most important for Ikea, new money lived differently, stimulated different desires among the broader public. Old money cherished family heirlooms; new money made MTV's "Cribs." It was ahistoric, rapacious for novelty. Tradition was a thorn in its side, not a guiding presence. Instead of fetishizing the treasures of the past gilded age, new money announced itself in playhouse hues and cartoony designs from Arne Jacobsen, George Nelson, Verner Panton and other modernists. Appropriate to the new economy, the furnishings were expensive, but their value lay not in the materials but in an overlay of information, a narrative of design. They told a story that flattered both the owner and his audience. It was retro and futurist, a comforting view of dizzying change. For Ikea, this was a recipe for opportunity. Marble was expensive; color could be done cheap. 
Josephine Rydberg-Dumont noticed a corollary change that had similar advantages for Ikea's American experiment: an upmarketing of downmarket goods. Calvin Klein's cK T-shirts, Starbucks coffee, basketball shoes designed as if for the space program, sushi in the Grand Union -- these were tokens of conspicuous quality for a broad part of the population. "Ten or 15 years ago, traveling in the United States, you couldn't eat well," she said. "You couldn't get good coffee. Now you can get good bread in the supermarket, and people think that's normal. I like that very much. That's more important to the good life than the availability of expensive wines. That's what Ikea is about."
It was a particularly good thing to be about in the 1990's, a decade in which the economic folk tales were of astronomical success (or, by the end, vertiginous falls), but the broad reality was quite different: for Americans in the middle of the wage scale, real earnings, adjusted for inflation, declined or held flat for much of the decade. Even when they were putting away a few dollars, members of the middle class were losing ground to the people to whose status they aspired, the heroes of those folk tales. The majority of Americans were participants in a zeitgeist of obscene riches without having a piece of the action. 
What they could have, in just the same degree as the new economy's new rich, was the immaterial titillations of design. Design was a perfect class commodity for a class that was going nowhere. It added value to a toilet brush or a garbage pail, to say nothing of personal computers. The ubiquity of these fluid computer-generated designs suggested an attractive world of class mobility. It promised that you could be moving forward, even if your paycheck was slipping back: why, just look at your toothbrush, designed by Philippe Starck for Alessi. Glossy design magazines sat side by side with the tabloids in supermarket checkout lines. Decor gurus built cable TV franchises among the same daytime audiences that used to watch soap operas. Target invited the six-pack public into the (blob-shaped) pool, introducing conspicuously cool lines by the name-brand designers Starck and Michael Graves. Here was a distinctly American perspective on democratic design: if you couldn't afford to make your home look like Buckingham Palace, you could get some of the snob appeal of an Ian Schrager boutique hotel. Not only that, the newer take was better.
And what that new perspective looked like, more than anything, was Ikea. Showcased in magazines, bruited among early adopters, Ikea suited the benign technocracy and ironic wink of the new economy. Where stores like Pottery Barn and Restoration Hardware offer the comfort of prefab antiques, with a promise of permanence and connection with the past, Ikea fabricates a connection with motion itself. With little change in the product line, the company shifted its profile from its blandly functional side to its design side -- if not among the literal "many," then among the taste makers the many followed. "They raised the popular consciousness of design," Fiell said. "It's based on a highly optimistic view of the future, with equality of opportunity and an integrated look that is part of the identity." Sold only in Ikea stores, surrounded by a universe of other Ikea goods, the designs aim for an instant sugar rush. Like the Swedish clothing chain H.&M., whose store opening clogged Manhattan sidewalks in April 2000, it promises 360 degrees of immediate visual candy, at impulsive, no-guilt prices -- what the critic George W.S. Trow has called the context of no context. It's like being on TV, all shimmery surface. As a set designer for MTV's "Real World" told me, "We love Ikea."
The aroma of impermanence that hung over a lot of Ikea products, the nicked veneers and wobbly joints of Ikea regret, no longer seemed such a problem. Impermanence had become a mark of progress, not of decay. After years in the red, Ikea's revenues in the United States doubled over a four-year period, to $1.27 billion in 2001 from $600 million in 1997. The company expanded from 5 stores in the United States at the start of the 90's to 15 stores now and plans to add 50 more in North America by 2013. The United States is the company's third-biggest market, after Germany and Britain. The company declines to give information about profits, but as an indication of the number of people visiting these stores, the in-house restaurants, serving Swedish meatballs and cured salmon, are now the 15th-largest food chain in America. 
And though it was linked to the boom, the benign futurism has so far proved resistant to recession. "Our philosophy should work in good times and bad times," said Lena Simonsson-Berge, marketing manager for Ikea North America. There would be no need to retune the Ikea pitch, she added. "We are prepared for downturns." 
There is a price for all of Ikea's cost-cutting, and during my immersion in Almhult I felt the increasing chafe of design irritation. Little flaws, multiplied, mocked the cheery optimism of the veneers. Even in the company headquarters, cabinet doors never seemed to line up at right angles; in a conference room organized around four abutting beech Effektiv desks, each corner was a slightly different height. Joints wobbled. "See, this is what I don't like," said Eric Linander, a communications officer, jiggling an unsteady table top. "The design is good, but the quality is not so good." The minor glitches undercut the promise of material utopia: things weren't getting perfect; they were creaking from below. Like many logistic systems that are internally consistent, Ikea's populism does not accommodate the inherently individualistic revenge of imperfection: that delivering 80 percent of the quality for 60 percent of the price is not always a bargain. What looks good on "Real World" does not always wear well at home. Linander casually dropped a word to the wise: self-assembled furniture requires retightening over time. 
The test of the limits of Ikea living lies in a pilot program called BoKlok, Swedish for "Smart Living," that the company has instituted at scattered sites in Scandinavia. (See "A Prefab Utopia," this page.) For nearly six years, in partnership with the international developer Skanska, the company has built small, prefab apartment buildings, expanding its design agenda beyond chairs and light fixtures to cover whole mini-communities and, by extension, the lives inside. So far, they have built more than 1,000 units and have branched into four countries. The inexpensive, pleasant apartments carry the overlay of "democratic design" to a logical conclusion. Madeleine Nobs, one of the three architects, all women, described the project in evangelical terms: "As an architect, I think you can make people's lives better by design." 
For all of Ikea's rhetoric about social mission, however, there is an unspoken paradox to the company's efforts to build homey communities. With its huge parking lot and accompanying traffic glut, an Ikea store is often a smiley-faced enemy of community cohesion. The low prices draw customers away from smaller neighborhood shops, the nodes of community exchange; the volume of business attracts other mass retailers, creating big-box strip malls. Wary residents in Westchester County, N.Y., recently organized to fight Ikea in court, ultimately preventing the company from opening a store in New Rochelle. In the same way, Ikea's self-image as an ecofriendly company stands in direct contradiction to its campaigns telling you to toss out a perfectly good lamp. 
But the company has an impressive track record for avoiding controversy and keeping its positive, even benevolent, image intact. Ikea was mentioned in a 1992 documentary that looked at child labor in Pakistan but managed to escape the damaging publicity lobbed at Nike and other multinationals, in part by forming strategic partnerships with groups like Greenpeace, Unicef and Save the Children. In 1998, when it was struggling with its environmental policy, Ikea reached out to Greenpeace and bankrolled a major research project by the World Resources Institute that impressed all involved parties. Most striking, in 1994, Ingvar Kamprad, the company's founder, was revealed to have supported various Nazi groups in the 1940's and 50's. He issued an apology, and in April 2001 the company expanded into Israel without incident. On opening day, 15,000 customers flooded the aisles. 
On a recent afternoon, I muscled my way through the Ikea store in Elizabeth, N.J., which frequently tops $1 million in sales on a Saturday. Like all Ikea stores, it is set up to force shoppers through the whole store, instead of letting them head for their department of choice: a bit of gentle social coercion, the strong arm of democratic design. Three times each year, department heads follow customers through the maze, mapping their paces to see how to get the most from the traffic flow. When they noticed that men weren't following their female partners into the textile departments, they set up displays of tools just outside. "We sold screwdrivers like you can't believe," Nordin said. 
On this day, the crowd was a sprawl of mixed classes and languages; the narrow cast of American marketing seemed suspended. I bought a plain Oppli bench to put my television on and an Ordning stainless-steel dish rack, one of the most stylish -- and, at $24.95, most upmarket -- items in the store. It was a branded experience, from the food I ate in the store to the bus that took me back to Manhattan. The assembly on the Oppli was genius. The Ordning, which looked so sleek in the biosphere of the Ikea store, looked terrible in my home. It sits banished in its stackable box, another postcard of Ikea regret. Yet this is the promise of material utopia: that a change of products can fix your life -- if not this change, then the next. I thought of Lotta Carlsson, who lived in the BoKlok in Almhult. She mixed some older furniture among the Ikea, including a brass-and-ironwork bed that belonged to her great-grandparents. "People said, 'Oh, did you buy that at Ikea?"' she said. The alternative, somehow, seemed so much less exciting. It wasn't designed newer or better or cheaper. Outside a little personal interest, it was hardly a story at all.

HEADLINE: We'll Always Have Paris 

BYLINE:  By Tony Judt; Tony Judt is director of the Remarque Institute at New York University.

 BODY:
 PARIS 1919
Six Months That Changed the World.
By Margaret MacMillan.
Illustrated. 570 pp. New York:
Random House. $35.
 From January to June 1919, the leaders of Britain, France, Italy and the United States met in Paris to decide the outcome of the war they had just won against the Central Powers. They faced a Herculean task. In the course of the Great War of 1914-18, four old multinational empires had fallen: the Russian, Austro-Hungarian, German and Ottoman. The fate of hundreds of millions of people, from Strasbourg to Baghdad, from Hamburg to Aqaba, was unclear. Previous peace conferences -- including the best known, the Congress convened in Vienna in 1815 to reorder Europe after the defeat of Napoleon -- had confined themselves to adjusting the fates of dynasties and states. The peacemakers of 1919 had also to pay attention to principles, promises, public opinion and a fast-changing and unstable political scene. Russia was in revolution and much of central Europe seemed ready to follow suit.
The historian of the Paris peace talks (better known to history by the Versailles treaty in which they culminated) faces a task almost as daunting. Paris was awash in study groups, side negotiations and specialist discussions conducted simultaneously during those frenetic months. Every territorial demand, frontier rectification, ethnolinguistic claim and counterclaim -- and there were dozens of them -- had a history extending back many years before 1914. How is this story to be presented so that a modern reader can make sense of it without drowning in unfamiliar names and obscure Ruritanian conflicts?
To complicate matters further, anyone writing in English about the making of the Versailles treaty must even now struggle to escape from the long shadow cast by two young English participants in the Paris negotiations, who wrote their own accounts of the events. In "Peacemaking 1919," Harold Nicolson sketched caustic vignettes of elderly statesmen adrift in a world they couldn't comprehend. And John Maynard Keynes, in "The Economic Consequences of the Peace," demolished the credibility of the settlement itself, eviscerated the case for war reparations and predicted the disaster that must follow.
Margaret MacMillan's prose is no match for Nicolson's, and no one can compete with Keynes's intellectual firepower. But with "Paris 1919" she has written a very good history of the negotiations, full of colorful detail and as comprehensive as anyone could wish. The organization of the book leaves something to be desired -- discussing the 1919 creation of Yugoslavia without first explaining what happened in the Balkan wars of 1912-13 is confusing; so is the author's decision to tell the story of the breakup of the Hapsburg empire after her account of the little states that succeeded it. But the separate national narratives are very well handled. 
MacMillan, a professor of history at the University of Toronto, is particularly good at describing and characterizing individuals, not only leading figures like Woodrow Wilson, David Lloyd George and Georges Clemenceau, but also peripheral actors like Queen Marie of Romania and a string of hapless supplicants from Beijing to Budapest. Wilson does not come out well. Despite his good intentions, perhaps because of them, he was widely viewed as petulant, petty and vain. Lloyd George and Clemenceau, closeted with him for half a year, eventually grew tolerant of his obsessions and moods, but they never got used to his peculiarly American brand of idealism, so ill suited to a time when arm-twisting and old-fashioned horse-trading were required to achieve anything. Wilson's obsession with achieving his new League of Nations was not shared by the more realistic and pessimistic Europeans. And when the Americans did finally abandon principles and resort to bullying, they seemed hypocritical.
Nevertheless, the American president was the key figure in Paris. The French were understandably concerned with keeping Germany down for the indefinite future. The Italians wanted the territorial pound of flesh they had been secretly promised in return for switching sides in 1915. The British sought above all to stabilize Europe's peripheries and protect access to their imperial possessions farther south and east. Only the Americans had a Big Idea -- self-determination. The peoples and nations now released from imperial captivity were each to receive their own spaces, assigned after careful specialist attention to history, geography, language and other relevant considerations. Poles, Czechs, Slovaks, Slovenes, Serbs, Latvians, Lithuanians, Estonians, Romanians, Bulgarians, Italians, Greeks, Jews, Arabs, Armenians, even Kurds were to have a place in the sun. Only Germans, and to a lesser extent Turks, were not free to determine where and with whom they would live -- the price of defeat.
The idea of self-determination was wonderful, the reality disastrous. As Robert Lansing, Wilson's secretary of state, predicted: "It will raise hopes which can never be realized. It will, I fear, cost thousands of lives. In the end it is bound to be discredited, to be called the dream of an idealist who failed to realize the danger until it was too late to check those who attempt to put the principle into force." He was right. The peoples of central Europe and the old Ottoman empire did not live in conveniently divided communities. They were typically mixed up together. 
Thus self-determination for the Romanians of Transylvania meant newfound and unwelcome minority status for their Hungarian neighbors in a Greater Romania. Danzig (now Gdansk) was a predominantly German city surrounded by a Polish hinterland; Trieste and Fiume (Rijeka) were Italian outposts in a sea of rural Slovenes and Croats; Smyrna (Izmir) was an overwhelmingly Greek port in otherwise Turkish Asia Minor. Did these cities belong in Germany or Poland? Yugoslavia or Italy? Turkey or Greece? And what to make of a formerly Austrian city like Czernowitz (now Chernivtsi, Ukraine), a mixture of Germans, Jews, Romanians, Ruthenians, Poles, Hungarians and others besides? Communities that had lived for centuries in the same place under imperial tutelage suddenly found themselves minority interlopers in someone else's state.
The Paris negotiators did their best, but their efforts were doomed, as some of them already realized. Observing the fate of the stateless Ukrainians, Lloyd George wrote, "It fills me with despair the way in which I have seen small nations, before they have hardly leapt into the light of freedom, beginning to oppress other races than their own." MacMillan is sympathetic to the victors' problems. As to the German question, she shares the current revisionist view that the war guilt and reparations clauses were not especially harsh, given what the Germans had done. Neither Hitler nor World War II should be blamed upon Versailles, she suggests.
That seems right. But even if we agree that Keynes needs revising, MacMillan's overall assessment of the Paris decisions does seem a bit generous. After all, even at the time it was clear to someone like the British general Henry Wilson that terrible mistakes were being made. Of Western support for the unsuccessful Greek project to occupy Smyrna he rightly noted, "The whole thing is mad and bad." Winston Churchill rushed to Paris in an unsuccessful attempt to block the carving up of the Turkish empire: it would bring "eternal war" with the Muslim world, he warned, from the Mediterranean to India. And so it has.
After World War II, the Americans accepted their responsibility to remain economically involved in Europe's reconstruction (something Wilson had energetically refused in 1919). Instead of drawing unworkable frontiers and creating new minorities, the victors of 1945 shifted entire peoples. But on the whole they left in place the arrangements invented in Paris a quarter of a century before. 
As a result, Paris in the spring of 1919 is still the best starting place for anyone wishing to understand today's world. Yugoslavia and Czechoslovakia are gone. But the Greek-Turkish animosity (like that between Hungary and Romania) can be traced directly to decisions taken in Paris. So can the Balkan wars of the 1990's; the tribulations of Albanians in former Yugoslavia; the Armenian-Azerbaijani conflict; the Israel-Palestine hostilities; the claims of the Kurds and the territorial sensitivities of the Turks. Of the modern world's serious trouble spots, only Korea and Kashmir owe little to the actions and omissions of the men of 1919. And Iraq? A British invention, born with French concurrence 83 years ago in a Parisian drawing room.

GRAPHIC: Drawing: From left, the makers of the new world order in 1919: Woodrow Wilson, David Lloyd George, Georges Clemenceau. (Dugald Stermer)

PERSON: JUDT, TONY; MACMILLAN, MARGARET 

GEOGRAPHIC: PARIS, FRANCE (90%); HAMBURG, GERMANY (79%) EUROPE (92%); UNITED STATES (92%); FRANCE (91%); GERMANY (79%); CENTRAL EUROPE (72%); HUNGARY (72%)

TITLE: PARIS 1919: SIX MONTHS THAT CHANGED THE WORLD (BOOK) 

LOAD-DATE: December 1, 2002

SECTION: Section 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk; Pg. 27

LENGTH: 1066 words

HEADLINE: Home Planet Security 

BYLINE:  By Andres Martinez; Andres Martinez writes editorials for The Times.

 BODY:
 ONE WORLD
The Ethics of Globalization.
By Peter Singer.
235 pp. New Haven:
Yale University Press.
$21.95.
 CLOSE your eyes and picture your community. Whom do you see? Your family, surely. Work colleagues? Everyone who shares your area code? Your religion? All Americans? Folks in Afghanistan? Unless we start answering yes to all of the above, we're in for big trouble.
That's the message of Peter Singer's timely and thoughtful book, "One World: The Ethics of Globalization." A professor of bioethics at Princeton University and one of the most provocative philosophers of our time, Singer writes, "How well we come through the era of globalization (perhaps whether we come through it at all) will depend on how we respond ethically to the idea that we live in one world." 
"One World" is a manual for elaborating this response. Singer's recipes are at once simple and elusive: we need to do more as individuals to alleviate the plight of the world's poor, and the world needs more effective global governing bodies to establish protections like meaningful labor and environmental standards.
The United States, Singer says, often stands as an obstacle to humanity's quest to embrace the idea of one world. As a proportion of national wealth, American foreign aid is the skimpiest among rich countries. We constantly refuse to pay our United Nations bills. We have failed to join, and are busy trying to undermine, the new International Criminal Court, as well as global efforts to crack down on pollution and end discrimination against women.
Ignorance may be our best defense. How many Americans understand the extent to which their country, especially during the Bush presidency, strives to undermine collective action on a number of fronts? Surveys, Singer reminds us, have shown that Americans wrongly believe that some 20 percent of the federal budget goes to foreign aid. A majority of respondents would like to see foreign aid's slice of the pie "reduced" to 10 percent. Of course, that would amount to a more than tenfold increase in Washington's development assistance.
"One World" opens with an analogy between terrorists who fly planes into skyscrapers and drivers of sport utility vehicles who engage in less deliberate killing by contributing to global warming. But that is more a tease than a sign of things of things to come. As globalization polemics go, the book is rather restrained. More than a rant, it is a stimulating tour of the moral and practical challenges posed by the world's accelerating contraction. 
There is plenty here to encourage either side of the globalization debate. Singer serves up many of the same criticisms of the World Trade Organization that protesters at international gatherings chant about. Yet throughout, he seems to believe that globalization, if only we could regulate it properly, offers humanity its best hope. His is a study of how, not whether, to embrace globalization.
In chapters dedicated to the environment, trade, the evolution of international law and foreign aid, Singer grapples with globalization's thorniest questions. Among them: to what extent must political leaders look beyond their direct constituents and act out of a concern for the welfare of people everywhere? And here's one that's well timed: when may a state that is not itself under attack go to war? 
"One World" contains far more statistical analysis than one might expect from a volume on ethics. But there is a refreshing intellectual integrity in Singer's efforts to assess the facts on the ground, as when he writes, "No evidence that I have found enables me to form a clear view about the overall impact of economic globalization on the poor." Singer is equally perplexed about contradictory indications on whether global inequality is on the rise. At times, though, his exhaustive surveying of others' research can become tedious -- as if he feels the need to show he's done his homework. 
Singer is a calculating ethicist. He applauds Kofi Annan's doctrine of humanitarian intervention, arguing that sovereignty considerations should not prevent the international community from intervening to protect people from their own governments. But, he says, it would have been foolish to try to protect Chechnya from Russia, or Tibet from China. Costs must always be calculated when deciding whether to do something potentially beneficial. 
Singer's sense of realpolitik is more contrived when he writes that the war on terrorism has turned America's need to embrace altruism into a strategic imperative. This reads much like the spinning of an author who got a call from his editor on Sept. 12 demanding a new introduction. To argue that the terrorist attacks made the hardship of distant villagers a national security issue is to disregard the fact that much of America's development assistance during the cold war was conceived as part of the effort to contain Communism -- often with disastrous results for villagers. 
The book's strongest chapter is undoubtedly "One Atmosphere." It is, at one level, a primer on global efforts to contain greenhouse gas emissions, and it concludes with Singer's well-reasoned call for granting nations, based on their projected population in 2050, a fixed entitlement to the amount of emissions they can produce. Singer's plan envisions the trading of polluting rights, along the lines established domestically by the 1990 Clean Air Act.
The chapter on trade is less satisfying. Not only does Singer dwell on a number of past disputes (including some that even he concedes are a bit dated), but he fails to confront some of the issues that are most outrageous from a moral perspective, like the hypocritical agricultural subsidies in Europe and America and their dire consequences for poor nations. 
The pressing challenge for the new century, in Singer's view, is the creation of a truly democratic global government, and by this he emphatically does not mean federalism of the type that grants all countries one vote, with the powerful ones having a veto. A lamentable shortcoming of "One World" is its failure to dwell more on the experience of the European Union in this and other areas. The union, a trading bloc that has evolved into a formidable transnational regulator, is the one cutting-edge research lab for many of Singer's core issues, especially the need to subjugate national interests to the welfare of a broader community.

HEADLINE: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 12-01-02: ON LANGUAGE; 
Defenestration

BYLINE:  By William Safire 

 BODY:
The gangland moniker of Abe Reles was Kid Twist. In 1941, the Murder Inc. member became an informer for the police and helped the Brooklyn prosecutor Bill O'Dwyer send Frank (Dasher) Abbandano and Harry (Pittsburgh Phil) Strauss to the electric chair.
 But before he could testify against Louis (Lepke) Buchalter or Benjamin (Bugsy) Siegel, Reles -- in police custody -- jumped, or was pushed, out the window of the Half Moon Hotel in Coney Island. Wiseacres used a curious verb to describe his murder, suicide or deadly escape attempt: the Kid "defenestrated." 
 A generation later, in 1968, the New York Times columnist C. L. Sulzberger resuscitated the word in writing of the mysterious out-the-window death of the Czech patriot Jan Masaryk: "It was widely recalled that murder by defenestration had been most famously enacted in that same city of Prague in 1618, starting the Thirty Years' War."
My predecessor in columny was only slightly incorrect: the nobles of Bohemia, following a tradition started in 1419, did throw two imperial officials and a secretary out of a window of the Hradschin Palace in Prague. Legend has it they landed in a pile of manure and escaped uninjured. This casus belli (pronounced KAY-sus BELL-eye, Latin for "cause for war," now a favorite term in the Pentagon) became known to historians as the Second Defenestration of Prague.
This lengthy but undeniably colorful introduction has to do with the Latin-rooted word for "windows," one of the building blocks in the new language of architecture and design. The first question put to architects by savvy clients with knockout "signature" buildings in mind is "What unique concept do you have for the fenestration?"
The architectural critic of The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, Patricia (Pittsburgh Phil) Lowry, wrote in October of a new hospital: "the architects subtly varied the fenestration patterns, establishing individual identities for the two pavilions." In Canada, The Edmonton Journal hailed a Quebec architect for placing a new home's kitchen, bathrooms and utilities all against the north wall: "preventing the fenestration of that wall reduced energy losses."
This offers the lexicographer a fenestration of opportunity: let us examine the high-rising jargon that architects and designers call, self-mockingly, talkitecture or archispeak.
"Different colors articulated the planar composition of interior walls," Raul Barreneche writes in Interior Design. Edie Cohen, in the same magazine, notes how "through the series of pavilions and planar setbacks, the architects successfully mitigated mass." The word means "lying in a plane; two-dimensional." Never say flat.
Just as Hollywood producers do lunch, urban planners and landscape architects hold charettes. A charette was originally a Roman two-wheeled vehicle (not to be confused with a four-wheeled chariot) and later came to mean a small cart in which French architectural students placed their drawings. Now, according to The Tallahassee Democrat, a charette is "a collaborative design process involving citizens, business owners, government officials and architects." In The San Antonio Express-News, Ron Wilson recently wrote that his city's housing authority "scheduled an all-day 'charette,' or architecture design discussion, to get more public input for the project."
In the new urbanism, "pedestrian friendly" planners are designing streets and spaces to make people feel more comfortable. "We're really excited about a new urbanism-type of project," the economic development manager Susan Grafton told The Rocky Mountain News. "It is going to deliver a new residential, mixed-use project in the city." The developer Rob Dickson defined the Albuquerque High project as "the new urbanism: live, work and play in the same area."
Charles Bailey, a new urbanist landscape architect from Columbia, Md., explains: "After planning and building out in the suburbs and exurbs, we're redirecting planning back to where the people already are, incorporating mixed-use areas, short blocks, civic areas. Multimodal is a term we're using a lot. We're developing communities not just with commuter buses but with light-rail systems, fixed-route buses and more room for pedestrian traffic and bikes. We're holding a charette on that with all the disciplines represented along with people who tell us to save that historic tree on the corner."
Prof. Thomas Fisher, dean of the school of architecture at the University of Minnesota, notes: "In building construction, you hear solid Anglo-Saxon words: door, window, frame. In architecture, you hear words more Latin- and French-based: fenestration, porte-cochere. Architects use anatomy as metaphor: we refer to the arms, head, body of a building. If it has a central corridor that connects everything, we'll call it the spine. In teaching architecture, I see students adopt the jargon because it makes them feel part of the club, though people who use talkitecture more often talk about their work than do it. Teaching writing, I make them unlearn the jargon. You wouldn't use a word like blobitecture in your writing."
I would. The French porte-cochere is just a covered driveway, but blobitecture has a pejorative ring to it, the way edifice complex (a play on "Oedipus complex") was used to deride the tendency of Gov. Nelson Rockefeller of New York to build monumental structures in Albany.
The architect Greg Lynn coined the term blob architecture in 1995 with no derision in mind. He was drawing on a computer, clicking out a random cloud of points that assumed an amorphous shape, loose and formless as an amoeba, which digital designers sometimes call a "biomorphic form." Lynn tells me the term "blob" comes from a sort of acronym for a technical description of a computer-formed shape -- a "binary large object."
Although blob architecture "lacks the elegance, rigor and beauty that comes from modules, proportions and symmetry," Lynn says, "in due time, the blob architects will discover a new form of beauty and elegance in the voluptuous, rhythmic and undulating forms of the differential calculus."
The envelope-pushing architect has seen his term shortened to blobitecture. Those planar types who prefer traditional forms like cubes and spheres -- and who look askance at the seeming shapelessness of what developed into a new style -- seized on the predigital meaning of blob: a bubble or a globule of liquid resembling a teardrop, with an extended meaning of a gooseberry or duck's egg, which cricket players treat as a zero -- hence, an error or bonehead play.

HEADLINE: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 12-01-02; 
Interior Life

BYLINE:  By A. O. Scott; A. O. Scott is a film critic for the New York Times and a frequent contributor to the magazine.

 BODY:
On my battered brown desk, right next to the laptop on which I'm writing this, is a stack of thick-spined glossy magazines, their pages dogeared and bristling with Post-its. They are full of seductive images -- of glistening swanlike faucets, zaftig chairs, naughty little peekaboo drapes and an awful lot of naked blond wood flooring. And yet for all their voluptuousness, I regard these publications with dread and anxiety, as if they were the research materials for an overdue term paper. Their purpose, of course, is to inspire me, to pique my slumbering domestic imagination, but instead I only want to ransack them for easy ideas, hoping the plagiarism won't be noticed. They offer up a cornucopia of styles and choices -- fanciful and practical, cutting edge and neotraditional, Italian, Swedish, Danish and Amish, stainless and distressed, hand-woven and machine tooled -- and force me to confront the unavoidable realization that I have no style of my own. 
 And this, I have discovered, just will not do. It's not that my wife and I, who are about to embark on an insanely ambitious renovation of our apartment, have bad taste. When it comes to chairs, bookshelves, bed frames and stove tops, we know what we like -- we think. But that is hardly sufficient, and not only because one of us makes aesthetic judgments for a living and would deride any such statement about books, movies or popular music. What we choose will be a reflection of who we are, and so every item on the checklist -- brass or porcelain? birch or pine? recessed lighting or wall fixtures? -- presents an identity crisis in microcosm. 
 I suspect we are not alone. In the era of customized consumer capitalism, distinction is mass-produced, and connoisseurship has been democratized. The wide availability of a variety of beautiful, unusual things -- at Pottery Barn, on eBay, at stores that turn the junk of earlier eras into today's collectibles -- increases the pressure, the sense of responsibility, that attends every purchase. Like the food revolution, the design revolution is built on the lovely paradox that what is special should be available for everyone's enjoyment and that good taste can at last shed its residue of invidious social differences.
Which means that indifference is unacceptable. You can still eat meatloaf, of course, or wear a button-down blue oxford-cloth shirt or sit around a Formica table top in molded plastic chairs, but each of these actions must represent a decision, a declaration that in a world of endlessly multiplying aesthetic options, this is what you chose, this is who you are. Which is what I'm looking for in those shelter rags, and probably in these very pages.
Once upon a time, things were simpler. Our first jointly owned piece of furniture, bought in the early days of our cohabitation, when the future was as blank and full of promise as a freshly painted room on moving day, was a cheap pine fold-out futon frame. A few months ago, in anticipation of our impending redesign, we hauled that scuffed, exhausted frame -- which had been dismantled and reassembled, often in the absence of printed instructions, at least a half-dozen times -- out to the trash and said goodbye to our carefree youth. In our 20's, like most of the people we knew, we had feathered a series of provisional nests up and down the Eastern Seaboard with castoffs and hand-me-downs: a derelict sofa hauled in from the street, a table from some grandparent's garage, an armchair bought for $5 from a nursing home that was going out of business. What we purchased new usually involved particleboard or foam rubber, and not only for financial reasons. Our native state was transience, and we wanted nothing in our lives (apart from each other, our television and some of our books) that could not be thrown away if the need arose.
Gradually, though, our acquisitions took on a different character, and our transience was not the nomadism of early adulthood but a sign of the long work in progress of settling down. Our current nest, which we imagine will be permanent, is in a state of constant flux, every room a three-dimensional to-do list. An enormous wardrobe is crammed into a corner of the living room because eventually, when walls come down and doorways are widened, it will look nice in our bedroom. Framed posters are stacked in the closet because the walls they might look best on are slated for demolition, or at least repainting.
And the process will not end when the savings are used up and the contractors go home. There will be bathrooms to think about, bright playrooms to be made over into sullen teenagers' lairs. The horizon of renovation is endless; the word itself implies renewal, a great American obligation, the alternative to which is death. As soon as we declare our homes finished, they risk becoming our tombs.
Or, to put it less melodramatically, by the time the work is done, the kids will be out of the house and we will be ready to retire to some Sun Belt leisure community where all the bungalows look the same. Then we can sell our perfected dream apartment to people who will immediately tear up what took us decades to install in order to facilitate their own renewal. "It has great potential," the broker will say. And so, once upon a time, did we.
But I'm ahead of myself. My own renovation -- my rebirth as a person with taste -- awaits. Paint colors, counter tops and tile patterns must be selected, and no one can do it for us. Friends who are further along in their own odysseys of renovation will try to help us navigate wood grains, kitchen appliances, cabinets and lighting fixtures; the architect and the contractor will show us blueprints and drawings and pepper us with queries about light, space, flow and dimension, and we will scratch our heads and make our fateful choices. The thought of it makes me tired. I wish that old futon was still around, so I could take a nap.
