HEADLINE: Streetscapes/Reader's Question; 
Researching the Past of a Lower East Side Tenement

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
 Q -- We are home schooling our daughters and for our social studies unit this fall have decided to try to find out what we can about our building, 237-9 Eldridge Street, on the Lower East Side. About five years ago we were doing some renovations and found in the walls a pamphlet for the Max Kobre Russian Bank, offering services like rail and ship ticketing, and some envelopes inscribed in pencil "Shapiro" and "Isat Shapiro." Would you have any other suggestions for us, or advice on where we might begin? . . . Rachel Andreyev, Manhattan.

A -- For many buildings in Manhattan built in 1866 or later (1868 in Brooklyn, 1874 in the Bronx, 1898 in Queens and Staten Island) a researcher can use the Department of Buildings' fax-back buildings information system to zero in on the construction date. Dial the department's main number -- (212) 227-7000 -- and press 2 and then 3 to get to the information system and then the property profile overview.
 Farther down the telephone chain is the computerized Actions and Violations report for this building, which contains the numbers of older building and alteration permits. (The process is quicker with the block and lot number, but the address is sufficient, and if a fax machine is not available, a visit is possible to the Manhattan office, at 280 Broadway, at Chambers Street, Mondays to Fridays from 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., and Tuesdays from 8:30 a.m. to 8 p.m.) 
In your case the Actions & Violations report yields the number for the new building application -- NB148/1903, meaning the 148th plan filed for a new structure in 1903 in Manhattan. The article "Researching a New York City Building," posted on the Web at www.nysoclib.org, gives a general rundown on this procedure. 
To see the details of the new-building application, it is easiest to examine the microfilmed copies of the department's docket books (yearly application summaries) at the Municipal Archives, at 31 Chambers Street, Room 103, Mondays-Thursdays 9 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. and Fridays 9 a.m. to 1 p.m. The entry gives the basic data of the building, a six-story, 50-foot-front tenement erected in 1903, at a construction cost of $45,000. The developer was Leonor Spielberger of 76 St. Mark's Place, and the architects were Sass & Smallheiser, who did many tenement designs.
Land maps and other records show that Spielberger's single tenement replaced a pair of five-story buildings, each 25 feet wide. Listings from the digitized 1890 New York City directory at www.Ancestry.com indicate that they also were tenements, with 8 to 10 families apiece, whose occupants included Joseph Zwonk, a cigarmaker, and Robert Weir, a boatman.
Because these earlier land maps show the older buildings without any light wells on either side, they were probably built before the 1879 law that required lozenge-shaped air shafts on either side. Post-1879 structures, because of their narrower central areas, are often called dumbbell tenements. 
In 1901, a new tenement law was passed with stricter light-court requirements. This legislation made it much less economic to build the old 25-foot-front tenements, like the one now occupied by the Tenement House Museum, at 97 Orchard Street, and spurred wider 50-foot-front tenements, like yours. 
Although the nomenclature has become muddied, buildings erected before the 1901 law are generally called old-law tenements, and those built afterward, like yours, are called new-law tenements. "A History of Housing in New York City," by Richard Plunz (Columbia University Press, 1990), contains an excellent section on tenement planning and legislation.
No post-1890 New York City directories have been digitized, and census returns are not fully searchable yet online. To determine occupancy of 237-239 Eldridge you will have to check census returns in person. Most people use the local-history section of the New York Public Library at the main branch, at 42nd Street and Fifth Avenue (Tuesdays and Wednesdays, 11 a.m.-7:30 p.m., Thursdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m.-6 p.m.) or the National Archives regional office, at 201 Varick Street, near Canal Street (Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, 8 a.m.-4:30 p.m., Tuesdays and Thursdays, 8 a.m.- 8 p.m.). 
Perhaps the "Isat Shapiro" of your envelope is captured by the 1910 census as Isaac Shapiro, 35, who had been in the United States for nine years but still spoke only Yiddish. Like most of the building's residents, his birthplace was listed as "Russ.-Yiddish." A carpenter, he had been out of work for 40 weeks in 1909 and lived at No. 237-239 with his wife, Frada, daughters Minnie, 7, and Pauline, 2, and son, Isidor, 3. Isaac had come over in 1904, followed by his wife and eldest daughter in 1906; Isidor and Pauline were born in the United States.
The census records are rich documents of humanity, practically short stories in the way they capture fragmentary glimpses of some people, like Isie "last name unknown," a 20-year-old boarder in the apartment of Max Goldstein. Isie was a peddler, described as "house to house." Looking at the occupations column of the census evokes a lost age: ice dealer; ladies' shirtwaists; seltzer business; brancher, artificial flowers; barrel dealer; hat pins. The latter was the given occupation of Fannie Ackerman, 15, who had arrived in the United States in 1904. 
Your children can search records of adjacent buildings to see if there were racial or ethnic distinctions among building tenants, and can search forward and backward to see how a street's population changed over time, up through the latest census open to the public, that of 1930. 
The ProQuest database of the digitized New York Times, available at many libraries, yields a number of citations for "237 Eldridge," including an October 1930 article about the closing of an illegal liquor operation in the building and a 1956 article about the arrest of a teenager who lived there and was planning an attack on another boy. It also picks up a 1904 article about Spielberger, the building's developer. He was a hotelkeeper in Rockaway Beach and began building operations in Manhattan in 1901; he declared bankruptcy in 1904.
Max Kobre of the Max Kobre Bank also had financial difficulties. In 1914 his three bank branches -- one on the Lower East Side and two in Brooklyn -- were shut down by the State Banking Department. Kobre was indicted on charges of banking fraud along with a partner, Moses Ginsberg. (Ginsberg was later vindicated, according to his 1959 obituary in The Times, and was designated a federal court trustee for the bank's liquidation. He entered the real estate business and in 1930 built the Carlyle Hotel, at 76th Street and Madison Avenue.)
There were near riots in 1914 at the Kobre bank at Canal Street and Broadway, although the depositors there ultimately got back 55 cents on the dollar. 
In 1916, on the day before Kobre's trial, his body was found under the open jet of a gas stove in his gas-filled kitchen at 115 West 122nd Street. But the coroner said that Kobre had suffered from heart disease, and the verdict was that death was from natural causes, so his estate got the proceeds of his $600,000 life insurance policy, which was divided among the depositors. 
Was Mr. Shapiro one of them? Perhaps not. By that time he was living in Harlem.

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
The Acts of Devotion Begin With the Doors

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH GIOVANNINI 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
CHURCHES sometimes channel their spiritual message informally through a few touchable details. In September, the Cathedral of Our Lady of the Angels opened in downtown Los Angeles, and parishioners are already reaching out to the small Chinese turtle, the spread-winged Chumash condor and the other figures on the Great Bronze Doors at the entrance, created by the Los Angeles-based sculptor Robert Graham.
 Visitors tentatively rub the archaic religious symbols in an instinctive gesture, as though making physical contact with wonder. Some bring their fingers to their lips for a devotional kiss. Mothers have lifted their babies to the reliefs so that they can feel the church, which was designed by the Spanish architect Rafael Moneo. The talismanic gates, made for this, the first Roman Catholic cathedral to be built in the United States in 40 years, invite visitors into an intimate relationship with the sacred. 
 A monument within a monument, Mr. Graham's 25-ton gates are made up of a pair of 15-foot-tall decorated doors centered at the bottom of a larger pair that are 20feet tall and 30 feet wide. The turtle, condor and some 40 other figures associated with ancient cultures occupy the smaller doors, along with a half-dozen tablets depicting various Virgin Marys from different Latin American cultures. The Virgin of Guadalupe, with her thornless roses, prays above the Virgin of the Rosary of Chichinquira. She in turn reigns in two panels opposite the Virgin of Loreto, who, in her flaring dress, hovers above flying angels. 
Both sets of doors pivot independently beneath a bronze tympanum, a recessed space that that frames Mr. Graham's interpretation of the Virgin. Here she is a serene and regal eight-foot-tall figure that leans forward, eyes closed, arms outstretched, palms up in an attitude of spiritual surrender. She floats above a luminous crescent moon, under a gilded circle that glows like a halo in the dependable Southern California sun.
Mr. Graham has given the Virgin ambiguous features, nearly as multicultural as Los Angeles itself -- a Caucasian nose, Asian eyes, African lips, thick American Indian hair. She has none of the aristocratic fragility that is often depicted in European paintings. This new Virgin of the Americas might be local, just off the boardwalk at Venice Beach, or fresh from the fields in the Central Valley. With this image and his array of ancient religious symbols, Mr. Graham ties this 21st-century church both to Catholic traditions and distant mythology. The gates are a Rosetta stone suggesting translations of faith between cultures. 
Lorenzo Ghiberti's 15th-century Gates of Paradise at the Baptistry in Florence, Italy, are perhaps the best known bronze gates in a long and venerable Catholic tradition. But in the last 100 years, the tradition has retreated, a casualty of increasingly secular times and withering economics: sculptors can no longer afford the artisans needed to produce labor-intensive bronze doors. 
Mr. Graham's gates represent four years of work by an unlikely, cigar-smoking art-world figure who subcontracts much of the labor to computer labs. Mr. Graham, 64, earned his Pop Art credentials in the 1960's sculpturing wax figures romping on beds in miniature erotic tableaus encased in acrylic boxes. In the 1970's, he switched mediums, and sensibilities, creating with a clinician's eye anatomically perfect, genitally detailed female bronze figures. He often portrayed his models with pretzellike limbs, or standing rigid in almost Pharaonic poses. If seen in natural light, the figures seem ready to spring. When he digitized his clay sculptures to translate them to the larger scale necessary in public work, Mr. Graham brought an ancient medium into the 21st century. 
Reacting against the commercial gallery scene and what he calls "a floating world" of objects unrelated to their location, Mr. Graham took on public commissions that gave context to his sculpture. Recalling the great murals he saw as a child growing up in Mexico City, and the frescoes he admired in Italy early in his career, Mr. Graham wanted his work to be seen and understood by a wide audience, not just the cognoscenti. In 1984, he created his first nationally prominent site-specific public sculpture, the two male and female figures that topped a gateway through which the Olympic flame was carried into the 1984 Los Angeles Games. 
His belief that art could and should have content beyond its own form was confirmed in 1999, when his monument to Charlie Parker in Kansas City, Mo., was considered as a repository for Parker's remains. "As a reliquary, the monument gained importance," said Mr. Graham, sitting in the haze of his own smoke in his Venice studio, looking prophetic in his mane of thick, wavy gray hair. A pair of bronze angels that never made it to the cathedral tympanum lay on a table in a roiling heap of baroque drapery and limbs. 
Cardinal Roger M. Mahony, archbishop of Los Angeles, awarded Mr. Graham the commission for the doors in 1998, commending him not only for his work in the public realm but also for his "exceptional sensitivity to the female figure."
Unlike sculptors working with abstract forms, however, Mr. Graham wanted to fold explicit religious content into his doors, and he immediately plunged into Catholic literature. "I took the religious message seriously," he said, adding, "but of course I had to reinvent it." His nudes had been sexual -- "everyone could understand it," he said. Now his figures needed a collective religious meaning shared by congregants. The character of the nudes that the Cardinal praised had resided in their proud, independent body postures rather than in their faces, which were expressionless. With the heavily draped Virgin Mary, the character migrated from the body to the face.
Mr. Graham's doors have a complex aesthetic relationship with the church, being symbolic and narrative in an abstract setting. Mr. Moneo fragmented the structure, designing a facade with a flying window bay and roof overhangs that are dramatically pitched toward drivers speeding along the adjacent Hollywood freeway. The presence of the gates splits the church's identity into abstract-versus-representational idioms, objective versus subjective -- as if two different artistic voices were debating here. Mr. Moneo's architecture is rooted in a secular aesthetic that he tries to make religious through a play of light, while Mr. Graham uses symbols to conjure an aura of holiness. 
Behind the small squares that support the turtle, condor and other figures, fretted surfaces texture the background; these are "fingerprints" left by a five-axis milling machine driven by a computer. Rodin left his bronzes animated with impressions of his fingers working the clay. The surfaces recorded the process of creation. With the corduroy-type surfaces imprinted by the routers, Mr. Graham expressed the process by which he translated his work to large scale. The computer essentially gave him the equivalent of scores of artisans, without the overhead. "It's like having a studio of 100 people working on the Statue of Liberty," he said. "All those hands." 
Mr. Graham's gates, then, are "smart." While the computer's logarithmic intelligence was instrumental in Mr. Moneo's angular design (there are few right angles), it is sublimated in Mr. Graham's concept for the gates. The computer doesn't open up a new art for the sculptor, altering his vision, but remains its servant. Nor does the computer invade the Catholicism of the gates as a double agent working surreptitiously for the forces of a new secular humanism. "Technology may allow you to do anything, but you need a reason to do it," he said. 
Resisting the temptation of idolizing the new machine for its feats of technological virtuosity, Mr. Graham deliberately keeps his gates focused on their religious role. They serve primarily as portals into sacred space, passed by people who may know little about art. Parts of the doors are already becoming shiny.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The artist Robert Graham, left, designed an eight-foot-tall multicultural bronze Virgin, right, which stands atop the 25-ton bronze entrance gates, above, at Rafael Moneo's Cathedral of Our Lady of Angels. (Photographs by Monica Almeida/The New York Times)

ORGANIZATION: ROMAN CATHOLIC CHURCH 

PERSON: GRAHAM, ROBERT; GIOVANNINI, JOSEPH

HEADLINE: At Medical Schools, A Time of Change 

BYLINE:  By GALE T. SCOTT

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
IN the weeks since Governor McGreevey unveiled an ambitious plan to reorganize the state's university system, alternating currents of hope and fear have been pulsing through faculty members and administrators who could be affected by such a vast change.
 The goal of the governor, simple enough in its complexity, is the consolidation of the state's universities -- Rutgers, the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, which has eight health education-related schools, and the New Jersey Institute of Technology -- with an emphasis on improving medical education and building a national reputation for research. 
 As for the more than 13,000 teachers, administrators and support staff whose state-financed jobs could be swept up in this effort, the issue is equally simple: job security.
The fear, doctors and faculty members say, is that there is a hidden agenda focusing on cutting costs by using the restructuring as a cover to nullify existing agreements on tenure, staffing and job security.
"The faculty is nervous," said Dr. Larry Frohman, a neurological ophthalmologist at University Hospital in Newark, part of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. "Many of us think is that this is about money, not excellence. My feeling is that the commission was handed its conclusions before the report was written." 
The plan, unveiled in October by a commission appointed by Governor McGreevey, recommended that the three research universities be recast as a single university of 64,000 students with semiautonomous campuses in Newark, New Brunswick and Camden. It also recommended consolidating leadership of the proposed new university by creating the position of chancellor. The commission that produced the 114-page report was headed by Dr. P. Roy Vagelos, a retired chief executive of Merck & Company who is a former faculty member of several medical schools.
The plan has been embraced by the New Jersey Institute of Technology and tepidly endorsed by Rutgers. But current and former officials at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey have been highly critical of the proposed merger, which is not surprising since the commission report lamented the school's reputation and said acidly that "the goal of excellence has not been achieved."
The volley was recently returned by Stanley S. Bergen, former president of the university, who said: "The report's methodology is inconsistent and poorly documented. It scrutinizes U.M.D.N.J. under a microscope, examines Rutgers with the naked eye, and glances at N.J.I.T. through a telescope."
Any reorganization would require the approval of the State Legislature and take years to put in place. First the governor plans to appoint a task force that will develop a blueprint for creating the new university. As Mr. McGreevey has frequently said, his overarching goal is the improvement of the state's medical schools, with the goal of attracting tens of millions of dollars in federal and private grants for medical and biotechnical research.
"If they do this thing right, if it's really about excellence, then it is all wonderful news," said Gordon Thomas, a professor of physics and biomedical researcher at the New Jersey Institute of Technology who was recruited from Massachusetts Institute of Technology two years ago. The institute, with 8,900 students, is the smallest of the universities named in the report with colleges of engineering, architecture, computer science, and liberal arts and science.
"The idea of making a world-class university with more collaboration among colleagues is fabulous," said Dr. Thomas. "But it matters how they do it. It will take resources."
But faculty members interviewed elsewhere were skeptical of the plan. In a state with a $4 billion deficit projected for the fiscal year 2004, the higher education budget makes a fat target, said Liz Raveche, a cancer researcher and president of the American Association of University Professors at the University of Medicine and Dentistry, which represents professors at all three schools.
"The elephant in the room that no one wants to talk about is what happens to contracts and tenure," Dr. Raveche said.
According to the University of Medicine and Dentistry in New Jersey, nearly 19 percent, or 425 of the faculty's 2,246 members, have tenure.
"If the organization you were working for doesn't exist and there's a new organization, it seems obvious that there's no more contract," she said.
According to the National Education Association, teachers should not assume that tenure -- or jobs -- will continue because such agreements automatically come up for renegotiation when schools are dissolved.
"These faculty members do need to be concerned," said Rachel Hendrickson, coordinator for the education association's higher education program. "Obviously the N.E.A. strongly believes it is everyone's best interest for contracts and tenure to continue, but there are no guarantees."

No Word on Tenure
When Governor McGreevey's office was asked about the issue of tenure, it referred the question to Dr. Vagelos, who declined to discuss the matter.
"We're not going to talk about tenure and staffing yet," he said, "What we did say is we would set up a task force to review and implement the plan and will deal with all such items going forward."
Yet some of the faculty at the University of Medicine and Dentistry conceded that losing some tenured staff and renegotiating contracts might not be all bad.
"I can think of several people in my department who really ought to step down," said one scientist from the Rutgers University campus in Newark, who asked not to be identified. "Medical research has moved so fast that many people just have not been able to keep up.'
And Dr. Frohman said efforts to run University Hospital smoothly were frustrated by union "bumping" rules.
"I can fire someone for not doing their job, but if that person has seniority, he or she is back on the job the next day," he said. "The rules force us to dismiss the last person we hired."
At the center of the debate has been Dr. Vagelos, who was invited by Governor McGreevey to head the commission by way of a request that came through former Gov. Brendan Byrne as the two played tennis one afternoon last year at the doctor's home.
In a recent interview, Dr. Vagelos readily agreed that more money would have to be spent on medical education. "The difference between where we are now and being in the top 10 is about $141 million," he said.
Last year, New Jersey spent about $42 million on each of its medical schools as against a state average nationwide of $57 million, Dr. Vagelos noted, adding that on average, the top 10 schools each spent $181 million supporting their medical schools.
While he saw the need for more money for such things as student housing, something U.M.D.N.J. does not have, he also said that costs had to be controlled by making all of the schools accountable to one chancellor. 
Standing in the way of changes right now is a balky state economy, though Dr. Vagelos expressed optimistism that things would pick up, in part by growth in the areas of pharmaceuticals and biotechnology.
In the meantime, U.M.D.N.J. has already begun a $500 million building project in Newark, and there is construction going on at Rutgers as well. "It's a good time to reprogram," he said.
Helping to chart a new course, Dr. Vagelos and his committee enlisted the help of McKinsey & Company, a consulting firm in McLean, Va., which conducted the research.
Along with Ruth Charbonneau, director of policy and research for the New Jersey Department of Health and Senior Services, four members of the consulting firm visited several medical schools around the country, reporting back to the commission members.
Later this month, the governor's task force is expected to begin meeting to decide how to implement the recommendations as well as come up with cost estimates and specific steps to move the consolidation along. According to the governor, legislation on the actual restructuring will be introduced early next year.
The report by Dr. Vagelos's committee -- which envisions a system similar to that of the University of California, linking the state's medical schools and colleges -- was highly critical of what it saw as the mediocre reputation of the University of Medicine and Dentistry.
That judgment was based, at least in part, on its conclusion that many of the slots in the medical school's residency programs have gone unfilled or have been granted to graduates of foreign medical schools -- often considered a reflection of whether the school enjoys a good reputation.
Dr. Vagelos said he was taken aback by a counterattack from the medical school, which has included a 6,000-word critique written by Dr. Bergen, the former president of the university, along with his successor, Dr. Stuart Cook.
"They think I'm the devil, trying to bring down the medical school," Dr. Vagelos said in a recent interview. "Nothing could be further from the truth. The idea is not to destroy but improve."
The university's critique took issue with the plan's methodology and its finding that the state's medical schools -- the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School in New Brunswick and the New Jersey Medical School in Newark -- had failed to attract top-caliber researchers.

Concern for the Poor
Dr. Frohman of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey said his doctors were particularly concerned about the possibility of cuts in medical services provided to the poor.
Though the report made a point of commending the hospital for its service to the indigent and favored having it remain part of the medical school, it also concluded, "Were losses at University Hospital to mount, the university and the state should consider a separate ownership structure."
In Newark, University Hospital pays for almost 70 percent of the care for the uninsured through "Charity Care," a state-financed program.
That includes the bills of patients like one 70-year-old patient treated recently by Dr. Roger Turbin, an assistant professor of ophthalmology at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey and director of ophthalmic trauma at University Hospital.
The patient had gone lost the sight in his right eye after a stroke.
In many hospitals there would have been little doctors could do, said Dr. Turbin. But within an hour of visiting his eye doctor, the man was in a University Hospital surgical suite with a team of specialists.
Dr. Turbin and others performed a delicate experimental procedure -- one that usually costs about $20,000 -- in which they threaded a one-millimeter diameter catheter through an artery in the patient's groin all the way to his right eye. They then used the catheter to inject a drug that dissolved a clot and allowed the patient to regain his sight.
Among Dr. Turbin's concerns is whether a reorganization would result in the reassignment of some colleagues to one of the university's other medical school facilities. Its students and medical residents also work in Robert Wood Johnson Hospital in New Brunswick and Cooper Hospital in Camden.
Unlike University Hospital -- which is owned by U.M.D.N.J. -- those hospitals are private not-for-profit corporations.
"We are in a centralized location, with multiple services available to us instantly," Dr. Turbin said. "If the university is broken up, and those services go to different areas, patients might not even get in to see us. I just don't see what they would accomplish in separating the medical schools."
But Robert Altenkirch, president of the New Jersey Institute of Technology, said the merger could result in better care for patients, and not just in New Jersey.
"I'm very much in favor of the restructuring," Dr. Altenkirch said. "The walls between practical medicine and lab science, particularly enhanced computing and engineering, are coming down."
As a result, he said, the latest developments will be able to move from the research lab to doctors with a minimum of bureaucracy. 
And so the debate goes on. With every voice in opposition, there is seemingly a voice of optimism. Supporters share a vision that the state's three state medical schools will become Harvards on the Passaic, Raritan, and Delaware.
"All the feedback I've gotten on the plan has been very positive," said Dr. William Hait, director of the Cancer Institute of New Jersey who was also a member of the Vagelos committee. "There have been too many artificial separations of institutions that are already working together."
At the University of California at San Diego, Dr. Edward W. Holmes, vice chancellor for health sciences and dean of the school or medicine, said the plan to put U.M.D.N.J. and Rutgers into the same state university system was "definitely the way New Jersey should go."
"When a school of medicine sits at the center of a campus, everyone benefits," Dr. Holmes said. "The scientists see their fundamental discovery translated into patient care. Breakthroughs tend to take place at the margins when engineering, physics, and medicine come together."
As for an argument raised by some faculty members at U.M.D.N.J. that the school, founded in 1970, was too new to be the best, Dr. Holmes disagreed. "Our school didn't exist 35 years ago," he said. "We've been ranked fourth in the nation."
But California invested more money. According to the Vagelos commission's report, in 2001 California contributed $116,000 for each medical student at San Diego. By contrast, New Jersey contributed $75,000 per student at New Jersey Medical School in Newark and $85,000 at Robert Wood Johnson Medical School in New Brunswick.
Beyond the state's financing, the governor and others who want to change the system contend that too much grant money from pharmaceutical companies and the federal government is going to schools in other states.
Though New Jersey attracts $10 billion a year in private research spending, according to the New Jersey Commission on Science and Technology, it ranks 24th among states receiving grants from the National Institutes of Health -- with its 2003 budget listing 588 awards totaling $182 million.
Just as jarring, two of New Jersey's pharmaceutical giants, Merck and Company and Novartis AG. this year opened major new research laboratories -- in Massachusetts. In news releases, both companies said the availability of top researchers and medical schools in the Boston area weighed heavily in their decisions.
As Dr. Holmes of California put it, grant money follows the research talent.
"The reputation of New Jersey's medical schools outside the state is that they are average, above average in some areas," he said. "They shouldn't be average in any area. It just isn't good enough."

Fears About Newark
There is another issue that few are eager to discuss on the record -- the ability of any university located in Newark to attract top students and researchers, several faculty and deans interviewed said.
Despite efforts to revitalize the city, it still engenders a bunker mentality in many commuters. Crime and the fear of crime has led to the need to post armed guards at faculty parking lots, and for them to escort workers to their cars after dark.
"Newark can be bleak," said Ricki Goldman, a professor of information systems at N.J.I.T. "There's no place to eat, no place to shop, nowhere to get a cup of coffee." Despite those reservations, she expressed optimism about a restructuring, saying, "It could mean more interdisciplinary work, better connections with industry, increased opportunity for research."
Dr. Vagelos acknowledged the problems, saying, "Newark is not Palo Alto."
But he said it could change, citing the strategy used to attract residents and businesses to the frayed West Philadelphia neighborhood surrounding the University of Pennsylvania -- like giving developers land with an agreement that they would build housing and schools,
"West Philly has been transformed from what it was 10 years ago," Dr. Vagelos said. "It's a real success."
His plans for the University Heights section of Newark include building student housing, and from that he said he was confident that merchants would follow.
"A lot of the great medical schools are in bad urban neighborhoods," he said. 
That is where the "best" patients are, he said, people who because of poverty, lack of health insurance, and other gaps that separate their daily lives from those of people in more affluent suburbs, are sicker and more likely to get injured. 
Those are the patients from whom doctors can learn the most, he said.
"I'm betting that 5 or 10 years from now Newark will be home to an exciting, bustling, vibrant university," Dr. Vagelos said.

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about the proposed reorganization of the universities in New Jersey misstated the affiliation of Dr. Elizabeth Raveche. She is president of the faculty organization at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. (The president of the university's chapter of the American Association of University Professors is Dr. Talib Najjar.)
An article on Dec. 8 about the proposed reorganization of the state universities in New Jersey misstated the level of state financing for its medical schools in 2001. According to the State Commission on Health Science, Education and Training, the National Institutes of Health contributed $38.1 million to the New Jersey Medical School and $46.7 million to Robert Wood Johnson Medical School last year for biomedical research, as against an average of $57 million apiece for state-affiliated medical schools nationwide. The 10 best-financed state-affiliated medical schools received an average of $181 million apiece.
In state financing, New Jersey Medical School received $75,000 per student and Robert Wood Johnson Medical School $85,000.

HEADLINE: Use of Hicksville Rail Yard Questioned 

BYLINE:  By STEWART AIN

 BODY:
LEADERS of a Hicksville civic group are up in arms over an agreement to abandon railroad freight operations in Garden City and to step up freight traffic in Hicksville. 
 They say that freight operations have ceased in Hicksville, and they want to keep it that way. Railroad officials disagree. They say that although freight in Hicksville has slowed to a molasses pace, operations there have never stopped completely. 
 The civic association says it was caught by surprise by the agreement and learned of it only after it was announced. "Why were we kept in the dark?" said Gregory Yatzyshyn, a trustee of the NorthWest Civic Association, which represents 150 families in the northwest section in Hicksville. "We don't understand. Why were we not treated equally with Garden City? Just because Garden City has money or influence, why should everything be dumped in Hicksville? It appears that Garden City has more money than Hicksville, which is why we consider it economic discrimination."
The freight yard in Garden City is at the site of the former Roosevelt Raceway near Stewart Avenue. The Hicksville freight yard is on West John Street opposite Cantiague Park.
After learning of what Anthony Sorvillo, another trustee, called a "sweetheart deal" in August 2001, the civic association's members met with representatives of the L.I.R.R. and the New York & Atlantic Railway, which began freight operations using L.I.R.R. tracks in 1997. But the civic group was not satisfied with the answers from L.I.R.R. officials, and in September it filed a Freedom of Information request with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the L.I.R.R.'s parent. The civic group is seeking documents on the L.I.R.R.'s use of the Hicksville yard from January 1965 through December 1997 in an effort to rebuff the railroad's contention that the yard is not being reopened but rather has never been closed.
Mr. Sorvillo, who lives about eight blocks from the Hicksville freight yard, said he had been told by railroad personnel that since 1965 the yard had been used exclusively by rail and signal maintenance crews. "We can see that no trucks come in and out of there," he said. "We're not blind."
Bruce Lieberman, the chairman of the New York & Atlantic Railway, said it was understandable that residents had not noticed freight traffic at the Hicksville yard because there has been so little of it. In the last year, he said, only about a dozen freight cars were unloaded there.
"That's about one a month," he said. "We're not going to cap it at that -- obviously we are trying to get more freight -- but understand the size of this. What do they think is going to happen? Less than 3 percent of the freight coming to Long Island is by rail. It was down to almost nothing five years ago." 
Nicholas P. Episcopia, the president of the Eastern Property Owners Association of Garden City, which has about 2,000 members, said that he did not know of anyone who sought special privileges to keep the yard closed. "I have no idea what they are talking about," he said.
Mr. Episcopia said that when there was discussion in the late 1990's about reopening the freight yard, the community asked only that an environmental impact study be conducted first. "If the environmental impact study had shown no adverse impact, there would have been nothing we could do about it," he said. "But the railroad switched gears and decided to abandon it."
Brian Dolan, an L.I.R.R. spokesman, said that the decisions involving the Hicksville and Garden City freight yards were part of a larger transaction involving the East Side Access Project. The access project, to be completed in 2012, will allow Long Island passengers the option of going to Grand Central Terminal instead of Pennsylvania Station. As part of the access project, Mr. Dolan said, in August 2001, the L.I.R.R. and the New York & Atlantic agreed to transfer some of their freight yards in a move that benefited them both.
"The New York & Atlantic Railway transferred to the Long Island Rail Road two freight properties in Long Island City, Yard A and the Arch Street Yard, which are needed for early construction on the access project," Mr. Dolan said. "In addition, it transferred the Garden City freight yard in exchange for the Hicksville yard, which at the time we shared with them."
Mr. Dolan confirmed that the Garden City yard had not been used for freight in years. As Mr. Lieberman put it: "To bring stuff to Garden City, you have to travel up the extension and go out to the yard. But we pass Hicksville all the time. And part of the function of the yard is that we don't often unload cars there but leave them for later delivery."
In giving up its half of the Hicksville yard, the L.I.R.R. agreed to move its rail and signal maintenance crews, 75 employees in all, and their equipment to the Garden City yard. 
Mr. Lieberman said that there were no plans to increase the size of the Hicksville yard. "There is no physical space to expand," he said. "What you see is what you get. The yard is ringed by industrial buildings, and I don't think any of them are going away."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Garden City yard is used by L.I.R.R. maintenance crews, who store cranes and snow equipment there. (Phil Marino for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Suozzi Unveils Development Plan 

BYLINE:  By BRUCE LAMBERT

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY 

 BODY:
WHEN Long Island's population exploded after World War II, it did so without any overall plan.
 In fact, Nassau's first master plan was not adopted till 1998 -- long after the county was already covered with sprawling strip malls, cookie-cutter homes, cul-de-sacs, congested highways and high-tax school districts. 
 Now County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi has come up with a new strategy for tackling the problems of what he calls "America's first mature suburb" and its 1.3 million residents. 
Mr. Suozzi, who took office Jan. 1, outlined his own plans for Nassau at a meeting on Tuesday with about 150 local government, business and civic leaders.
Heading his list of goals are reviving the older downtowns, preserving open space, attracting businesses with high-paying jobs, redeveloping polluted sites, expanding the tax base and building moderate-priced housing for beginning workers and retirees and promoting tourism, sports and entertainment.
"We're trying to give people a clear road map on what will make this a better county," Mr. Suozzi said in an interview. 
In that vein Mr. Suozzi unveiled a new map that organizes the county into 35 economic development zones. The map sets the stage for the next phase, in which local officials and neighborhood groups will meet and start drafting specific projects for their areas. A similar effort is already under way to revive beleaguered Roosevelt.
A major obstacle to planning in Nassau has been its Balkanization into dozens of municipalities and hundreds of special districts. Mr. Suozzi's new economic development zones attempt to bridge those boundaries by grouping similar neighborhoods together. For example, Zone 18 combines East Meadow, Levittown and Salisbury.
Mr. Suozzi was flanked by numerous local leaders who praised the concept. They included the supervisors of Nassau's three towns: Richard V. Guardino Jr. of Hempstead, John Venditto of Oyster Bay, both Republicans, and May W. Newburger of North Hempstead, a Democrat, as is Mr. Suozzi.
Others joining in the announcement included village officials and leaders of the Long Island Convention and Visitors Bureau and the Long Island Association, a leading civic and business group.
Because of the helter-skelter growth of the past, "what we ended up with is a hodgepodge," Mr. Suozzi said at a news conference after the meeting. "It wasn't planned for."
Now Nassau needs to guide its own future and identity, Mr. Suozzi said. "We're not just a bedroom community of New York City anymore," he said. Describing Nassau as "between Queens and Suffolk" in development as well as in geography, he said that preserving the county's suburban character was paramount. 
While Mr. Suozzi is focusing on Nassau's problems, he also said that the county needs to retain and build on its many strengths. They include a highly skilled work force, numerous beaches and parks, top-rated schools and hospitals, rising property values and the lowest crime rate for a county of its size.
Leaders of the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit research and advocacy group for the metropolitan region, previewed Mr. Suozzi's proposal and gave it high marks.
"We are very much behind the things he is doing on planning on Long Island, and he is absolutely headed in the right direction," said a spokesman for the association, Jeremy Soffin. The group's president, Robert Yaro, described the proposal as "visionary."

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
A Daunting Task for Computer Associates' Chief

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH

 BODY:
DAVID H. PEIREZ'S first impression of Sanjay Kumar came about two years ago. Mr. Peirez, a corporate lawyer in Garden City, met Mr. Kumar, then the second in command at Computer Associates International in Islandia, when they both arrived at a breakfast meeting about the same time.
 Most of the meeting's details have been forgotten, Mr. Peirez, a senior partner in Reisman Peirez & Reisman, said last week, but he has not forgotten Mr. Kumar's quiet authority and regular-guy manner. Later that year, Mr. Peirez volunteered his support -- unbidden, he said -- when Computer Associates' management came under attack from Sam Wyly, the Texas investor who sought control of the company's board. 
 "Sanjay drove a regular car, not a Bentley or something hyperluxurious," said Mr. Peirez, who spearheaded a coalition aimed at keeping the company on Long Island. "He drove himself, instead of being driven. I came away with the impression of Sanjay as a very open guy who doesn't mince words." 
With the abrupt resignation on Nov. 18 of Charles B. Wang as Computer Associates' chairman and Mr. Kumar's promotion to the top spot, speculation on the company's future has been rife. Very much at the center of the speculation is Mr. Kumar, who at 40 now holds the three top positions -- chairman, president and chief executive -- at the world's fifth-largest software company. Having helped run the company for nearly a decade, he now must demonstrate that he can steer it back into profitability after it posted $1 billion loss its last fiscal year, which ended March 31.
The other challenges facing him are considerable. The list includes a criminal investigation into the company's accounting methods, a probe by government securities regulators, loss of investor confidence, image problems among corporate customers, and dismal forecasts for the entire information technology sector.
Some Long Islanders are watching the change of command from a purely local perspective. Computer Associates is the Island's largest company in terms of market value, and more than any other, it has replaced the Grumman Corporation as the symbolic center of the regional economy. 
From that vantage point, the appointment of Mr. Kumar, who lives in Oyster Bay, was widely welcomed. "Computer Associates is a Long Island company, and Sanjay is a Long Islander," said Peter Goldsmith, the president of the Long Island Technology Network. "His appointment is good news."
Generally, Mr. Kumar has gotten good reviews from analysts, fund managers and others who track the company. "Sanjay gets it," said Betsy Burton, an analyst for Gartner Inc. in its San Jose, Calif., office. "Sanjay understands how to work with partners, how to manage market perception, how to deal with the press and deal with analysts. He has better interactive skills." 
Mr. Wang, who shepherded Computer Associates from a struggling start-up to the ranks of America's biggest companies, with 15,000 employees, drove growth largely through acquisitions, hard-nosed negotiating and the cultivation of what critics called a Darwinian work-place culture.
He also rewarded himself and other insiders handsomely. Mr. Wang, Mr. Kumar and Russell Artzt, the executive vice president for research, claimed more than $1.1 billion in bonuses in 1998, based on the company's market value. Shareholders rebelled; the three gave back about half the bonus pay. How the company determined its value in the years 1995 through 1998 is the subject of two federal investigations.
Robert Gordon, a spokesman for the company, said the resignation of Mr. Wang, 58, would have no effect on the two probes.
Mr. Wang's departure, announced as a retirement although he is not receiving a pension, stirred conjecture that the company was seeking to distance itself from him. Michael Faltischek, the managing partner in Ruskin Moscou Faltischek in Uniondale and the chairman of the law firm's corporate governance practice group, said that the circumstances surrounding his exit suggested that Computer Associates was taking "remedial steps."
"If management has been abusive, you have to change the people running the company in order to change perception," he said. "If remedial steps are taken, probably government officials will not seek full sanctions. Pre-empting their actions will not only soften the regulatory blow but serve the secondary purpose of rebuilding corporate integrity."
There was little in the early years of Computer Associates to suggest it would grow into one of the biggest and, for a while, one of the most profitable enterprises in the United States. The company was founded by Mr. Wang and several partners in 1976, and they took the company public in 1981. During the 1980's and most of the 1990's, as the information technology sector ballooned, so did the company's revenues and profits. 
The company's rapid growth -- sales this year are expected to reach $3 billion -- came as Computer Associates solidified its position in the mainframe computer business, producing the software that operates and connects large computers, while expanding into storage technology, wireless products and high-tech security systems. 
Like many of the company's employees, Mr. Kumar joined the business as a result of a merger. A Sri Lanka native from a Tamil family, Mr. Kumar and his relatives fled the ethnic violence in their homeland and in 1976 moved to Greenville, S.C., where his mother had been hired to teach in a private school. He joined Computer Associates in 1987 when it absorbed the Uccel Corporation, a small Texas software company where he worked as a product manager.
Within Computer Associates' rough-and-tumble corporate culture, Mr. Kumar's lack of a college degree did not hold him back. Rather, his life story struck a chord with Mr. Wang, who had followed a similar path, immigrating as a boy with his family from Shanghai to Queens, where he learned computer skills at Queens College. Mr. Wang made Mr. Kumar his assistant, relocating him and his wife, Sylvia, to Long Island. They eventually bought a house next door to Mr. Wang in Oyster Bay. A rapid series of promotions followed, to president in 1994 to and chief executive in 2000.
Mr. Kumar has already begun to put his mark on Computer Associates. In the last three years it has invested $2 billion in research and development, nearly twice the amount spent in the prior three years, said Yogesh Gupta, the chief technology officer. 
Earlier this year, Mr. Kumar instituted a new compensation plan that ties managers' pay to customer satisfaction, Mr. Gupta said. "We have been measuring customer satisfaction for four years running," he said. "But this year, for the first time, hundreds of managers will have their pay determined by how customers rate their satisfaction."
On Oct. 31, Mr. Kumar announced the appointment of Robert B. Lamm, a former director of the American Society of Corporate Secretaries, as the company's corporate secretary and director of corporate governance, a new position. The appointment came only weeks after Mr. Kumar said that the company would adhere to what he called a "gold standard" in corporate governance.
"The organizational vision is there," Ms. Burton, the Gartner analyst, said of Mr. Kumar. "But I don't know that he has gotten the right team in place yet to do that. Sanjay is in many respects raised by Charles Wang. I think he is going to take a broader view than Charles did, but I don't think it has trickled down through the company. At least not yet."

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES; 
Balancing A Budget On an Ax

BYLINE:  By DIANA MARSZALEK

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE 

 BODY:
FACED with years of financial woes, bound by a long-disputed property tax cap and a strained relationship with its state representative, the city of New Rochelle would have to lay off 16 firefighters and leave 18 vacancies on the police force unfilled under its proposed 2003 budget.
 While many municipalities -- and the county itself -- are struggling with budget shortfalls, New Rochelle is feeling a particularly acute pinch this year. 
 The proposed budget cuts -- which would likely lead to the elimination of an entire firehouse -- would significantly reduce the police and fire services New Rochelle residents currently receive, city officials said. The fire department roster would drop to 142 firefighters from 158 -- down from 180 in 1991. With the current unfilled vacancies, the police department has 164 officers. 
"As far as the fire department goes, you might as well put a nail in the door if we lose these guys," said Fire Commissioner Raymond F. Kiernan. "It will just not be the same organization."
Mr. Kiernan said that not only would the Drake Avenue firehouse, which has served the city's south side since the 1880's, likely be a casualty, but the fire department also may have to stop answering emergency medical calls and refer them to a private ambulance company. Approximately half the 8,000 calls the department receives each year are for medical emergencies, he said.
"We would have to fold up and go back into the fire business only," Mr. Kiernan said. "We would have a fire department as small as it was in the Great Depression."
Local leaders say they have no choice but to slash the city's police and fire departments -- two departments they have long tried to preserve -- if they are going to have the required balanced budget.
In the $110 million budget proposal, leaving 18 police officer positions unfilled would save $946,000 and laying off 16 firefighters would save $960,000. The budget proposes reducing garbage collection to once a week, eliminating street sweeping and reducing financing to the library and programs for the elderly to save a total of $4.4 million. 
Though Assemblyman Ronald C. Tocci, who represents New Rochelle in the State Legislature, said it is the city's duty to preserve its police and fire services, city officials said they have done so for so long by reducing other departments that they have no choice. Unless Albany releases the city from a tax cap that leaves it with few options for raising money, there is virtually no relief in sight, they said. 
"The bottom line is we don't have any money and all we do is cut, cut, cut," said City Manager Charles B. Strome. "The policemen are protesting about their manpower and I don't disagree."
Not cutting the budgets of core departments -- police and fire, public works, recreation and library -- is certainly a priority but now only a fantasy, Mr. Strome said. 
While other municipalities are also facing budget shortfalls, New Rochelle's woes are hitting harder because the city cannot increase its property tax rate to meet its needs the way other cities can.
Under a nearly decade-old agreement with the state, New Rochelle cannot raise its property tax rate more than 1.7 percent each year without forfeiting its sales tax rate, which is 1.5 percent higher than the 6.75 percent countywide base. Rye, for example, is considering a 29 percent property tax increase and Westchester County is considering a 28.6 percent increase. Currently, New Rochelle's sales tax revenues are $9 million higher than they would be without the additional 1.5 percent, according to Mr. Strome. 
In addition, local leaders say Albany, which gives New Rochelle a disproportionately low amount of supplemental and per capita state aid -- the only two kinds of state money that can be used for operating expenses -- is slighting them. New Rochelle, which has 72,000 residents, receives $465,000 a year in supplemental aid. Yonkers, with 195,000 people, receives $46.9 million. White Plains, which has 50,000 residents, receives $1 million, according to Mr. Strome. 
"No other municipality in New York has the fiscal constraints we have," said Mayor Timothy C. Idoni. "And we are the seventh largest city in the state."
The complexities with the state have led to a strained relationship between New Rochelle officials and Mr. Tocci. That was particularly evident in the recent Democratic primary, in which New Rochelle City Councilman Noam Bramson defeated Mr. Tocci, the incumbent. Mr. Tocci, who then ran as a Republican, defeated Mr. Bramson in the November election.
M AYOR IDONI, who struck the original tax cap agreement with Mr. Tocci when the city was luring Costco and Home Depot to town, said that he agreed to just a two-year tax cap and that the cap made sense when sales tax revenues grew with the strong economy.
Mr. Idoni said, however, Mr. Tocci's refusal to support dropping the property tax cap despite repeated requests from the city over the past six years essentially means Mr. Tocci reneged on the original deal and New Rochelle is suffering as a result.
"We've been begging for state aid for two years to keep this from happening," Mr. Idoni said. "This is the result of either political indifference or our state legislator's inability to get it done."
Mr. Tocci, on the other hand, said that the city is reeling from years of financial mismanagement and that city officials should preserve its police and fire departments without further burdening taxpayers.
"In a budget of $110 million the first question should be how much the city needs for police and fire departments," Mr. Tocci said.
He said he continually strives to promote New Rochelle's needs in the State Legislature, noting a $500,000 emergency grant last August that enabled the city to postpone the fire department layoffs until February.
New Rochelle taxpayers have twice rejected a library tax that would have freed up money in the city's operating budget.
City leaders say the toll of sparing the police and fire departments would be small for the average New Rochelle homeowner. The 10 percent increase it would require would mean adding $200 a year on the average property tax bill, Mr. Strome said.
Meantime, however, that is not an option, as city councilmen are pressed to adopt the 2003 budget by the end of this year.
And unless circumstances change, this won't be the last bleak budget for New Rochelle.
"We can make the cuts this year," Mr. Strome said. "And next year we're going to have to do it all over again."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Drake Avenue firehouse, which has served New Rochelle's south side since the 1880's, is likely to close as a result of the city's proposed 2003 budget cuts. (George M. Gutierrez for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST SIDE; 
Bold Design for Ferry Terminals, Or Landings on the Half Shell?

BYLINE:  By ERIKA KINETZ 

 BODY:
In public art, should the emphasis be on "public" or "art"? The East River ferry has become a new stage for this old debate. 
 While most East Siders are excited by the commuter ferry service that should be in place on the East River by the end of next year, some say the bold modern design of the ferry landings lacks local flavor. 
 "They've got a shell for the shelter that swoops up and comes back down," said M. Barry Schneider, president of the East 60's Neighborhood Association. "It's almost bulbous in nature. Some of us thought it was just design for design's sake. It didn't lend a lot of good feeling." 
The landings, which will be situated at East 90th, 75th, 62nd and 34th Streets, as well as at the Battery Maritime building in Lower Manhattan, were designed by Sheila Kennedy and Frano Violich. The $20 million project awaits final approval from the city's Art Commission.
Slim wind turbines will help power the lights at the terminals. Global positioning systems will be used to give passengers information about the progress of ferries. Concrete and plexiglass bollards powered by solar cells will glow blue when deprived of light, at night or when someone sits on them.
In January, the project earned the prestigious Progressive Architecture award, and it has garnered recognition elsewhere. But to some, such award-winning boldness smacks of hubris. 
"They remind me of the T.W.A. building at Kennedy, which looks kind of like a clam," said Terry Grace, who lives in the East 70's. "I would have liked to see something much more modest."
The architects disagree. "The aluminum picks up reflections from the water," said Luis Boza, project manager at Kennedy & Violich. "The stone ticket booth is made of masonry blocks that pick up the language of the bulkhead that runs along the river. It's not a completely foreign modern object."
Paul Januszewski, project manager at the city's Economic Development Corporation, which is overseeing the ferry plan, said: "We wanted the design to be something different that you weren't used to seeing, and when you saw it you would know it is a ferry landing. We feel it is a cutting-edge design. We don't expect everyone to be happy with it."
Paul Byard, an architect and the director of the historic preservation program at Columbia University, added: "Architecture is an instrument of leadership. If we do not let it lead, we are impoverishing ourselves." ERIKA KINETZ

GRAPHIC: Photo: The ferry terminals, shown in rendering, are a $20 million project. (Economic Development Corporation)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: URBAN STUDIES/IDLING; 
Whistling Past the Unemployment Office

BYLINE:  By ALAN FEUER 

 BODY:
THE face of unemployment need not be a fretful mask of clenched teeth and quivering lips. With a few bucks in the piggy bank and a willingness to the see the world as one's personal oyster, joblessness can be amusing, even fun.
 Dave Rippon has been out of work for nearly two months, which is long enough to be concerned, if not terrified. He had a good job with the United States Department of Education in Washington until the Republican armada came to town. 
 A recent morning found him sprawled on the couch of his Manhattan Valley apartment, dissecting the finer points of the "Today" show. Jerry Nadler was talking about his stomach surgery. Bob Dole was judging a karaoke contest. "It's very soothing," Mr. Rippon said.
On the upside, unemployment means having the time to write his memoirs (President Truman once used his grandfather's bathroom) and the chance to take his mother-in-law shopping at Harry's Shoes on the Upper West Side. On the downside, it means worrying about the future, and having a father-in-law who has started wondering if he hasn't lost a daughter so much as gained a bum.
Then there's the money issue. "It's sort of like dying," Mr. Rippon said of when his pockets will finally be empty. "You know it's going to happen, but you can't spend a lot of time thinking about it."
So every day at 9:30 a.m., he gets on the Internet to search for a job. The pickings are slim. A database manager for the League of the Hard of Hearing. An in-store marketing associate at Sears.
The city isn't hiring. The nonprofit world got killed in the stock market. And as for severance pay, Mr. Rippon got two weeks of health insurance and a couple of government pens. He has an impressive employment history stretching back to his college days: horse-manure shoveler, ski salesman, asbestos remover and short-order cook. After grad school, he worked for the Giuliani administration.
Still, after 30 interviews, he hasn't gotten so much as a nibble. But the day was crisp and sunny. Perfect for an adventure. 
The newspaper on the coffee table suggested a plan: the new Eminem movie was playing nearby at 11:45 a.m. On the way, he stopped at Starbucks and made a startling discovery. Of the four people sitting by the window, three were unemployed. "I'm finding it harder and harder to talk to people who have jobs," one of them said wearily. It was depressing. Mr. Rippon left. 
At the box office, he was first in line, and the theater was so empty he could have played football in the aisles. After the movie, he tried going skating in Central Park but the rink was closed. F. A. O. Schwarz, however, was near.
So he strolled through the palace of make-believe, distracting himself with stuffed animals and roller skates. He inquired of a Magic 8-Ball: "Will this story humiliate me?"
Its answer: "My sources say no." ALAN FEUER

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dave Rippon has been out of work for nearly two months. His daily routine includes the Today show. (Justin Lane for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
An Endangered Family-Run Garage

BYLINE:  By NANCY HAGGERTY

 BODY:
TOMPKINS GARAGE, a family-run business in Yorktown that has survived for more than a century, now faces two major threats to its future -- a $1.5 million suit from a neighbor and bills from the state that could top $1 million.
 The garage, originally built to fix wagons, tractors and then Model T's, is suddenly the focus of attention by guardians of the watershed around New York City's reservoirs as well as the state Department of Environmental Conservation. 
 The station's owner, Jimmy Tompkins, 43, said, "I don't have the slightest thought of giving up." But the amounts of money at stake are daunting for a business that he said netted about $60,000 a year. 
The state Department of Environmental Conservation says the Route 129 garage, founded by the Tompkins family in 1890, is the source of a suspected carcinogenic chemical found in groundwater on New York City property abutting the New Croton Reservoir and at a nearby residential property. The chemical, the gasoline additive methyl tertiary butyl ether, commonly referred to as MTBE, is believed to have migrated from the station twice, first following a slow and initially undetected leak in a gas pump line in the late 1990's and then after the spill of an estimated 250 gallons of gas in 2000.
While the reservoir remains clean, MTBE has been found in 13 of 20 test wells, one registering more than 600 times the level judged safe for consumption.
Neither spill is attributed to action by the garage but, as the owner of the gas tanks, it is legally responsible. Mr. Tompkins, who reported both spills, said the first was the fault of a repair company hired to fix a pump and the second was caused by a delivery company whose driver was found guilty in Yorktown Court and fined $1,000 for spilling the gas. Both companies paid for the initial state-supervised cleanup of the pump area.
Mr. Tompkins's lawyer, Larry Wolinsky, said he would sue the two companies responsible for the spills to recoup money related to state-ordered well drilling, testing and cleanup. He estimated final costs around $1 million. That does not include damages relating to a suit filed by Lorraine and Carmine Colarossi, who own a house whose well was first found to be contaminated in 1998. The Colarossis are also suing the trucking company, Mystic Bulk Carriers, for $1.5 million.
The amount of MTBE in their well has now dropped to a level that the water is judged safe to drink, but it remains contaminated with septic waste and salt unconnected to the garage, said Jennifer Post, a conservation department spokeswoman.
Michael B. Kaplowitz, a Westchester County legislator, said Mr. Tompkins's problems were "difficult, problematic but not ultimately a death knell." He argued that state and city environmental officials had failed as watchdogs. Saying a full cleanup should have occurred long ago, he said the delays were a result of either "institutional laziness or callousness" stemming from the "high frequency of such spills."
Ms. Post defended the conservation department, saying, "To have an effective plan we need to know the nature and extent of contamination."
If the conservation department drills wells to intercept contamination, which it is considering, work to pump out, treat and pump water back into the ground could begin within a few months, she said.
Meanwhile, Mr. Tompkins, who lives with his wife, Kathryn, and their two children in the family home next to the garage, said: "We're a little place caught in the middle. We don't know what to do. The D.E.C. acts like this is the Exxon Valdez. It's eating us alive. I'm not against a cleanup. But why try to put me out of business?"
In addition to the bills, Mr. Tompkins, who has owned the garage since 1988, is upset with the city's decision to end his use of a .08-acre parking lot next spring. It is on watershed land across from his station. With the exception of a six-year period when Mr. Tompkins balked at paying rising rent, the garage has leased it since 1931.
Charles Sturchen, a spokesman for the city Department of the Environmental Protection, said his agency was generally trying to eliminate commercial use of watershed land.
"We try to live the best we can with our neighbors in the watershed but some uses don't fit with our mission," he said.
Supervisor Linda G. Cooper of Yorktown, who is a former head of the Yorktown Conservation Board, termed the garage an anomaly because of its proximity to the reservoir.
"It's part of that which defines the Huntersville area and makes it unique until itself," she said. "We're trying to ensure the water quality is not compromised. We want to make sure the remnants of the spill are cleaned up, and we want to protect a longstanding business. I think we all want to preserve the livelihood of someone who does a good job."
Coincidentally, Tompkins Garage was developed as a direct result of the construction of the reservoir. The family, which settled in Yorktown in the 1700's, was forced to give up its farm as part of that project.
After relocating to the current site, Mr. Tompkins's grandfather, Gilbert, the father of 12, began repairing, trading and selling wagons and tractors, and selling apples.
Eventually, Gilbert Tompkins's son, Art Tompkins, took over. For a while tractors were the focal point, but Art Tompkins also started fixing Model T's and other cars, a business that took off.
"The next thing you know they were coming from all directions," recalled his brother, Chester Tompkins, 92. A local blacksmith sometimes fashioned vehicle parts.
The garage was a gathering spot. Neighbors brought over homemade applejack whiskey, and animal pelts were regularly bought and sold there.
The original wooden one-car garage was lost at the start of the 1930's when the road was modernized.
Despite the Depression, Art Tompkins's brother, Henry Tompkins, decided to rebuild and upgrade the site, making the business a full-service station, selling gasoline and repairing cars and trucks in a larger building that Chester designed and helped build.
That brick building, with an addition Jimmy Tompkins built, is today's garage.
Mr. Wilson said the Tompkins family succeeded through good economic times and bad simply because it had a "good name and good mechanics."
Despite the troubles, he appears optimistic, envisioning his son, James, 10, eventually in charge.
James said he wanted to take over after going to college.
"I'd like to run it for as long as I can -- to go a real long time," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Tompkins Garage, above, and as it was in the 1930's, with its owner, Henry Tompkins, left. Jimmy Tompkins, the current owner, faces threats to his livelihood because of environmental concerns. (Above and bottom, photographs by Chris Ramirez for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey Offices; 
Making Buildings Better When the Economy Is Bad

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN 

 BODY:
WHEN the economy goes downhill, it is time to upgrade.
 At least, that is the tack a number of commercial landlords in New Jersey are taking as they make significant renovations and improvements during the current difficult economic times, said Steven M. Frank, a senior vice president at CB Richard Ellis. "Despite high vacancy rates -- or because of them, in some cases -- some owners are investing in modernizing their buildings or in repositioning them as higher-quality properties," Mr. Frank said. 
 The Mack-Cali Corporation, for example, completed a multimillion dollar renovation of an office building adjacent to the Willowbrook Mall in Wayne earlier this year, installing a new glass entry, granite and limestone lobby and outdoor plaza, and refinishing several tenant common areas. 
Several other office complexes where renovation projects are nearing completion include the M. Alfieri Company's total exterior renovation of its four-building corporate park in Bloomfield (previously the headquarters of the pharmaceutical company Hoffman-LaRoche); the Jack Parker Corporation's upgrade of the Parker Plaza it has owned for 20 years in Fort Lee; and W. P. Commercial's redesign of the Atrium Corporate Park in Somerset.
"It is not an easy decision for many landlords to make to invest in this environment," Mr. Frank noted, "but as we look across all industries, in particular technology and biotechnology, the leaders that will come out of this recession are those who are investing in their product. It is no different in commercial real estate."
With many economists saying that business cycles appear to be shortening, investing before an upturn becomes paramount, Mr. Frank added. Of course, only property owners who have a certain amount of equity in their buildings and whose cash flow is adequate can afford to invest in capital improvements in times like these, he said.
"In the case of the Jack Parker Corporation," said Mr. Frank, who has represented Jack Parker for more than a decade, "with its resources, it has been able to reinvest and further separate its property from the pack. That allows them to keep the existing tenant base happy and confident, and it enables them to attract tenants when other buildings may be perceived as suffering."
Toys "R" Us Inc. occupies the top two floors of Parker Plaza and is looking to sublease 50,000 to 75,000 feet as it consolidates its offices in Wayne, Mr. Frank said. But the building is currently 97 percent leased and has just attracted a new tenant, SK Global, the trading arm of a major South Korean conglomerate, which will relocate from Manhattan next year. SK Global signed a long-term lease for 40,000 square feet, with the understanding that Jack Parker was planning major improvements to the building beginning in the first quarter of 2003.
These include complete renovation of the building's grand atrium, new lighting, furniture, a cafe and an outdoor garden on the sixth floor deck. 
JEAN-PIERRE VAGANAY, chief operating officer for Jack Parker, said, "When a building is more than 90 percent occupied, most owners put things on cruise control." He added, "We believe that the wisest time to spend your money is when things are not going too well."
Mr. Vaganay said there are fewer prospective tenants in the marketplace, and his company wants to make sure its building is in a condition to attract them.
Mr. Vaganay said the cooling system in Parker Plaza was recently replaced, and a third chiller was added to make the system more efficient. "It was not something that had to be done," he said, "but the summer months have become warmer and warmer, and we wanted to increase our cooling capacity so our tenants are comfortable and satisfied."
The roof was also replaced on the building as part of scheduled maintenance, Mr. Vaganay said.
At the Central Park Corporate Campus near the Bloomfield border with Montclair, a whole new look was designed for the generic-looking former pharmaceutical headquarters when it was vacated two years ago.
"We had to decide at the time," said Michael Alfieri, the president of the M. Alfieri Company, "whether to freshen up or to reposition. I would say generally we take a long-term view on real estate. It's mostly about the asset coming first and staying ahead of the curve on keeping the asset contemporary and Class A."
At the Bloomfield campus, Mr. Alfieri said, the issue was this: "We believe in the location, but the buildings are rather cold, and sterile. "So, we took a broader look at it, and asked ourselves. 'If we want to create quality of life in this place, how can we make it a friendly environment?' "
Architects were hired to redesign the campus, rather than simply update it, and last year its appearance was transformed with $10 million in renovations. An energy-efficient green glass curtain wall was installed on the exterior of the building that fronts on Broad Street. The public spaces and lobbies of the buildings behind it were rebuilt with modern, higher-quality materials and the windows all replaced. 
"The last part of the plan," Mr. Alfieri said, "was to completely renovate the landscaping and consolidate the green space for a parklike setting, add a conference room and a cafe, which, all totaled, cost roughly another $10 million. Maybe other landlords wouldn't have kept going with that, given this market, but we had a vision for what the property could be."
Final touches were put on the landscaping, conference room and cafe in November. 
"I think we had to do it all," Mr. Alfieri said. "When we were happy with the environment we created, then it started to sell."
Among the tenants that Central Park Corporate Campus has attracted this year, he said, are Apogee Networks, Country Wide Home Loans, Del Monte, NJ Sports Production, Procter & Gamble and World Audio Visual Enterprises. The total 400,000 square feet at the campus is currently about 75 percent leased, and negotiations are under way that would bring it to 90 percent.
Mr. Alfieri asserted that "Apogee Networks, which is a software company, left a park on Route 80 in Saddle Brook and told us they were taking 25,000 square feet with us because of the park environment." 
Mr. Alfieri said his company was also investing in renovations to its office building at the Metropark train station in Edison. A mezzanine was removed from the 5-story atrium entrance of the 15-story building, to bring in more natural light, "friendliness and warmth." The landscaping was also upgraded, and the elevator system is being computerized. "We wanted to bring the building up with the current competition," he said. 
WP Commercial recently did similar renovation work at its Atrium Corporate Park -- renovating the lobby, elevator cabs and common corridors and installing new walkways and landscaping outside, with future plans to construct a cafe.
"The five-story atrium is a dramatic piece of architecture," said Mark Schaevitz, WP's chief operating officer. "It was built in the 80's, however, and had that cold, imposing kind of look. We think people were turned off."
Also, Merrill Lynch, once the major tenant in the building, has been moving out over the course of several years, although it still occupies part of the space, Mr. Schaevitz said. "This presented us with a leasing challenge in tough times."
Given the current highly competitive situation for landlords, he said: "We felt it was time to redevelop and reposition the image of the building. We took a redesign approach, both with the atrium and with the exterior of the building."
"The old floor was green concrete," he said, "with surrounding tile. It is now black granite, with rich plush carpet. The outside of the building was dark green glass and it had red stripes -- not the aesthetic of today. Now it is a mute black."
Mr. Schaevitz said his company had searched carefully for an architect who would completely redo the building's appearance without "trying to win design awards" and ultimately chose a Manhattan firm, MPFP. 
Mr. Schaevitz agreed with a statement by Mr. Frank of CB Richard Ellis, who said, "In down times, you have to do prudent renovations, spending what cash flow permits." 
Mr. Schaevitz added: "But you can't wait, if you can afford it. When things become more competitive, marketability is as much dependent on image as it is on availability."
Showing a prospective tenant actual improvements, he said, is vastly more effective than showing plans for renovations to be done contingent on the signing of a lease. "After all," Mr. Schaevitz said, "you only get to make a first impression once."
