PERSON: Katherine Oliver 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
Selling the Celluloid City, With Style

BYLINE:  By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
WHEN the out-of-the-blue phone call came to Katherine Oliver in London last March, she was supervising 600 people in 25 cities with a budget in the hundreds of millions. Her title? Managing director of global broadcasting operations for Bloomberg L.P.
 Daniel L. Doctoroff, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's deputy for economic development, was on the line. He made her an offer she could easily have refused: become commissioner of the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting, with its quaint $1 million budget, a staff of 17, and a salary line -- $140,000 -- that was a paltry fraction of her London take-home. 
 "It was a surprise," Ms. Oliver recalled, and although it took some rumination, she said yes. But why? "Two things: Mike Bloomberg. New York City." She laughed. "People thought I was absolutely nuts." 
The office faces dire challenges, as New York City's film workers listen anxiously for the giant sucking sound of jobs departing for Canada. Right now, there is the outrage of "Rudy!" the unauthorized biography of Rudolph W. Giuliani for -- yes -- the USA Network, being shot in -- yes -- Montreal.
The office was founded in 1966 to cut through city red tape for filmmakers and to end the extortionate demands that were eating producers alive and driving them from the city.
The office zapped the graft and became an institution, but Ms. Oliver did not quite comprehend what she was getting into. Dropped like an astronaut from the tech-forward Bloomberg universe (pager, mobile, BlackBerry), she touched down in a time warp.
The antique computers at the office were little used, the Paleozoic telephone system discouraged connection with humans, electric typewriters were employed for office communications, and permit seekers were required to visit the office to fill out forms in quintuplicate.
Worse, Ms. Oliver, a former diva of cable television, arrived in a city office that was not equipped with cable. 
Since Ms. Oliver arrived Aug. 1, she has been closing in on the 21st century. "I'm the new kid on the block," she said, "and I can ask for things." Already there is a new phone system, and 12 personal computers for the staff. The old hand-written master calendar has been obsolesced by Excel spreadsheet grids. And within 30 days of Ms. Oliver's arrival, producers were able to seek permits online. 
The cable, she's still working on. "My mission," she said, "is to promote New York City on a global basis as a location and a viable place to work. This can help -- because movies are big advertisements for New York City."
For now, industry veterans are thumbs up. "She's got a lot of fresh ideas, and she has really reached out to people," said Jane Rosenthal, a producer of "Analyze That," shot in New York City last spring. "And she has the ear of the mayor."
It is that mayor who has defined her mission and who has given her some very public support. "Kathy has the drive and creativity to take this industry in our city to another level," Mayor Bloomberg announced the other night to 400 film, theater and television industry professionals at a reception. 
Ms. Oliver presided over the event in an electric Navy blue pinstripe suit by Ozwald Boateng, the Savile Row-trained tailor, accessorized with a peacock blue Thai silk blouse and Manolo Blahniks. During her English odyssey, The Times of London tsk-tsked at Ms. Oliver's "outre, theatrical dress."
Sitting in her office, Ms. Oliver shrugged. "In the media business," she said, "the things you wear can be a little funky." 
Funky, perhaps, for a 39-year-old from St. Anselm's parish in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. Her nickname is "K.O." (right, the initials) and knocking herself out is the M.O.
After stints as a radio news writer and reporter, she became an on-air reporter for the cable networks FNN and CNBC. She first encountered Mr. Bloomberg 11 years ago when he hired her as an announcer, making her one of the team of 11 that created Bloomberg Radio in 1992. Soon she anchored, and produced, Mr. Bloomberg's first 15-minute television show, then helped start his cable channel in 1994. 
In 1996, Mr. Bloomberg made her his ambassador to London to start up the company's European, Asian and South American services. Ms. Oliver knows pretty much everything there is to know about being a woman manager in Latin countries. "They would want to talk to the man of the office, and then Mike would tell them simply that I was the man of the office," she recalled. 
"Work has been a big part of my life," she said, adding that she is not too busy to be dating.
MS. OLIVER can't bring back "Rudy!," but she has her eye not only on Canada but also on "Australia, New Zealand and South Africa," she said, "where they speak English and are making attractive offers." 
How can the city stay competitive? "In the end, New York is its own greatest asset," she said, "the skyline, the diversity of the neighborhoods, and the sheer energy of the people. You can't measure these things. But they're translated into film."

HEADLINE: A Perfectionist Does It His Way 

BYLINE:  By ALEX WITCHEL 

 BODY:
"HI, I'm putting my belt on!"
 It was 11 a.m. when I arrived at Jeffrey Steingarten's loft in the Flatiron district to find that he was not dressed and that his bed was not made. I noticed this because his bed is only a few feet from the kitchen that takes up most of the place. 
 As he slammed the Murphy bed up into the wall and started blasting opera, his assistant, Elizabeth Alsop, offered me a seat at the kitchen table where someone -- who could it be? -- had left a copy of a favorable USA Today review of his new book, "It Must Have Been Something I Ate: The Return of the Man Who Ate Everything" (Alfred A. Knopf). It is a volume of his collected food essays from Vogue, where he has written since 1989. His first collection, "The Man Who Ate Everything," was a New York Times best seller in its paperback edition, and last spring, he won a National Magazine Award for some of the essays in the new book. Mr. Steingarten can write, he just can't tell time. 
He emerged wearing a navy blazer, gray flannels and loafers, dressed as the lawyer he was before Vogue -- Harvard College 1965 (where he wrote for the Lampoon) and Harvard Law School 1968. The kitchen was crammed with piles of every sort, from flour bins to rotisseries one on top of the next, and to get to the counter he inched around what looked like a pirate's stash: dusty bottles of port, rum and whiskey lined 12 deep along the walls. He had spent the week practicing his form on the dish that was to be our lunch, agnolotti al plin, a miniature filled pasta that's pinched around the edges. He had recently been in Turin, Italy, for a Slow Food convention, where he spent hours with Luigi Caputo of the restaurant Balbo, learning how to pinch like a pro.
Perfecting recipes and cooking techniques in the most obsessive ways possible is pretty much Mr. Steingarten's job description. He goes somewhere in the world, watches someone do something, then comes home and tries it 50 different ways himself. 
He augments his findings with some of the most exhaustive research available outside of NASA, then writes up the tale, whether it is how he arranged a delivery of rendered horse fat from Vienna so he could make the perfect French fry, or how he chased down a wild bluefin tuna in the middle of winter for the thrill of the hunt and the prize of eating premium toro on the spot. Of that adventure he wrote: "What arbitrary and destructive force was pulling me ineluctably toward my star-crossed encounter with this monstrous ruler of the frozen deep? I believe it was the editor in chief of Vogue."
At this particular moment, giving the completely false impression that he intended to make up for lost time and get to work, Mr. Steingarten started rolling pasta, and his elegant navy blazer was soon lashed with flour. Why on earth was he dressed that way to cook? "I find it's more slimming," he said, squeezing dots of filling in a straight line along the edge of the pasta sheet. "Men have it much worse than females. Throughout history there have been great paintings and sculptures of chubby women. But have you ever seen a statue of a fat man? Absolutely not."
He rolled the pasta forward, pinched it and ran a pastry wheel next to the line of little lumps, making what looked like a long ruffle. "Here's the secret, O.K.?" he said. "It's important to force the air out when you pinch it. You don't want them falling apart or getting bloated in the water." He said something else I couldn't hear with the music still blasting. "You're going to have to turn that off," I said, which elicited a frown from the author. "I can turn it off," Ms. Alsop offered, which prompted Mr. Steingarten to thunder, "No! No one touches my hi-fi."
In the ensuing silence, Mr. Steingarten determined he was in need of a drink. So, at 11:30 he opened a $400 bottle of '89 Louis Latour Montrachet, and explained that once the agnolotti were cooked and dressed with herb-infused butter and a sprinkling of Parmesan, he would subject them to three variations before serving: one dish would be adorned with shaved white truffles, another with truffle oil, another with truffle flour.
As he spoke the phone rang and a plaintive voice from Vogue inquired on the machine about Mr. Steingarten's expense report, a call Ms. Alsop ran to take. He shrugged. "I had euros and pounds on one form; it really flummoxed them," he said, clearly distracted by his wineglass. "I'm afraid it's corked," he said sadly. "Montrachet is so good and this is so not good." He sighed deeply. "It just shows, Gather ye rosebuds."
Good advice. One hour down, we might at least attempt an interview. I could ask questions. He could even answer them instead of tracking an e-Bay bid for still another rotisserie. He reluctantly sat at the table, where he tried opening a bottle of red this time, an '82 St. Julien, Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou. The cork would not budge and he took a sharp knife to it, easing it out of the bottle. Since I wasn't drinking, he kindly gave me an excellent piece of candied orange peel from Fauchon and fresh dates that were quite sublime. I asked about his family.
"Let me get a cigar," he said, up again. "My grandfather was a grocer on the Lower East Side; not a very successful grocer. He got in trouble at one point for watering milk. We never talked about it." Mr. Steingarten's father was a lawyer, and he and his wife raised their son and daughter, Lois, in Hewlett Neck, N.Y. Mr. Steingarten married Caron Smith in 1977, and in 1998 she took a job at the San Diego Museum of Art, where she is senior curator of Asian art, so their marriage is now bicoastal. When I asked how that was working out, he proclaimed, "When I'm not there, Caron eats horribly."
So much for family history. "Can't we talk about food?" Mr. Steingarten asked dolefully. During law school (his roommate was Dr. Andrew Weil, the holistic health guru) he would come home from property class, watch Julia Child on WGBH and write her recipes on his yellow legal pads. Then he would cook. But not like other people. This is a man who in the last 10 years alone has made at least one potato gratin a week, every week of every year, drawing on a collection of 200 recipes. He dry-aged a 30-pound cross-section of beef in his refrigerator, then butchered and cooked it himself -- except for the parts that had rotted.
His first assignment for Anna Wintour, whom he had met through friends, was in 1988 when she was editing HG, an incarnation of House & Garden. Mr. Steingarten was to write 500 to 800 words on whether fish could really be cooked in a microwave oven. After sampling 12 microwave ovens, he turned in a piece 4,200 words long -- and she printed it. When Ms. Wintour went to Vogue the following year, he went with her.
BUT what about the 20 years between law school and food writing? He worked for Kevin White, the mayor of Boston, doing research on poverty law and legal services for the poor. He moved to New York in 1971 and continued that work, receiving several foundation grants to research the legal rights of the mentally ill. He wrote the occasional piece for Harper's and Atlantic Monthly on politics or economics, but it was not until Ms. Wintour that he found his muse. That she happens to be the body double for Olive Oyl is the height of improbability, but it's his good fortune that she apparently likes reading about food more than she likes eating it. Mr. Steingarten has been known to say that when his weight is up, Ms. Wintour is less inclined to take his calls.
He smiled. "There's no doubt she wants me to go on the Atkins diet," he said. "I've actually spent a third of the time on it during the last 30 years, and a third on high carbs. Look, if there was a diet that worked, no one would be fat."
Ms. Wintour, speaking briskly by phone, said: "I have great respect for Jeffrey. He is obsessive and a perfectionist and that's what makes him so special. He's so completely thorough in his research, he comes at it from such an original angle." A hint of a smile entered her voice. "We did get into a lot of trouble with that horse fat piece; we had an avalanche of letters about that one. But I can tell you, no one in the food world buys Vogue for the fashion, they buy it for Jeffrey."
One of Mr. Steingarten's pet themes is an utter lack of patience with people who are convinced they have food allergies. Lactose intolerance in particular irritates him, as does the government's squeamishness about allowing the import of unpasteurized cheeses. He says he gets food poisoning only once every two years or so, something of a record for someone who travels the world eating things like deep-fried bamboo worms, roasted wasp larvae and mashed pig's brains.
And speaking of food, such as it is, are we ever going to eat? 
Ms. Alsop presented two sides of smoked salmon from a tour of Brooklyn smokehouses Mr. Steingarten had just taken with Mark Russ Federman, the owner of the esteemed appetizing store, Russ & Daughters. Ms. Alsop placed two cookie sheets in front of him, one covered with wild salmon, the other with farmed salmon. He sliced some of each and quickly determined that the wild one was spectacular, the farmed less so. But one taste was not enough. He sat, fork in hand, and kept on eating.
I looked at my watch. Three hours and 15 minutes and the cooking had yet to begin. It seemed perfectly clear that there was to be no interview. We might at least have a meal.
Mr. Steingarten gathered himself slowly, turned toward the stove and tripped over some bottles. "That's what happens when you're being rushed," he said, in an injured tone.
Rushed? Was he joking?
"I looked forward to today not just because of the article, but because you and I would be playing," he said quietly, looking as if someone had just pushed him into his locker. 
Oh. I looked at his face, at the jumble surrounding him -- cans and cans of boudin noir, Illy coffee, two bottles of Chambord side by side (whatever for?) and I put down my pad. I picked up a perfect piece of Parmesan from DiPalo's and let go. "You know Jeffrey, you're right," I said. "Let's do it your way."
He smiled like the sun and once the specter of pesky questions disappeared, he couldn't have been happier, or speedier, even though he made Ms. Alsop measure the servings of the agnolotti -- three ounces, to approximate those served at Balbo.
To say the pasta was quite firm was a polite way of saying it was undercooked. The white truffles, which he shaved with abandon, disappointed him. "They have a very good aroma, but I think their taste is weak," he said. The version with truffle oil was ghastly, but the version with truffle flour was tasty, indeed.
Then he made espresso and opened boxes labeled Domori. Speaking of the master pastry chef, he said, "Pierre Herme says it's perhaps the best chocolate he's ever had." We tasted it dark and light, along with Gianduja, a Piedmontese hazelnut chocolate. "Rich, soft, slightly milky," Mr. Steingarten said, rolling it, and the words, around in his mouth.
Again, I looked at my watch. Four and a half hours later, it was getting close to dinnertime. "Thank you for letting me come and play," I said, and we laughed together, no hard feelings.
"But one more thing," I said, turning back toward the table. "I feel bad about the chocolate because I tasted it in little bites." I had broken up at least a half-dozen pieces, which now littered the table on their bits of foil.
"That doesn't matter," Mr. Steingarten said comfortably, following my gaze. "I'll eat it all."

HEADLINE: Japanese Officials Are Trying To Lower the Yen With Talk 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 3 

 BODY:
Japanese financial officials are once again talking down the yen, but their motives this time extend beyond trying to increase exports.
 Finance Minister Masajuro Shiokawa said on Sunday that based on the weakness of Japan's economy, the dollar should trade at 150 to 160 yen, about 20 percent below its current level. The yen promptly notched its biggest one-day decline in more than two months on Monday and has failed to recoup its losses. It also fell against the euro. 
 It traded near 124.50 yen in Tokyo today, even after Mr. Shiokawa said the government would not actively sell yen to push down the value of the currency. 
In the past, remarks suggesting the government thought the yen was too strong would have signaled that the government was nervous about how the currency's value might inhibit Japanese exports, the main driver of the economy here. Recent figures show that shipments overseas are indeed flagging and that the economy will probably slow next year.
A weaker yen, whether driven lower by government pronouncements or economic fundamentals, would make Japanese products cheaper in overseas markets, a boon to companies like the Toyota Motor Corporation and the Sony Corporation, which earn the bulk of their profits in North America.
But policy makers are also battling persistent deflation, a widening budget gap and a bad-loan crisis that will probably require additional government support to banks.
It is unclear how much a bailout will cost, but with tax revenue falling and ratings agencies threatening to cut Japan's creditworthiness, the government must come up with more ways to finance its operations. One way is to get the central bank to print more money, which should lead to a weaker yen.
This, however, could create friction with other exporting countries in Asia and in America, where lawmakers are wary that companies are trying to dump goods. Just as important, the current Bank of Japan governor, Masaru Hayami, has resisted drastic steps to soften the currency and has even written books praising a strong yen. His policy board has consistently fended off calls to set an inflation target, buy foreign treasury bills or take other unconventional steps that might force the yen lower.
Mr. Hayami's term as governor, however, ends in March and Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi must help pick a successor soon. In this light, Mr. Shiokawa's comments are a sign that the government may be looking for a more accommodating central bank chief. By making this clear now, rather than in several months, policy makers are signaling their intentions to investors and trading partners. 
"We have reached a turning point," said Chris Walker, an economist at Credit Suisse First Boston. "People are waking up to two facts: Hayami will soon retire and the government will have to spend more."
Deliberately weakening a currency is not easily done. More than $1 trillion speeds through the foreign exchange markets every day, and traders must balance many factors when selling and buying. Economic recovery in the United States remains weak, for example, and the Federal Reserve's cut of half a percentage point in interest rates last month has reduced the return from some American financial assets.
Weakening the yen may also encourage other nations to push their currencies down, offsetting some of the competitive advantage Japanese companies might gain. 
Still, Japan could win support for its weak-yen strategy if it is seen as part of a broader policy to combat deflation and end the decade-long bad-loan crisis. American officials would be hard pressed to argue with this because they have repeatedly called on Japan to fix its debt-sodden financial system, Mr. Walker said.
Given the political implications and the difficulty of manipulating exchange rates, though, few analysts said they expected the dollar to rise to 150 or 160 yen soon. Rather, they said, Japan appears more interested in laying the groundwork for a weaker yen in the future.
"The key point is not the level, but the direction," said Marshall Gittler, a currency strategist at Deutsche Bank in Tokyo. "Shiokawa and his colleagues are signaling loud and clear that they want a weaker yen. That's what investors should remember."

HEADLINE: Pricing the Ballgame 

BYLINE:  By Robert H. Frank; Robert H. Frank is a professor of economics at Cornell's Johnson School of Management.

DATELINE: ITHACA, N.Y. 

 BODY:
The Mets' move last week to variable ticket pricing occurred because Shea Stadium is like a commercial airliner. When a 757 takes off from nearby LaGuardia with unfilled seats, something of value is lost forever: the airline loses the revenue, and passengers lose the chance to travel. When the Mets play before less than sellout crowds at Shea, both the team and its fans lose as well. 
 Airlines have long used sophisticated pricing methods to fill empty seats, and the Mets' move follows a similar logic. Last season, a given seat at Shea sold for the same price every day. That seat will now sell at four different prices, depending on when the game occurs and the popularity of the opposing team. Fans can catch the lowly Brewers on a May weekday for as little as $8, down from $12 last season. But to see Barry Bonds hit a home run on a July Saturday, they'll have to pay at least $16. 
 Economic theory's ideal pricing scheme is one that eliminates excess demand during peak periods while serving customers at cost during off-peak periods. By that standard, the Mets' move is a clear improvement. Of course, that fact hasn't prevented the inevitable complaints about higher prices for popular games. The real problem, however, is that the new formula doesn't go far enough. Saturday Yankees games in July will still sell out months in advance, and Monday Brewers games in May will still fill less than a third of Shea's seats.
The Mets are not unique in departing from the economist's ideal price structure. Why do so many hotels, restaurants and other businesses charge prices that are too low when they're busy and too high when they're not? Their concern is that aggressive peak-period pricing might court a customer backlash. Why go to a restaurant that charges double on Saturdays, angry customers might wonder, even though the meal costs no more to prepare than on other nights?
This question betrays a faulty understanding of cost. Although the raw ingredients cost no more on Saturdays, the cost of serving additional diners is still far greater than on other days; the restaurant would have to enlarge its facilities and buy more equipment to accommodate larger crowds. Additional Tuesday patrons, in contrast, can be served without spending an extra cent on such items. A similar logic applies to the Mets, who would need a bigger stadium and more parking to serve additional fans at sellouts.
Would larger price differentials be fair? Customers don't feel betrayed when grocers charge them three times as much for three pounds of beef as for one pound, since those who buy more obviously impose higher costs on the seller. By the same token, peak-period users of stadiums or restaurants should pay higher prices, because they too impose higher costs. But because the cost differences in these cases are less obvious, customers often regard price differentials as unfair. This perception is an illusion.
No strategy will fill more empty seats at Shea than for the team's new manager to guide the Mets to a winning season. By all means, let the quest to win continue. Meanwhile, the team and its fans will gain by having prices that track costs more closely.

HEADLINE: Candidates In South Korea Differ Sharply On the North 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 3 

 BODY:
In their first debate as they entered the South Korean presidential campaign's final stretch, the two leading candidates advocated sharply different approaches toward North Korea tonight, and called for tighter regulations governing American troops here.
 With opinion polls suggesting the race is too close to call, the governing party candidate, Roh Moo Hyun, stoutly defended President Kim Dae Jung's so-called sunshine policy of engagement with North Korea, suggesting at one point that the only thing that needed changing was the policy's name. 
 Lee Hoi Chang, meanwhile, Mr. Roh's main conservative rival, relentlessly attacked Mr. Kim's approach to North Korea. Mr. Lee repeatedly alluded to recent revelations that North Korea had been secretly developing nuclear weapons and said that if he won on Dec. 19, he would make a clean break with recent policies that sought to obtain the cooperation of the impoverished North by providing economic aid. 
"I have a very definite policy on North Korea," said Mr. Lee, a former Supreme Court justice, suggesting that he would continue to send food and other goods to meet civilian needs. "I will stop money support," he added "because money can subsidize nuclear development. That is why we must stop it. This is also a part of an effort to make North Korea abandon nuclear weapons."
Both Mr. Lee and Mr. Roh, along with a third candidate who took part in the two-hour debate, Kwon Young Gil, said they would seek to renegotiate the Status of Forces Agreement, or SOFA, governing the legal rights and behavior of the 37,000 American troops stationed in South Korea.
Mr. Lee, the candidate of the conservative Grand National Party, narrowly lost to Mr. Kim in the last presidential election, five years ago. South Korean presidents are limited by the Constitution to one term. Opinion polls are banned by law in the final phase of the campaign, but the last published polls indicated that Mr. Roh had a narrow lead.
The American troop presence here has become the focus of an increasingly intense protest movement, which began last summer when two teenage girls were crushed to death by an American armored vehicle. The protests have accelerated since the acquittal late last month of the two army sergeants involved.
The servicemen's trials here, conducted in accordance with the Status of Forces Agreement, involved all-American juries, which has incensed many here, fueling calls to renogotiate the agreement.
With anti-American feeling rising, the leading presidential candidates have said South Korea should renegotiate the agreement. Today, President Kim added his voice to the calls. 
He noted that it was revised last year to bring it to the level of those pacts with Japan and Germany, "but with this incident as a lesson, the two sides must work more closely to improve SOFA further and develop the Korea-U.S. alliance in a future-orientated direction," Mr. Kim was quoted as telling his cabinet in the transcript released by his office.
Mr. Kim also took pains today to defend his country's alliance with the United States. "Constructive criticism of U.S. policies is permissible, but a tide of indiscriminate anti-American sentiment is of no benefit to the national interest," he said.
Mr. Roh, a political heir to Mr. Kim, with similar roots in center-left social activism, was even more assertive on the Status of Forces Agreement, and appeared to be trying to channel some of the public anger into his campaign. "As a presidential candidate, is it necessary or appropriate to sign on to a plea?" he said. "The SOFA agreement should be amended, although one thing is for sure: If I become president, I will definitely correct our chronic attitude of accepting" American demands "without criticism."
Throughout his presidency, Mr. Kim has been an ardent advocate of dialogue with North Korea, which won him the Nobel Peace Prize in 2000. His stance, though, has sometimes contributed to diplomatic tensions with the Bush administration, which has consistently taken a more skeptical approach to North Korea.
For weeks, Mr. Lee has attacked the sunshine policy, characterizing it as naive, and has tried to turn the news of North Korea's nuclear program into a liability for Mr. Roh. "We've had five years of the sunshine policy, but behind our backs, North Korea was working on nuclear weapons," Mr. Lee said. 
In reply, Mr. Roh said his views on the need for American troops had changed long ago, and he struggled to establish some credentials on national security issues. "After that I had some political experience and came to know better," he said. "I came to know that it is necessary for U.S. troops to stay in Korea. That was a mistake of my judgment."

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET-- Jersey City; 
Building Warehouse Space on Speculation in a Frail Economy

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Construction has started on two sprawling warehouses on the Hudson River shoreline in Jersey City, even though the developer has no agreements yet with potential tenants. 
 "The site's location tipped the scale toward construction" despite a softening in the commercial market, said Jeffrey E. Kelter, president and chief executive of the Keystone Property Trust. The groundbreaking at the gritty 26-acre site in the southern reaches of Jersey City's riverfront was held last month. 
 The buildings, one with 182,000 square feet and the other with 343,000 square feet, are off Exit 14A of the New Jersey Turnpike, near the port installations in Newark and Elizabeth. The site is in both a state-designated urban enterprise zone and a federal-designated foreign trade zone, which offer tenants tax breaks and other incentives. 
Building on speculation in a fragile economy may seem quixotic. But Keystone, a publicly traded real estate trust based in the Philadelphia suburb of West Conshohocken, Pa., has the financial strength to construct the buildings without tenants, even at a cost of $33 million. It is betting that once the buildings are completed by June, they will not sit idle. 
Keystone owns 21 million square feet of industrial space nationwide and 6.6 million in New Jersey, with 3.3 million square feet more under development in the state outside Jersey City. The Jersey City buildings will be the final development within a 50-acre industrial park called Greenville Yards, begun as a city redevelopment project. Two warehouses, totaling 269,180 square feet, have already been built for specific users who also own their land, and construction will start this month on a third building, with 50,000 additional square feet. 
Keystone is confident that there will be demand for its buildings since, for years, only a meager amount of modern warehouse space has been constructed on speculation in North Jersey and particularly in the port area. The warehouses will have 36-foot ceilings, numerous loading bays, sprinkler systems and enough space for long tractor-trailers to turn around easily.
The lack of construction and the scarcity of buildable sites have helped temper the impact of the recently difficult economic times on vacancy rates and rents of industrial space in North Jersey. According to Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate services firm, the vacancy rate for such space was 6.3 percent in the third quarter, up from 5.1 percent a year earlier. In the same periods, average asking rents for warehouses fell to $6.29 a square foot a year from $6.39. 
Rents at Keystone's buildings, designed by Andrew C. Churchill of Indianapolis, are expected to be $8.50 a square foot a year. "What tenants gain by operating more efficiently in modern warehouses more than offsets the rent," Mr. Kelter said.
John P. DiCola, senior vice president for investments at Keystone, said the company expected seaport sites to be increasingly attractive to users, particularly importers and exporters. He pointed to the capital improvement program begun in 2000 by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which this year dredged harbor channels to accommodate larger container ships. That in turn will enable the port to capture some Asian cargo trade from West Coast ports, he said.
Keystone bought the 26-acre site in September for $6.5 million from the Jersey City Redevelopment Authority. The authority, with Barrett Builders of Fort Lee as the designated developer, began to build the 50-acre industrial park in the late 1990's after a decade of delays, related in part to environmental issues.
The site, a brownfield, had to be cleaned of contaminants, mostly fly ash, remnants from its past as part of a 200-acre tract once owned by Conrail and used as a switching station, said Thomas Barrett, president of Barrett Builders, which is also the contractor for Keystone's buildings. The Port Authority earlier developed 150 of the 200 acres for uses like the Tropicana Northeast distribution center and a BMW complex where imported cars are received and inspected before being delivered to dealerships. 
Keystone's parcel is being cleaned according to a state-approved plan. The cleanup involves monitoring the groundwater, hauling away tainted soil and capping the tract by building the warehouses on it, Mr. Barrett said.
Sanford Greenberg, project coordinator at Jersey City's redevelopment authority, said the Keystone buildings would generate up to 400 jobs of a sort different from those in the city's office towers. "We need all sectors to diversify our employment and economic base," Mr. Greenberg said, adding that it "helps during hard times."

HEADLINE: Women's Colleges Learning How to Get a Man 

BYLINE:  By MAREK FUCHS 

 BODY:
Since its founding in 1893, Hood College in Frederick, Md., has enrolled only women as full-time residential students. But after a decade of deficits and a growing struggle to find students, it has decided to become coeducational.
 "It was very frustrating from an admission standpoint to be at an all-women's school," said Susan Hallenbeck, dean of admissions. "You'd be at a college fair, talking to someone who was articulate and bright and when they learned that it was a women's residential school, they'd say no thanks and turn around and walk away." 
 There were once hundreds of all-women's colleges, most of which were founded in the 1800's and early 1900's. But since the late-1960's, in response to social, financial and competitive realities, most women's colleges have, like Hood, opened their doors to men. 
But the day the trustees vote to go coeducational can mark the beginning of a new challenge: attracting men to a place that is fixed in the public consciousness as a women's college. Fighting that lingering reputation has, for a range of institutions, been a difficult task.
Sarah Lawrence, which opened in 1928 as a women's college, went coeducational in 1968, but the percentage of men at the 1,000-student school in Yonkers has been frozen at 20 to 25 percent ever since. 
"The biggest struggle still," said Thyra L. Briggs, the dean of admissions, "is to let everyone know that we're coeducational. Thirty-five years later, mothers are still pulling their sons away from our table at college fairs, saying, 'Oh, no, that's a girl's school.' " 
The fact that Sarah Lawrence happens to have a woman's name, noted Ms. Briggs, is problematic, "and not just in rural Iowa -- but also Groton, Conn." There's a joke on campus that men would be more interested in a school called Max Lawrence.
Ms. Briggs said that 25 percent of all applicants -- both men and women -- end up enrolling, but fewer men apply, and the college will not lower its standards to achieve parity between the sexes. That said, Ms. Briggs admits to "keeping one eye on men, just as we keep one eye on people of color and other geographic and socioeconomic groups that add diversity."
Michele Tolela Myers, president of Sarah Lawrence, said there was a time when the small proportion of men caused considerable angst, and the methods used to dispel old notions were a touch heavy-handed.
In 1982, the college released a 16-page marketing booklet, "Sarah Lawrence Men." The first sentence was a question: "To be male and to be at Sarah Lawrence?" The answer offered reassurance: "The men are here to stay as vital figures in the intellectual, cultural and recreational life of the college." The booklet went on to profile six Sarah Lawrence graduates, including, pointedly, an industrial engineer, a doctor and a man who spends his free time playing in a town baseball league. 
One factor that made Sarah Lawrence's conversion difficult, Dr. Myers said, was that for decades the college had been identified in the news media as an intellectual center for politically and socially active New York women. "But at the time we went coeducational a lot of other schools did, too, so it wasn't news," Dr. Myers said.
What was a big story at the time was what sort of men would go to a former women's college, and some of the first answers caused Vassar, which went coeducational in 1970, a public relations headache. From Mary McCarthy's popular novel "The Group," about eight Vassar graduates, as well as frequent references in the culture, Vassar, like Sarah Lawrence, was an icon as a women's college.
But in 1974, an Esquire article turned the spotlight on the first men at Vassar, and the depiction was not flattering.
In one of the tamer passages, Janie Gaynor wrote: "The 'Vassar Male' has not had time to develop completely, but the preliminary model seems to be skinny with a sallow complexion."
Vassar's freshman class this year is now about 40 percent men, close to the average for liberal arts colleges. But Frances D. Fergusson, who has been Vassar's president for nearly 17 years, said that getting there has not been easy. "It takes time in academia, meaning a generation, or 25 years, for people to change their opinions about an institution," she said. 
She added: "I got here 16 years after the moment when the change occurred, and there were still people who would forget we were coed, even those who were doing our recruiting."
Though the basics of the Vassar education were not touched, there were tweaks.
"When I came in, admissions material was done in pastel colors," Dr. Fergusson said. "It didn't work so well." Then there was the issue of the school colors. "They were a soft pinky-rose and gray," she said. "They are now a deeper maroon red and gray. We saturated the colors a little, which seems appropriate." 
Vassar, which is in Poughkeepsie, opened a $10 million athletic center in 2000, which Dr. Fergusson said was done for the sake of all students, not to attract men. "But I will say," she added, "that for a while Vassar did hesitate to go into athletics, because it looked like we were giving in to men. But that overlooked how much women -- and increasingly so -- are involved in athletics."
Norman Fainstein, who used to be the dean of faculty at Vassar, is now the president of Connecticut College in New London, also a former women's school. He said the reality of having a less splashy past made attracting men "easier and smoother for us" than it has been for Vassar or Sarah Lawrence. Connecticut College, which went coeducational in 1969, is currently 42 percent men, and has remained between 39 percent and 49 percent men since 1985. 
Dr. Fainstein said that compared with Sarah Lawrence, his college has another advantage that is a product of luck.
"It's a neutral name," he said. "Like Colorado College, we sometimes get confused with the state school, but there's not the women's school confusion." There could have been -- it was once named Connecticut College for Women -- but the "for women" was easily lopped off. 
Few college officials admit to overt strategies to lure men to campus, but Richard A. Berman, the president of Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y., does.
Manhattanville, a Catholic college which became both coeducational and non-denominational in the early 1970's, is currently 32 percent men, and Mr. Berman said his goal was to bring it up to the national average. To this end, the college is dedicating resources to majors that appeal to men, like economics, which is 55 percent male, and mathematics, 50 percent male.
"We tend to strengthen some of the majors that are more attractive to men, while staying within our mission," he said.
Four years ago, in part to attract men, the college started hockey teams for both men and women. Recently, it signed a five-year, $1 million contract so the two teams could use Rye Playland's ice rink as its home ice. "We've also raised the bar for all our athletic programs," Mr. Berman said, "and we've done more recruiting."
Shoring up sports and tailoring academic offerings are crucial for former women's colleges, said Thomas G. Mortenson, a senior scholar at the Pell Institute, especially in the current environment in which men are going to college in smaller numbers over all than women.
"Sports programs and facilities are attractive to men, and you better have engineering and computer science or you don't have a fighting chance," Mr. Mortenson said. "Too many schools are all about literature, English and French, and then they put some photographs of beautiful girls in the brochure and think that will attract the men."
At Hood College, which hopes that admitting men will lead to a financial turnaround, officials are employing a grab bag of methods. Hood is starting five male athletic teams; emphasizing fields of study, like management, that appeal to men; mining databases for alumni with sons of suitable age; and waging e-mail campaigns to guidance counselors.
Dr. Hallenbeck, Hood's dean of admissions, said the college had received 21 applications from men, and she hoped to enroll an entire residence floor of 30 to 35 come September.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE; 
An Urban Attraction for Students

BYLINE:  By ROBERT SHAROFF 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 3 

 BODY:
A college dormitory now under construction will double the amount of student housing in the Loop, the city's downtown business district, and is another step in the transformation of State Street -- formerly the city's retail hub -- into a mixed-use avenue of stores, theaters and educational sites.
 The $150 million project, called University Center, is notable for another reason as well. It is, spokesmen for each of the institutions involved said, the first time three universities have collaborated on the construction of housing. The three -- all of which have downtown campuses within walking distance -- are DePaul and Roosevelt Universities and Columbia College. 
 The three have formed a nonprofit corporation called the Educational Advancement Fund to develop and manage the 700,000-square-foot, 1,720-bed dormitory, which is expected to be finished by the start of the 2004 academic year.
"The economies of scale, the financing and the construction all speak to this being a prototype other schools will duplicate in the future," said Kenneth McHugh, executive vice president for operations at DePaul, which started the project in the late 1990's when plans for a DePaul-only dormitory on the site fell through. "The financing alone is something no one university could do on its own. There are enormous economies of scale with regard not only to construction costs but also to operating expenses."
The project is being financed by 30-year bonds that will be retired by the roughly $20 million a year in revenues the fully leased dormitory is expected to generate. The city -- which has been promoting the revitalization of State Street for a number of years -- has donated the land, a 1.45 acre site at the southeast corner of State Street and Congress Parkway, valued at about $5 million.
Alicia Mazur Berg, Chicago's commissioner of planning and development, said the city was getting "a big bang for the buck." The student population not only has a major economic impact on stores and restaurants, she said, but also contributes to Mayor Richard M. Daley's stated goal of making the Loop a place where there is 24-hour activity.
A big factor in the success of the project was making it a stand-alone proposition not dependent on the financial performances of the different universities. 
"The financing has been done in a way that maximizes control on the part of the institutions but at the same time passes off much of the risk for debt service to individual investors," said Robert Bronstein, president of the Scion Group, a Chicago-based real estate consulting firm that assisted in the project's financing. 
Specifically, the universities have signed a guarantee to lease all of the dormitory's 1,720 beds for the first year of operation. 
Current demand for student housing downtown is so strong, however, that, "investors are willing to invest based on the cash flows of the project, as opposed to the creditworthiness of the schools," Mr. Bronstein said.
The universities are not equal partners in the project. DePaul and Columbia both are taking about 40 percent of the beds while Roosevelt will have about 20 percent. 
Both Columbia and Roosevelt -- which have headquarters in the Loop -- have existing dorms in the area, with a total of just over 800 beds. DePaul, meanwhile, which has 2,600 beds at its main Lincoln Park campus on the North Side, recently signed a two-year lease on a 230-bed property at 320 North Michigan Avenue, which is intended to fill the housing gap until the new building is completed.
Rates paid by students in the joint dormitory will be the same no matter which university they attend and will range from $625 to $985 a month. 
"One of the challenges of this project will be creating a cohesive student community within the facility," said Albert Gall, executive vice president of Columbia College. "It would be difficult to build such a community if Columbia's students, say, were paying more than other students."
The project is being designed by two Chicago architecture firms, Antunovich Associates and VOA Associates, with the former being the lead designer.
The 18-story reinforced-concrete structure will also include 32,000 square feet of ground-floor retail space as well as 15,000 square feet of conference space. "The idea is that in summer, when a dorm would normally be empty, the universities will host conferences where attendees will stay in the building," said Joseph Antunovich, president of Antunovich Associates.
The dorm rooms come in two sizes; there are 312 two-bedroom suites and 192 four-bedroom miniapartments. Each room is designed to house four students. "Each room will have high-speed Internet access, cable TV and individual climate-control systems," Mr. Antunovich said. "It's a very sophisticated facility."
That there is a shortage of student housing in Chicago seems undeniable. Three years ago, the Scion Group surveyed 33 of the largest postsecondary institutions in the city and found that 29 cited the lack of adequate housing as a continuing problem in attracting and keeping students. 
"It really is something that is critical to the growth of urban schools," Mr. Bronstein said. "If you're 17 or 18 years old and can't live on campus, chances are you're not going to rent an apartment in downtown Chicago or Boston or New York."
A decade ago, there was little or no student housing in the Loop. The boom began when the School of the Art Institute opened a 200-bed dormitory -- since converted to academic space -- across Michigan Avenue from the institute in 1993. This was followed by a 200-bed dormitory on Madison Street in 1996. Both of these buildings involved renovating existing Class C office and hotel properties into living spaces. 
Finally, in 2000, the school opened a splashy complex at the corner of State and Randolph Streets that involved both new and old construction and included a 500-bed dormitory and a new home for the Gene Siskel Film Center, part of the institute. In addition, the complex has 34,000 square feet of retail space anchored by a three-level Borders Books store. Over all, the school has spent about $100 million on downtown student housing projects over the last decade, financed by 30-year revenue bonds.
The addition of housing has had a significant impact on the school, according to Tony Jones, its president. "When I came here in 1985, 75 percent of the student body was from Illinois or neighboring states," he said. "Today, it's the reverse. It's a gigantic sea change."
The three universities behind University Center have similar aims. "The project is very market driven," Mr. Gall said. "In the last few years, the number of out-of-town applications and inquiries we've had has increased significantly. In order to position the institution to respond to these inquiries, we have to acquire and develop housing strategies."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS; 
AOL Time Warner's Warning About Advertising Sends Shares Down

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
A disappointing outlook from AOL Time Warner put investors on the defensive yesterday, prompting them to question the strength of other companies and bid stocks lower. 
 Analysts said the downturn, which extended a decline that began on Friday, was not surprising given how far stock prices had come recently, with the Dow Jones industrial average moving higher in the last eight weeks. 
 While investors are growing more confident about the economy and earnings, they are expected to cash in some profits, especially amid the uncertainty over whether there will be a war with Iraq. 
"At these levels, the market is in pullback mode," said Gary Kaltbaum, market technician for Investors' Edge Partners in Orlando, Fla. 
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 119.64 points, or 1.4 percent, at 8,742.93, for a three-day loss of 188.75. 
The broader market also retreated. The Nasdaq index fell 35.82 points, or 2.4 percent, to 1,448.96. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 13.78 points, or 1.5 percent, to 920.75. 
Investors sold off AOL, down $2.36, to $14.21, after the company affirmed its 2002 earnings forecast for its America Online unit but warned of sinking advertising revenues. 
Wall Street's losers also included companies scheduled to issue earnings outlooks later in the week, a sign that investors were feeling skittish. 
Merck dropped $1.13, to $58.82, ahead of its yearly forecast tomorrow. Its shares fell as much as $4.79 but partly recovered after the company said that it was reaffirming its outlook. 
Intel fell 74 cents, to $20.31, ahead of tomorrow's midquarter update. 
Investors also punished Ford Motor, which fell $1.49, to $9.96, after posting about a 20 percent drop in November car sales. 
Brokerage firm downgrades hurt other stocks. The supermarket chain Albertson's fell $1.31, to $22.26, on a downgrade from J. P. Morgan, while Marriott International declined $1.22, to $34.47, on a downgrade from Deutsche Securities. 
Analysts called the market's slippage moderate, and in some ways, necessary.
"The market has gotten a little extended here without resolution to the Iraq conflict," said Jeff Kleintop, chief investment strategist for the PNC Financial Services Group in Philadelphia. 
"We have gone beyond or at the threshold of where the market is comfortable going right now," he said. 
But there were some gainers on Wall Street, including Citrix Systems, up $1.26, at $12.69, after raising its fourth-quarter earnings estimate. --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
By Reuters
Treasury prices pushed higher yesterday, taking advantage of a second session of stock weakness to recoup some lost ground, though traders cautioned that customer demand was sporadic. 
Data on chain store sales, while showing some growth last week, failed to match hopes of a bumper start to the holiday season and gave some support to Treasury prices.
The 10-year note rose 4/32, to a price of 98 11/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 4.21 percent, from 4.22 percent on Monday. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond also rose 4/32, to 105 2/32. The yield dropped to 5.04 percent from 5.05 percent.

HEADLINE: Egyptian Court Frees Rights Advocate and Orders Retrial 

BYLINE:  By NEIL MacFARQUHAR

 BODY:
In a stunning slap at Egypt's emergency laws, the country's highest appeals court ordered a retrial yesterday for Saad Eddin Ibrahim, an Egyptian-American civil rights advocate whose high-profile prosecution strained ties with the United States and was seen as a blatant effort to intimidate critics of the Cairo government.
 Mr. Ibrahim, a sociology professor who has been ailing, was released so quickly from Tora Prison in Cairo after the ruling that when his family was called to collect him they found him just outside the walls in his prison robe with just his walker.
 The Court of Cassation nullified a seven-year sentence issued two times by the Supreme State Security Court and announced that the highest court itself would hear a new trial starting on Jan. 7. 
Mr. Ibrahim, 64, and his supporters expressed confidence that he would be acquitted this time.
"This whole case was unnecessary," Mr. Ibrahim, looking drawn, told reporters as he sat on a couch in his apartment a few hours after his release. "Everyone emerged a loser. The country is a loser. The government is a loser. The regime was a loser. I was a loser, and my family was a loser."
He and 27 others, mostly staff members at the Ibn Khaldoun Center for Social and Developmental Studies, were arrested in July 2000 after announcing that they would monitor parliamentary elections that fall. The center had said the elections in 1995 were rigged.
Mr. Ibrahim had been found guilty of defaming Egypt, accepting money from overseas without authorization and other charges stemming from his research on sensitive topics like voter rights and the treatment of the Coptic minority.
The case was a curiosity from the start, with the grapevine attributing it to an article that he wrote that ridiculed the idea of Arab leaders, including President Hosni Mubarak, grooming their sons for succession. 
The United States had raised concerns about the case and its ramifications for reform in Egypt. President Bush sent a letter to Mr. Mubarak over the summer that warned that the United States would not deliver new aid to Egypt to protest the prosecution. 
Today, the Bush administration praised the court decision. "As you are very well aware, the United States has felt that his conviction was unjust," said Philip T. Reeker, a spokesman for the State Department. 
The American Embassy in Cairo, Mr. Reeker said, has been in close contact with Mr. Ibrahim and his family throughout the case and will continue to monitor his treatment. 
Egypt had sought an additional $130 million this year after Congress approved a $200 million increase in aid for Israel to fight terrorism. Traditionally, the United States has increased aid to Egypt by two-thirds the amount of new funds for Israel. The two nations are the top two recipients of American assistance.
Administration critics have accused the government of being too timid in backing Mr. Ibrahim because they did not want to bruise relations with Cairo at a time the United States needed support in trying to solve the Palestinian-Israeli conflict and, possibly, in action against Iraq. Egypt reacted by telling the United States to stay out of its internal affairs, and the criticism from Washington was used to smear Mr. Ibrahim. 
"It backfired, because the governmental press used this to tarnish Saad Eddin Ibrahim further and tell people here we've been deprived of $130 million because of this American spy," said Hisham Kassem of the Egyptian Organization for Human Rights. 
Neither human rights advocates nor Mr. Ibrahim's family said they thought that the American criticism had any effect on the Court of Cassation. They said the court would have ordered a retrial anyway in view of its reputation for independence. 
"The moral of the story is that the judiciary needs reform, that we're still safe with the Court of Cassation, and that it's not safe for civil rights activists to work anymore," Mr. Kassem said. "They are perceived as a threat by the government." 
Mr. Ibrahim noted that the ruling yesterday was the second time that the Court of Cassation had saved him. It had previously ordered the Supreme State Security Court to retry the case, and that court handed down the same speedy verdict. 
Egyptian and international human rights organizations had denounced the trials last year and earlier this year, accusing the State Security Court of trampling over basic procedures in its eagerness to convict. 
"This shows how this parallel system is so unjust against the citizen and against the country," said Mr. Ibrahim, a professor at the American University in Cairo. 
Three other employees of the Ibn Khaldoun Center, which Mr. Ibrahim helped found and which pushed for political and economic reform throughout the Arab world, had also been found guilty and given lesser sentences. The Court of Cassation also demanded new trials for them. They are widely expected to be released soon. 
Human rights organizations that monitored the trials said the charges against Mr. Ibrahim belonged in the regular court system and not in the emergency courts, which give the government sweeping powers to arrest and convict.
"In the state security system, you clearly have a misuse of law," said Neil Hicks, a specialist on the Egyptian legal system at the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights in New York. "You have a system used to target the government's nonviolent political enemies." 
Mr. Hicks said the new decision showed that there was still some independence in Egypt's judiciary system. 
"It sends an important message that there is still space for independent thought and free speech and nonviolent criticism of the government in Egypt," he said.
In a statement from Washington, Human Rights Watch, called on the government to restore Mr. Ibrahim's passport and to let him travel abroad for medical treatment. He broke his leg in prison. 
Spectators packing the small courtroom clapped and hugged one another when the ruling was read. 
"It's a wonderful day for me, for my husband, for Egyptians and justice in this country," said Mr. Ibrahim's wife, Barbara. 
Mr. Ibrahim spent 14 months in jail, being released for five months in the summer for his second trial. He said that he spent his time incarcerated working or giving literacy classes for the prison guards and that he heard the news about the court decision from other inmates. 
"We're all a bit stunned," said his daughter Ronda, describing the initial scene at home with Mr. Ibrahim's dandling a grandchild on each knee while speaking on a telephone in each ear to well-wishers and Arabic satellite television stations.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Saad Eddin Ibrahim greeting family members yesterday outside Tora Prison in Cairo after 14 months in jail. His wife, Barbara, and daughter Ronda, below, after the top appeals court in Egypt freed Mr. Ibrahim. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Democratic State Senator Is Switching to the G.O.P. 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
State Senator Olga A. Mendez, who represents a largely Hispanic district in northern Manhattan and part of the Bronx, announced yesterday that she was leaving the Democratic Party. She made the announcement surrounded by Republican leaders, including the governor and the mayor.
 Senator Mendez said she was switching parties because she and the voters she has represented for two dozen years had been taken for granted by the Democrats. 
 "The party has changed," she said at a news conference at the Women's National Republican Club in Midtown Manhattan. "And I no longer feel that the Democratic Party will be able to fill the needs that will solve the problems of my Puerto Rican constituents, my African-Americans and my whites in the 28th District. "I was hopeful that things would have changed within my own party. They haven't, so I do what I've got to do." 
Her announcement news conference, treated as a major event by Republicans, was attended by Gov. George E. Pataki, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, among others.
With her switch, the Republican hold on the State Senate grows to 38 members, with the Democrats holding 24 seats. That gives the Republicans a three-fifths majority, which they need to pass the various local laws, and cuts the Democratic minority's leverage.
Many Democratic leaders, noting that Ms. Mendez has long voted with the Republican majority, said her decision would have little practical effect. Indeed, she was seen as one of Governor Pataki's major allies, having appeared in campaign commercials on his behalf earlier this year. 
Mr. Pataki did unusually well among Hispanic voters, taking about 38 percent of their votes, according to one estimate by the Graduate Center of the City University.
Ms. Mendez asserted that many Hispanic voters had become disenchanted with the Democratic Party. Pointing to economic development plans of the Pataki administration in her district, she said that voters had rewarded those efforts by throwing more support to Mr. Pataki and Mr. Bloomberg in recent elections.
In his remarks yesterday, Mr. Pataki said that her decision was fresh evidence that Republicans were making considerable gains among Hispanic voters as well as other groups. He said that he and other party leaders were working to "make sure that our party reaches out in ways that it hadn't in the past to different communities like the Latino community, like labor and gay and lesbian groups, to make sure that we do have an inclusive, big-tent party."
Ms. Mendez said that she had been repeatedly courted in the past by Mr. Bruno and that this time, he had offered her any Senate committee chairmanship she wanted. But she said that she had declined to take on any such role, adding that she had "other things" in mind that she would discuss later.
What the switch in party affiliation bodes for Ms. Mendez's political career in the long term is uncertain. In February, another longtime Democratic state senator, Pedro Espada Jr. of the Bronx, made a similar announcement, saying he was joining the Republican Party. Although Mr. Espada never officially changed his registration, his announcement became an issue in his re-election effort.
Mr. Espada lost the Democratic primary to City Councilman Ruben Diaz Sr., who had been selected by Democratic Party officials in the Bronx less than two weeks before the primary. And Mr. Espada, who remained on the ballot on the Republican and Independence Party lines, lost the general election last month. Like Mr. Espada, Ms. Mendez represents a heavily Democratic district that includes East Harlem, parts of Washington Heights and the South Bronx.
Some Democrats suggested that the 77-year-old senator might not run for re-election in two years. Yesterday, she called that supposition untrue. She added that she felt certain "that I made the right decision."
She said that she had not calculated how the voters night react to her decision in future elections but added that "I'm willing to take the consequences."

GRAPHIC: Photo: State Senator Olga A. Mendez says she is leaving the Democratic Party because it has taken her and the voters she represents for granted. (Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times)

PERSON: Ronnie Lowenstein 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
A Budget Office Scorned . . . Until a Budget Crisis

BYLINE:  By LYNDA RICHARDSON 

 BODY:
DURING the city's boom times in the late 1990's, Ronnie Lowenstein had a low profile as the chief economist in the New York City Independent Budget Office. Still, she had good reason to jump out of bed every morning and get to work. Call it the fear factor.
 The budget office, though approved by voters in 1989 as part of the city's Charter, was on the hit list of a succession of mayors and elected officials, who saw it as another layer of bureaucracy. Modeled on the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, it did not come to life with financing until 1996. And that took three lawsuits. 
 "People knew we were under attack, so they didn't want to be seen with us, literally," says Ms. Lowenstein, smiling and shaking her head. "There were elected officials who would call us but not be seen with us."
Ms. Lowenstein, 51 and now the director, is found the other morning in her austere office in a William Street high-rise near City Hall. With the city crunching numbers, having just plugged a $1.1 billion budget gap this fiscal year and struggling to fill a hole next year that had grown to $6.4 billion, guess whose telephone is ringing constantly?
"I may have been dull a few years ago, but I'm way more interesting now," says Ms. Lowenstein, laughing. "What may have been seen as abstract when the city was in a surplus seems very immediate when the city is looking at closing firehouses and hiking the property tax. We get so many requests from everybody; advocates -- the media, elected officials and the public -- that we now have to triage requests."
Sitting at a conference table in her tidy office, she is warm and friendly, chipper even, considering she was up at 1 a.m. baking holiday cookies. She pulls out a blank legal pad in anticipation of questions she can't immediately answer. On the walls, what passes for decorative art is a very large poster of an unofficial income tax receipt with a pie chart.
She is asked about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's austerity plan. What, for example, does she think of the 18.5 percent property tax rate increase imposed on city residents?
"If you've got a very large gap to deal with, you have to do some amount of spending cuts and tax increases, and this is the opening salvo in making sure this year's budget is balanced and starting to balance the budget for next year."
Yep. This is about as good as it gets. Don't expect her to unload juicy stuff on, say, her inner feelings about tax-increment financing.
"I'm not going to tell you whether I like this or that," she says. "Part of being the director is checking subjective beliefs and partisanship at the door."
She joined the office in 1996 from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, taking over as director two years ago. She switched her party registration from Democrat to independent to emphasize her lack of political ties.
Even so, the office drew a vitriolic reaction from former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican. Among other things, it issued a report contradicting his assessment that a new stadium on the West Side would pay for itself. Ms. Lowenstein says the agency has a more collegial relationship with Mayor Bloomberg.
Recently reappointed to a four-year term by a committee of four elected officials, she clearly relishes the agency's role as impartial broker. "That was the idea from the beginning, putting out the best credible policy analyses that you can possibly do and the ability to be dispassionate about a topic that people feel passionate about," she says.
Ms. Lowenstein, who looks smaller than 5-foot-4, seems unflappable, detail-oriented. Yet her manner is perfectly accessible as she plunges into a fusillade of numbers. "This is techie," she leans over often to say. Her warm brown eyes take in a visitor's glazed expression, and she lightens up.
BUDGET watchers give the agency high marks for its readable Web site,www.ibo.nyc.ny.us and for reports like the newsletter on topics ranging from education spending and capital construction to the environment. In April, the agency released the first in a series of reports outlining options to reduce the city's budget gap.
"Pieces of it have been picked up in the current plan, but we're not keeping a scorecard," she says proudly.
Ms. Lowenstein grew up in Plainview, N.Y., the daughter of a garment-industry manufacturer and a substitute teacher. While studying at Guilford College in North Carolina, she imagined becoming a lawyer. So did many of her friends. Hear of supply and demand? She settled on economics.
"There are so many public-policy issues that fundamentally hinge upon economics, including welfare, taxation and education," says Ms. Lowenstein, who received her Ph.D. from Columbia. "I wanted to shed some light on it, and understand this important tool and translate it to a broader audience."
For the record, there's another side to Ms. Lowenstein. Remember those holiday cookies? An Upper West Sider, she has two sons, ages 17 and 20. Her husband, Kenneth, is a land-use lawyer.
As a parent, she wants her 27-member staff to get home to their kids at night. During the budget season, she says, that often means trading draft reports and spreadsheets by e-mail from home, well past midnight.
"I think it would be a mistake to say that now that we are well respected, we can sit back and coast," she says. "We've got to continue to show we're very credible and useful."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
BOEING WORKERS IN WASHINGTON APPROVE CONTRACT

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 The Boeing Company's engineers and technical workers in Washington State have overwhelmingly approved new three-year contracts that give the company some stability during a time of turmoil in commercial aviation. 
The agreements included raises and higher pensions but also increased the workers' share of medical care costs. The engineers and the technical workers approved their contracts by identical percentages, with 88.2 percent voting yes and 11.8 percent voting no, the union said. The union's leadership had recommended approval, saying it was the best contract possible given the economic downturn.

HEADLINE: United's Rivals Press a Struggle Of Rare Ferocity 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 3 

 BODY:
The vitriolic campaign by major competitors of United Airlines to undermine its application for $1.8 billion in federal loan guarantees is only growing more brutal in its final days.
 Led by Northwest, Continental and American, the effort has included not just heated lobbying and the bandying about of financial analyses that cast doubts on United's business case, but also personal attacks by rival airline executives against United's top management. 
 Such contentiousness harks back to the last great political battle over bailing out an American industrial icon -- the Chrysler Corporation's struggle in 1979 to win Congressional backing for loan guarantees, at a time when Chrysler, the No. 3 automaker, was drowning in red ink.
That debate, like the one raging now over United, raised fundamental questions about the government's role in saving a sick company. But General Motors and Ford laid low in the battle over a Chrysler bailout -- a fight that seems benign in comparison with the nastiness prevailing now, as United's petition awaits a ruling by the federal Air Transportation Stabilization Board. 
"Lobbying as an instrument of competitive strategy is nothing new, but I don't think I've ever seen it be so close to a blood sport," said John D. Donahue, professor of public policy at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University.
United's competitors -- irritated for years at how United, an employee-owned airline, has been run -- argue that Washington should do nothing to help the carrier avoid a Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing that they argue is just the medicine it needs.
"This is survival for us," said Gordon M. Bethune, Continental's chief executive, who has led the rivals' charge. "This is not a game. This is not a boys' club. All of us are dying." 
Earlier this week, Mr. Bethune, calling United's management "clueless," circulated a financial analysis by Continental saying that United, even with taxpayer backing, would run out of cash by early 2004. United executives quickly denied that, accusing Continental of making faulty assumptions about its finances.
But Mr. Bethune, whose airline went into bankruptcy protection twice before finally emerging in 1993, said that loan guarantees for United would reward a badly managed company that had not sold off valuable routes or made deep cuts like other struggling airlines. 
"Look at Eastern, T.W.A., Braniff, Pan Am and what they tried to do" to stay in business, he said in an interview. "United isn't too big to fail. They'll just make a bigger hole when they hit the ground."
Uniquely among the major airlines, employees own 55 percent of the UAL Corporation, United's parent, and have three seats on its board. Competitors say that arrangement, born of an earlier financial crisis, has made United soft, prone to granting generous contracts to its workers and otherwise allowing its operations to grow bloated. 
United officials, and leaders of its unions, say the other airlines hope to benefit from the chaos that might surround United if it seeks bankruptcy protection. They may also press their unions to match any lower pay rates or work rule changes forced upon United by a bankruptcy court.
"I can see why they would want to defeat us," said Frederic F. Brace III, United's chief financial officer, in an interview. "We are the airline that has the best set of assets in the industry, and our operating performance has been truly outstanding. They would clearly hate to compete with an airline that has the assets, the performance and much lower costs."
Still, the leading airlines -- caught in the worst industry downturn ever, with the industry's losses in the billions since the September 2001 attacks -- could end up ruing their success if the government turns away United's request for help.
If air travel shrinks further amid a war with Iraq, "these very airlines may find themselves pleading to resurrect a loan guarantee program before an angered and recalcitrant Congress," said Kevin P. Mitchell, president of the Business Travel Coalition, which represents corporate travel departments and travelers. 
While the Chrysler bailout was ultimately approved by Congress, a decision on assisting United falls to the more obscure air stabilization board, created by Congress after Sept. 11, 2001. Its three voting members -- top officials of the Treasury and Transportation Departments and the Federal Reserve -- have deliberated in private, and up to now over much smaller guarantee packages for much smaller airlines. 
As a result, experts say, neither United nor its competitors can be sure just what will sway the board. And that may be why rivals have been so hard nosed in their attacks.
"Because this is a new system and a secret system," Professor Donahue said, "nobody knows what the rules are and even if there are any rules."
The competitors' bitter campaign has startled some people in the airline industry, who remember the days before deregulation, when an almost familylike atmosphere prevailed among the carriers even as they competed for customers. The only family that the campaign against United brings to mind these days is the Sopranos, with Mr. Bethune in the unlikely role of don.
Mr. Bethune said he would have preferred to simply send a letter to the loan board opposing United's application and then let the process take care of itself. But, he maintained, seeing the lobbying campaign waged by United and its competitors, he decided to weigh in. "If it's just facts and data, we would just shut up and they would never get the loan," Mr. Bethune said. But once the process became political, he said, he thought it was important to speak up, because "our government is not always run on logic."
Mr. Brace, the United executive, sees a quite different impetus: Mr. Bethune, he said, would be eager to snap up United routes and other assets in a bankruptcy court fire sale.
"Obviously, Gordon has expressed his motive very directly," he said. "I can understand why they clearly would love to get their hands on some of our assets."
Analysts said that American, which last year displaced United as the world's largest airline, would also benefit from a hobbling of its competitor. It could compete aggressively for passengers in Chicago, a major hub for both carriers. And American -- struggling to beat back the industry's profit leader, Southwest, with which it competes on many of its domestic routes -- would be likely to seize any opening to cut labor costs.
Tim Doke, a spokesman for American, acknowledged there would be advantages for competitors in a bankruptcy filing by United. But there is a case to be made, he said, that United would benefit more.
"I think you can equally draw the scenario that it immediately gives them relief from paying their bills, such a significantly lower cost structure, and the ability to implement distress pricing," Mr. Doke said. "They would be able to use their lower costs as a pricing lever."
Although American, too, lost planes in the September 2001 attacks, it did not apply for loan guarantees because of indications that the loan board "would not look favorably on applications from people like us, Delta, Continental and United" that had assets they could easily sell or use as leverage in financing, Mr. Doke said. But when United applied, he said, "we were a little surprised."
Both Mr. Bethune and Mr. Doke argue that granting loan guarantees to United on the basis of the concessions it has secured from its employees would deal an unfair blow to the survival efforts of another struggling carrier, US Airways.
Already operating under bankruptcy protection, US Airways in recent days has cut more jobs, closed some maintenance operations and sought further concessions from its unions, which are beginning to dig in their heels.
"They'll never get another nickel," Mr. Bethune said of management at US Airways, if United gets its loan guarantees after obtaining just one round of concessions from its unions.
A US Airways spokesman declined to comment on whether it is lobbying against United's application.
