HEADLINE: Troops Disrupt Protest as Caracas Oil Workers Join Strike 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 3 

 BODY:
Soldiers firing tear gas put down a peaceful protest by striking antigovernment workers from the state oil company today, prompting dissident managers to announce that their walkout against President Hugo Chavez's left-leaning government would extend for a third day.
 The workers from Petroleos de Venezuela, one of the world's largest oil companies and a key supplier of oil to the United States, on Monday joined a national general strike convened by business leaders and politicians pressuring Mr. Chavez to hold an early referendum on his rule. 
 The strike, which continued today, had appeared to lose some momentum, as a growing number of shops and businesses opened throughout the city. 
But after troops scattered protesters, furious opposition leaders announced that the strike, aided by street protests, would continue on Wednesday. Oil company executives opposed to Mr. Chavez said they would join in full force, possibly paralyzing the government, which derives half its revenues from oil sales.
Dozens of heavily armed National Guard troops descended without warning early in the afternoon on hundreds of white collar workers who were staging a protest outside the offices of Petroleos de Venezuela.
"The people were peaceful, holding flags and yelling slogans, and they came down brutally and with a huge force," said Juan Fernandez, an oil company manager who is a dissident leader, in an interview.
The strike, which began Monday, puts the government and an increasingly emboldened opposition on a collision course and threatens to disrupt oil supplies for the United States. "Confrontation is dangerous," Mr. Fernandez said. "You know when it begins, but not when it ends."
The participation of oil company employees in a strike in April shut down the economy and prompted a week of protests that turned violent, leading to Mr. Chavez's temporary removal from power. Opponents charge that Mr. Chavez's government is inept and dangerously radical, while supporters say his reforms have given voice to the poor masses.
Speaking to reporters this evening, Mr. Chavez argued that the strike was a thinly disguised effort to topple him from power. He also played down the unrest, saying, "They are not going to destabilize the country." But oil company executives said 90 percent of the industry's executives and staff support workers were on strike, along with 65 percent of the blue collar workers.
Overseas shipments from the Puerto la Cruz refinery were interrupted. Gasoline supplies in Caracas were also expected to run out soon because of striking truck drivers.
The turmoil at the Petroleos de Venezuela facilities overshadowed a development that could help resolve the political turbulence. Electoral officials announced today that they had voted 4 to 1 in favor of holding a nonbinding referendum in February on Mr. Chavez's rule.
The announcement by Alfredo Avella, president of the National Electoral Council, appeared to overcome a Supreme Court decision last week that had voided an original 3-to-1 vote in favor of the referendum. The Supreme Court had said three votes were not enough, but today Mr. Avella announced that a board member who had not voted initially had voted in favor today.
"This changes everything," said an official close to talks, which are being mediated by the Organization of American States. "We just hope things do not go crazy, and tomorrow we can start negotiating."
The streets here, though, were filled with mobs of enraged anti-Chavez protesters intent on antagonizing National Guard troops. Government foes angry that some businesses opened today forced the closings of a string of stores in at least two neighborhoods.
The store owners, many of them opponents of the government themselves, condemned the protesters, saying they felt harassed. Indeed, some shopkeepers who at first opened their doors had a change of heart after antigovernment demonstrators threw firecrackers inside their stores.
"We are not against a strike, but people should be allowed to do what they want to do," said Orlando Rodriguez, after shotgun-toting police officers arrived to enable him to open his deli. "We are fighting against Chavez, too. Why? Because he is trying to force us to do things."

HEADLINE: Big Three's Auto Sales Fell Sharply in November 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 3 

 BODY:
Sales at General Motors and the Ford Motor Company fell sharply in November from robust levels a year ago, and stocks of both companies were battered today. 
 Many investors are concerned about the prospect of slumping industry sales next year, which even the automakers are expecting, coupled with increasing competition as foreign carmakers open more plants in the United States and continue to encroach on the lucrative pickup and sport utility market. 
 Shares of Ford, which had begun to emerge from a deep swoon in recent weeks, fell 13 percent today, or $1.49, to $9.96. The company reported a 20 percent decline in sales in November from a year earlier and said it would cut production in the fourth quarter and next year. 
G.M. reported an 18 percent drop in sales from a year earlier, and its shares fell 5.1 percent, or $2.05, to $37.90. The disappointing performance last month was a significant setback for G.M. because its market share for the year is now down slightly from a year ago. 
Overall industry sales, which were strong until recent months, fell 12.7 percent in November from a year ago, according to Ward's AutoInfoBank. 
"Investors got much more optimistic about the economy over all so the sales numbers were a discordant data point," said John Casesa, an auto analyst at Merrill Lynch. "The auto sales numbers say demand is still struggling."
Among other carmakers, November sales at BMW rose 25 percent from November of last year and are up 18 percent for the first 11 months of this year compared with the period last year. Honda sales rose 4.6 percent for November. Toyota sales fell 5.2 percent, but the company has gained more than half a percentage point of market share in the United States this year, according to the Autodata Corporation, a data and research firm. 
Sales at Chrysler, which put heavy incentives on its midsize S.U.V.'s, declined 12 percent for November, while sales at Mercedes rose 7.5 percent. Both companies are units of DaimlerChrysler. Daimler stock fell 5.1 percent, or $1.82, to $33.75. 
Industry sales did improve from October, which had a seasonally adjusted annual selling rate of 15.4 million units, the lowest level in more than four years. Last month, sales recovered to a rate of approximately 16 million units.
Analysts said the wild swings in Ford stock in recent weeks, and to a lesser extent in G.M. shares, had probably been influenced by hedge funds, private investment pools that cater to the wealthy. Many hedge fund managers seek out volatile stocks and look to profit by making big bets on short-term gyrations. The activity of such investors, analysts said, has probably been amplified because more traditional investors, including individuals and mutual funds, have not been investing in automotive stocks.
Ford stock hit a 10-year low of $6.90 in October but had gained 66 percent from that low point when the market closed on Monday, before shares tumbled today.
While Ford cut its production, G.M., with a smaller inventory, said it would increase output in the fourth quarter and in 2003. A marketing and incentive push is expected as G.M. tries to raise December sales enough to have a second consecutive year of increased market share -- something G.M. has not achieved since the 1970's.
"We are still targeting a slight increase in this calendar year," said Paul Ballew, G.M.'s chief industry sales analyst. "It's going to require us to pick up the pace in December." 
Through November, G.M. had sold about 4.54 million cars and light trucks -- S.U.V.'s, pickups and minivans -- compared with about 4.39 million a year earlier, according to the Autodata Corporation. 
G.M. also said today that Rick Wagoner, its chief executive, would add the title of chairman when the current chairman, John F. Smith Jr., retires in May. The moves had been expected. Mr. Smith, 64, came to power after a boardroom coup in 1992, and Mr. Wagoner, 49, has risen through the ranks as his top protege. While G.M. was widely criticized for much of the 1990's for its sinking market share and for products deemed boring, in the last couple of years the work of Mr. Smith and Mr. Wagoner, who took over for Mr. Smith as chief executive in 2000, has been looked upon more favorably. 
Most analysts say that G.M. has far greater manufacturing efficiencies than Ford and, with idiosyncratic products like Hummers and Cadillac Escalades, has cast off some of the blandness that once characterized its lineup. 
Mr. Wagoner faces several challenges.
First, Detroit continues to spend thousands of dollars a vehicle on incentive deals like interest-free financing, but there are indications that consumers are starting to treat the Big Three's 14-month-old price war as part of the normal landscape instead of as a special event. Second, a softening in sales has dealerships brimming with extra inventory. Third, industry sales are expected to soften next year while competition increases. Fourth, G.M., as well as Ford, faces a huge disparity compared with foreign rivals because of pension and health care costs. Fifth, imports continue to maintain strong sales with lesser incentives because they have better reputations for quality and desirability. 
"My priorities are clear," Mr. Wagoner said. "We'll continue to bring out 'gotta have' products, compete aggressively in the marketplace, and drive quality and cost improvements, while we work to strengthen our balance sheet."

HEADLINE: Bush to End Rule Allowing Jobless Money for New Parents 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 

 BODY:
The Bush administration will repeal a Clinton-era rule that allows states to use unemployment insurance money to help people who take a leave from work to have babies or adopt children, officials said today.
 The executive action will effectively shut down legislative efforts in as many as 16 states to make unemployment compensation money available to working parents who have taken time off to care for a newborn or adopted child. 
 The move prompted an outcry among family rights advocates and women's groups, but was welcomed by business groups that had opposed the rule since President Bill Clinton approved it in June 2000. 
The Labor Department said the repeal was necessary because the economic slowdown since the Sept. 11 attacks had depleted state unemployment trust funds, leaving 28 states with less than 12 months of benefits in reserve. Officials said, moreover, that the Clinton rule, which has not been put into effect by any state, would allow for claims that Congress never intended to finance.
"Our first priority is to help laid-off workers and their families, and this new measure strengthens their safety net," said Emily Stover DeRocco, the assistant secretary of labor for employment and training. 
Ms. DeRocco said states had demonstrated their concern about dwindling reserves by refusing to activate the rule, which she called an experiment. Only the Massachusetts Legislature approved the use of unemployment money for family leave purposes, but the measure was vetoed by Gov. Paul Cellucci, a Republican.
Advocates of the rule voiced dismay and accused the administration of forcing new parents to choose between being responsible workers and responsible parents.
"It's outrageous," said Judith L. Lichtman, president of the National Partnership for Women and Families. "It's just a slap in the face to working people."
Ms. Lichtman said the rule affecting unemployment money was a creative successor to the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993, which entitles employees of large companies to 12 weeks of unpaid leave to care for newborn children or sick relatives or tend to their own health problems.
"All this regulation did was, for the first time, give states the option to use" the unemployment money to cover wages lost when parents took leave, she said.
Business groups have fought the rule for two years, saying it amounts to a new tax on employers. Citing estimates that as many as 1.9 million working women might be eligible for such benefits, the United States Chamber of Commerce and the National Association of Manufacturers charged that states' unemployment insurance costs could increase by as much as 20 percent.

HEADLINE: Bush Restoring Cash Bonuses For Appointees 

BYLINE:  By ERIC LICHTBLAU 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 

 BODY:
The White House has decided that several thousand political appointees across the federal government will be eligible for cash bonuses, abandoning a Clinton-era prohibition that grew out of questionable practices in the first Bush administration.
 Administration officials said the policy shift, ordered by the White House chief of staff, Andrew H. Card Jr., earlier this year but never publicly disclosed, seeks to correct the inequity of political appointees' working side by side with civil servants who routinely receive bonuses. 
 The new policy is being instituted at many federal departments, and a few agencies have already begun distributing awards of several thousand dollars each to political appointees. For example, the Justice Department has given bonuses to political appointees who were deemed to have played important roles in counterterrorism and the Sept. 11 investigation, officials said.
The policy is causing rumblings of discontent from some career officials. They say the policy threatens to reward employees for political loyalty and could force career civil servants to compete against well-connected political appointees for the millions of dollars in bonus money that their bosses distribute each year. The Bush administration did not help matters last week with the announcement that it was setting pay increases for career federal employees below what Congress was seeking. 
An Oct. 8 Justice Department memorandum explaining how the bonuses will be distributed within the department says that awards for political appointees "will be limited to truly outstanding performance that contributes directly to achieving the president's and the attorney general's national goals and objectives." 
For the first time in eight years, cabinet-level officials and agency chiefs have been authorized to approve annual awards of up to $10,000 -- and possibly more -- for the influential senior attorneys, policy advisers, confidential assistants and other appointees who are brought onto their political staffs. Awards can total $25,000 -- or higher with approval from the White House. Senior political appointees typically earn from $115,000 to $140,000 a year.
Mr. Card said in a previously undisclosed March 29 memorandum to cabinet secretaries and agency chiefs that he wanted to reward "substantial work achievements that go well beyond the performance of routine duties."
"Political employees should be judged and rewarded in the same manner as career employees," the memorandum said. 
Mr. Bush's aides say the White House policy shift reflects the administration's emphasis on a "results-oriented government," rewarding excellence and productivity by all federal employees.
Critics, however, say they see the potential for abuse.
"I think it's a dangerous precedent to establish," said Leon E. Panetta, a White House chief of staff under President Bill Clinton. "If you start giving cash awards to political appointees, it can be abused by handing out cash because someone's doing a good job politically or just knows the right people." 
In 1994, Mr. Panetta prohibited bonuses to senior political appointees after negative publicity surrounding bonuses given out in the waning days of the administration of President George Bush.
Among more than $100,000 in awards that Attorney General William Barr approved in January 1993, in his final weeks in office, were $7,500 bonuses to two of his closest political aides, who then went on to join him at the Washington law firm where he was a partner. 
Mr. Panetta's restrictions caused years of frustrations for some senior political appointees who were restrained from rewarding political appointees who worked under them.
"I was giving out bonuses for career people and not giving bonuses to political staff who often worked a lot harder than the career people did," a former Justice Department official recalled. "It was frustrating."
But some departments have found ways to skirt the restrictions.
Congressional investigators at the General Accounting Office found last year that several hundred political appointees received performance bonuses of as much as $17,000 from September 1999 to April 2001, apparently in violation of the 1994 policy. In 15 cases, political appointees had to give the money back because the payments violated a separate law banning bonuses to political appointees during a blackout period surrounding presidential elections.
The new White House bonus policy affects political appointees in two categories: noncareer Senior Executive Service officials, who fall just below presidential appointees in rank, and Schedule C employees, who are lower-ranking and lower-paid. They totaled at least 1,935 political appointees as of the most recent federal count.
Although political appointees make up only a tiny fraction of the 1.7 million federal work force, they often wield extensive influence at the highest reaches of government.
In setting the schedules and agendas of cabinet members, guiding political strategy and rendering legal opinions and policy advice, political appointees often play a critical behind-the-scenes role -- sometimes to the consternation of career employees who view them as "short-timers" who are rewarded for their connections.
Schedule C appointees will be eligible for performance awards, while Senior Executive Service appointees will be eligible for cash awards "based on contributions to government economy, efficiency or effectiveness," though not for straight performance bonuses, Mr. Card's memorandum said.
"Due the sensitivity of this parity issue," Mr. Card added in the memorandum, cabinet secretaries and agency chiefs should review all awards for their political appointees.
Mr. Card required top-level review to ensure "that political appointees are not getting any special treatment," a White House spokesman, Scott McClellan, said.
Political appointees will continue to be ineligible for cash or time-off awards in the eight months surrounding presidential elections, Mr. Card noted in his memorandum.
Presidential appointees -- cabinet secretaries, agency chiefs and senior deputies whose confirmations must go before the Senate -- are still exempted from bonuses. Congress operates under a separate system, with individual members given discretion to award bonuses to their own staff members.
The White House directed departments to move ahead with the new awards policy on their own, and that has led to a somewhat disjointed implementation. The Justice Department and the Department of Housing and Urban Development, for instance, have already begun distributing awards of several thousand dollars each to some political appointees in recent weeks, officials said. 
At many other departments, however, officials are still developing the criteria and, in some cases, are planning stricter standards than the White House suggested. The Environmental Protection Agency, for example, plans to require that political appointees be on the job at least a year to be eligible for an award.
At still other departments, officials plan to continue the ban on political bonuses. 
Some career officials and good-government advocates said they were concerned by what apparently was a lack of oversight, direction or public and Congressional discussion surrounding a policy change with broad ramifications.
"If done well, this change can be a smart way to connect performance to rewards," said Max Stier, president of Partnership for Public Service, a nonprofit group that promotes federal civil service work. 
"But obviously you need a system that's going to be viewed as fair, and to do that, you need the data to know what's happening and to know that expectations are being met," Mr. Stier said.
Some career officials said that what the White House saw as a move to reward strong performances may be seen instead as another slap at civil servants.
The Bush administration has moved in recent weeks to place as many as 850,000 government jobs up for competition from private contractors. On Friday, the White House announced that the raise for federal civil servants next year would be 3.1 percent, lower than the 4.1 percent sought by Congress.
The administration's effort to reward political appointees threatens to increase tensions, particularly because civil servants will apparently be competing with appointees for the limited bonus pools, some civil service advocates said. Administration officials said no extra money was planned to pay for the political bonuses.

HEADLINE: Win One Like the Gipper 

BYLINE:  By MAUREEN DOWD; E-mail: liberties@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Bill Clinton, the president who used to ape Ronald Reagan, told Democrats yesterday what they must do to take on George W. Bush, the president who now apes Ronald Reagan.
 They've got to get the Gipper swagger. 
 "When people are feeling insecure," a ruddy Mr. Clinton instructed a Democratic Leadership Council meeting at New York University, "they'd rather have someone who is strong and wrong rather than somebody who is weak and right." 
Democrats have been turned into eunuchs by the warlike Bushies. Some are skittering left. Some are skittering right. Most are just cowering behind the barn hiding from Sheriff Bush and his gimlet-eyed, sharp-shootin' sidekick, Karl Rove.
Mr. Clinton, who was always adept at purloining anything he fancied from Republicans, told Democrats flatly that they could not "wilt" on national security or whine about their identity crisis. (Though, being Bill Clinton, he laced his speech with whining about how his presidency was underappreciated.)
"I think you ought to be optimistic," he told the pessimistic Democrats, "and I think you ought to be strong. Of course it is hard."
He broke presidential club etiquette to say that Mr. Bush had things backward. "Al Qaeda should be our top priority," he said. "Iraq is important, but the terrorist network is more of a threat to our security."
He said that the Bush administration had missed 9/11 clues: "There are a couple of thousand flight schools in America. It wouldn't have been that hard to check them all." One of the men who flew an airplane into the World Trade Center had 30 credit cards and a quarter-million-dollar debt, he said, and Mohamed Atta had 12 addresses. Those were signs they were "up to no good."
(Though, being Bill Clinton, he didn't mention that his preoccupation with the Monica threat to his future might have diluted his focus on the Qaeda threat to our future.) 
The D.L.C. was on board with him. Al From, the head of the group, and Bruce Reed, the former Clinton White House policy chief, put out a memo on Monday that pretty much suggested that Democrats become an annex of the Republican Party.
Running away from Nancy Pelosi and jumping into Lynne Cheney's lap, the memo warned that if Democrats continue to come across as counterculture wimps on terrorism, they are doomed.
"Close the cultural gap that, left unchecked, will give Republicans back a virtual lock on the Electoral College . . .," Mr. From and Mr. Reed exhorted. "Half that battle is simply respecting the values of mainstream America in the first place. We will never be the party that loves guns most, but we can respect law-abiding citizens' rights to own them. We will never be the pro-life party, but we can show that we want abortion to be rare as well as legal."
Why not push for Clarence Thomas as chief justice and declare global warming a hoax? 
When Mr. Clinton was president, his attitude was "Le parti, c'est moi." And even though most of the Democrats he campaigned for in the midterms tanked, Democrats still expect Mr. Clinton to get them out of this horrible fix -- his specialty.
The prince of Harlem is one of the few who can raise money -- even though that role evokes his tatty past, renting out the Lincoln Bedroom, and his tabloid present, raking bucks and hanging with Hollywood stars.
Democrats continue to have an ambivalent relationship with Bill, missing his way with words and votes and the economy, but resentful that he put Terry McAuliffe in charge.
As the Democratic Ken doll John Edwards flew off to Europe to meet with NATO officials -- the CliffsNotes version of foreign policy credentials -- John Kerry tried to shed his Ken-doll skin with a big speech in Cleveland, following his announcement that he's running.
In the Q and A afterward, Mr. Kerry finally came out and said what the timid Democrats have been whispering for months: that the administration cooked up the Iraq crisis to distract everybody from a bad economy and an unpopular domestic agenda.
"They sat down in August and made a conscious decision to bring that up and to dominate the discussion with Iraq," Mr. Kerry said.
As Democratic swagger goes, it was a good start.

HEADLINE: Mayor Says Tax Rise Has Helped Balance Current Budget 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the 18.5 percent increase in the city's property tax rate and new budget cuts had balanced the city's budget this fiscal year and put it on track to close about half of its projected $6.4 billion budget gap next year.
 But if the city's budget glass is half full, it is still half empty. Mr. Bloomberg's plan to close the rest of next year's budget gap relies on savings and revenue that would require the cooperation of the state, the federal government and the unions. 
 The tax increase and the budget cuts should leave the city with a surplus of roughly $500 million when this fiscal year ends on June 30. The property tax increase will give the city an additional $1.7 billion next year. And officials say that the mayor is counting on $1.1 billion in departmental savings next year, including some recurring cuts that were put in place this year and some cuts that will need City Council approval.
Together, those measures should fill about $3.3 billion of next year's projected $6.4 billion gap. Mr. Bloomberg said yesterday that his estimates of how the city's economy would perform in the rest of this year, and how much money the city would therefore collect in taxes, were "on the realistic but conservative side." If they proved conservative, the city could end the year with an even larger budget surplus.
But the projected gap of more than $3 billion that remains in the fiscal year beginning July 1 is still formidable, and many of the mayor's proposals for closing it are beyond the city's control. It was the city's dependence on outside sources -- especially on Albany -- that factored into Standard & Poor's decision last week to change its assessment of the city's fiscal outlook to negative from stable.
To raise $1 billion -- and close a third of the remaining gap -- the mayor wants to tax commuters who live outside the city. His plan calls for lowering the income tax on city residents but charging the same rate to commuters. But Gov. George E. Pataki and Republicans in the State Senate, whose approval would be needed to enact the tax change, have so far said that they do not support the plan. 
The mayor has been asked several times recently whether he will raise the personal income tax on city residents if Albany formally rejects his proposal on the commuter tax. He usually replies indirectly, saying only that the law requires him to balance the budget.
Asked yesterday at a news conference at Federal Hall in Lower Manhattan whether he would consider a temporary surcharge on the income tax on city residents, Mr. Bloomberg said: "Well I think that everybody would like to be able to look the public in the eye and say we're cutting taxes. In boom times, that's possible."
Speaking earlier yesterday at an awards breakfast, the mayor told diners, "I can guarantee that everyone in this room is going to have to dig deeper into their pockets because we are going to have to tax everybody more." Aides said later that he was referring to the property tax increase and possibly the commuter tax.

HEADLINE: Tension Mounts Between United and Machinists 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG with STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 3 

 BODY:
Executives and union leaders of United Airlines stepped up their pressure on United's mechanics today, seeking their approval of a $700 million package of wage and benefit concessions that the airline says could help it avoid bankruptcy court.
 The mechanics' vote is scheduled for Thursday, and so much hostility toward management runs through the shop floors at United that many mechanics say the outcome is uncertain. If the mechanics reverse course from their vote a week ago and approve the concessions, many say, it will be by only a narrow margin. 
 United Airlines also announced plans today to lay off 220 pilots in early January and 132 in early February, reducing the total to about 8,250, and to cut senior management ranks by 18 percent, to 36 senior managers. Glenn F. Tilton, the chief executive, said that the remaining managers would take an average annual pay cut of 11 percent over the airline's planned five-and-a-half year recovery period and would forgo merit and incentive bonuses this year. The management savings would total more than $60 million, he said. 
Those announcements came as Mr. Tilton ratcheted up his own participation in the campaign to sway the votes of the mechanics. He signed a letter sent to every mechanic and then flew from United's headquarters here to San Francisco for meetings tonight and on Wednesday with workers at the airline's largest maintenance center -- and the one with the most militant machinists.
An agreement by the mechanics to take the concessions would give United, the nation's second-largest airline and a unit of the UAL Corporation, the final piece of a business plan it has presented to the federal government in an effort get $1.8 billion in federal loan guarantees. Rejection of the concessions would scuttle that plan and almost certainly any hope of getting the loan guarantees, possibly forcing United to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.
Last Wednesday, more than half of the airline's 13,000 mechanics turned out for a vote, and 57 percent of them rejected the wage and benefit concessions. After making some revisions on Sunday night to the concession package, the airline and union officials organized another vote for Thursday. There is now immense pressure for the mechanics -- from executives, from the union leaders, from pilots and flight attendants -- to reverse their earlier decision. 
Many mechanics are wary. 
"I've got the fear in me that they'll file for Chapter 11 no matter what we do," said Joe Schwirian, a mechanic for 17 years in San Francisco who voted against the concessions the first time. "I think it's in their game plan to do that. They gain too much from filing for Chapter 11 -- they can close bases or do other things to skirt the contract."
But Mr. Schwirian's car-pool colleague, Charlie Lincoln, a lead mechanic and shop steward, had a different take on the situation. "My vote was a 'yes' originally," he said, "because what bankruptcy means to us contractually is not a good thing. The membership who voted 'no' is just angry at the company. They're voting out of anger and not knowing the facts."
That anger -- present even among many mechanics who voted for the concessions -- burns as hot as the engines that these workers maintain. 
It is anger at the fact that they agreed in 1994 to a deep wage cut with no raises for six years, in exchange for stock options that are relatively worthless today. It is anger arising from what they call wasteful management decisions, like United's recently failed attempt to buy US Airways, and executive compensation, like the $3 million signing bonus Mr. Tilton received in September. And it is anger raised by the steady prodding of a rival union -- the Aircraft Mechanics Fraternal Association -- that has repeatedly tried to take over representation of the workers.
In fact, many mechanics say the vote last Wednesday was as much an expression of dissatisfaction toward their current union -- the International Association of Machinists -- as it was a slap at United's management.
"I am not a union hater but they give us no information," said Kenneth Epps, a 43-year-old turbine mechanic in San Francisco who said he planned to vote against concessions on Thursday. "A lot of mechanics don't trust our employer and a lot of folks don't trust the union. Voting no is a no vote to the union and a no vote to the company."
United executives tried to sweeten the concession package by agreeing on Sunday to slightly alter a measure on unpaid vacation days, as well as promising to try to resolve workplace issues. 
Conditions that have made mechanics irate include the starting times of swing shifts, the outsourcing of work to other companies and what the disgruntled call the ineptitude of floor supervisors and middle management. Many mechanics have long demanded that a system be put in place where they can voice their complaints.
"Part of it is the machinists tend to have more of a conflict with management than the other unions," said John W. Budd, a professor of industrial relations at the University of Minnesota. "The pilots are up in the air; the flight attendants are up in the air. They can do what needs to be done. But the machinists are on the ground. There's a huge potential for management to be looking over their shoulder."
The relationship that the mechanics have with their supervisors varies widely by workplace. This was indicated by the radically different ways that votes turned out last week at some of the largest bases. In San Francisco and in Indianapolis, the second-largest site in number of mechanics, workers voted by almost 2-to-1 to reject the concessions. At Denver, workers voted by 57 percent in favor of the concessions.
"I'm cautiously optimistic that this will pass," said Steve Adams, secretary-treasurer of the Denver local, which has about 1,000 members eligible to vote. "But they are going to bellyache all the way to the ballot box."
Some mechanics and union officials who support the concessions say the outcome on Thursday could mirror what took place at US Airways this fall. That airline, which filed for bankruptcy in August, had asked the machinists for further concessions, which the leaders agreed to but the membership rejected by 57 percent in a vote on Aug. 28. Three weeks later, the union held a second vote after David N. Siegel, the chief executive of US Airways, said that the airline was in worse shape than he had previously indicated, and the concessions were passed.
But what is now happening at US Airways could also encourage the United mechanics to take a firm stand against concessions. Just three days before the first vote at United, US Airways announced further layoffs of 2,500 workers, with 450 of those coming from the ranks of the mechanics. That raised the ire of mechanics at United, several of them said.
The United mechanics also still talk about the business decisions that management made that led to the company's bleeding cash: the attempted buyout of US Airways that was blocked in July 2001 by the Justice Department; the failed attempt to create a business jet division called Avolar; and the seeming lack of a coherent business plan for coping with the economic downturn of the last couple years. 
What is more, the labor groups were promised by Gerald M. Greenwald, the UAL chief executive who oversaw the employee stock option plan from 1995 to 1999, that they would never work without a contract again. That promise turned out to be hollow, and the mechanics watched in frustration as their contract expired in July 2000 without a deal. 
"They feel that since July of 2000, they have been disrespected and abused," said Scotty Ford, president of the union local that represents United mechanics. "I have got all the people who work for me working the properties, trying to impress on them the seriousness of the situation, trying to convince them that the need is real."
It was not until March 2002 that the mechanics got a contract granting them their first raise since 1994. Mechanics also have other bitter memories from the autumn of 2000, when United accused the machinists of staging a work slowdown and got a court injunction against them.
And in the middle of negotiations for that contract, the Aircraft Mechanics Fraternal Association tried to take over representation of the mechanics. Many United mechanics are now lobbying in favor of that union, which argues that it more ably represents mechanics because it does not have other labor groups as members. 
The Aircraft Mechanics have set up a phone message hot line to United workers saying: "It is not our labor costs behind the crisis at United or the airlines. It is greed and arrogant management. If we give concessions today, they will demand more blood tomorrow."

HEADLINE: Canada's 5 Big Banks Are a Study in Contrast 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Dec. 4 

 BODY:
Customers of Canada's five big banks in other words, most Canadians -- tend to view the institutions as interchangeable monoliths, with branches from coast to coast selling a full array of corporate and personal financial services and earning ever-rising profits.
 Yet the contrasts among the banks -- in descending order of size they are Royal Bank of Canada, Scotiabank, the TD Bank Financial Group, Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce and Bank of Montreal -- have seldom been starker than over the last two weeks as they have reported results for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31. 
 Much of that contrast arises from their divergent approaches to a common question: how to grow beyond Canada's borders, especially in the United States.
"It used to be that our banks were the department stores of the financial services business," said Raymond Protti, president of the Canadian Bankers Association. But, he added, "going forward, we're going to see some marked differentiation in the strategies." 
Royal Bank reported record earnings equivalent to $1.86 billion for fiscal 2002. "We performed strongly this year against almost all of our objectives," Gordon M. Nixon, the group's chief executive, told the bank's shareholders. Accordingly, Royal Bank's stock rose 16 percent during the period, while bank stocks as a group have been stagnant.
On the other hand, TD reported the first annual loss in its history, and Canadian Imperial's profits shrank by almost two-thirds. "It has been a disappointing year for our shareholders," A. Charles Baillie, TD's chairman and chief executive, acknowledged in announcing the loss. Mr. Baillie, who announced in October that he would retire as chief executive on Dec. 20, said last week that he would also give up the chairmanship next April, a year early.
Bank of Montreal's earnings for the last financial year, at $910 million, were roughly unchanged from the year before. Scotiabank, the last of the five to report, said on Tuesday that its earnings fell 17 percent, to $1.15 billion, after writing down its investment in Argentina by $345 million.
Some two-thirds of all Canadians have accounts at one or more of the big five banks, according to recent surveys by the government, and only about 29 percent of people say they comparison shop for banking services. "For consumers, all mortgages and personal loans seem alike," said Martin Pacheco, head of consumer education at the government's Financial Consumer Agency, which conducted the surveys.
The trouble for the banks is that the home market is saturated, and the outlook for domestic earnings growth is lackluster.
Bank of Montreal said in a recent study that "profit margins are lower in Canada than in many other countries, suggesting that there are more profitable places to expand." According to Sachin Kewalramani, an analyst at Morgan Stanley in New York, the Canadian banks as a group face a period of "modest" earnings growth, with slower loan growth, rising loan write-downs and "challenging" capital markets.
To find better opportunities, the banks have increasingly looked south. Mr. Protti said that the American market was "the primary engine of growth" for Canadian banks. 
"This integration of North America is the new economic reality in which all of us -- businesses, government and consumers -- must operate," he said. Since 1996, the five big Canadian banks have spent about $8.33 billion on acquisitions south of the border. But they have chosen different businesses as targets.
Two once-promising avenues that TD, once known as the Toronto Dominion Bank, pursued in the late 1990's have brought it grief in recent years. The bank became a major player in the discount stock brokerage business when it bought Waterhouse in 1996; stock trading is no longer nearly so lucrative.
It was also among the most active lenders to the telecommunications, technology and electric power industries. Write-downs on loans to these sectors soared to $188 billion in fiscal 2002 from $390 million a year earlier and were the driving force behind the bank's loss.
Canadian Imperial's thrust into the United States has been through its investment banking arm, CIBC World Markets, and through an ambitious but costly venture to provide electronic consumer banking services in partnership with supermarket chains. The bank said last month that it would close the venture, known as Amicus, and take a $146 million charge.
Royal Bank's expansion strategy has focused on more stable retail banking businesses. Its recent acquisitions in the United States, chiefly Centura Banks of Rocky Mount, N.C., in mid-2001, yielded 21 percent of Royal's total revenue and some $146 million in profit for the latest fiscal year. The Centura unit in turn gained a toehold in Florida in August by paying $150 million for Admiralty Bancorp of Palm Beach Gardens.
The banks say that a chief stumbling block to continued expansion in the United States has been Canadian officials' refusal to allow them to grow any bigger at home through mergers or acquisitions. "The big issue is one of scale," Mr. Protti said.
In 1998, the government blocked two deals -- a bid by Royal Bank bid to take over the Bank of Montreal and a proposed merger of Canadian Imperial and TD. According to reports in the Canadian news media, a more recent proposal to combine Scotiabank and Bank of Montreal was blocked by the prime minister, Jean Chretien.
Many Canadians fear that if the five banks, which are among the country's largest businesses of any kind, are allowed to become any bigger at home, they they will have free rein to raise service fees, close branches and lay off workers. One bank analyst said, "The politicians need to be convinced that there's some advantage to letting the banks merge."
Hoping to shift public opinion their way, the chief executives of all five major banks appeared before a parliamentary committee in Ottawa last month to argue in favor of allowing domestic mergers.
Mr. Nixon of Royal Bank told the committee that "increased scale is important for the continued health and development of our industry, both in Canada and increasingly in a North American market."

HEADLINE: The Holiday Card, Set in Motion 

BYLINE:  By KATIE HAFNER

 BODY:
THE holiday movie season is approaching, and Keith Whitmer's production studio is shifting into high gear. Mr. Whitmer sits for hours in a room in Manhattan viewing scenes accumulated from a year of shooting, then more hours putting a movie together. 
 Mr. Whitmer is not an independent filmmaker. He is burning video CD's in his apartment to send as Christmas gifts to far-flung relatives -- his parents and sister in California and his brother in Atlanta. 
 And with December's arrival, Mr. Whitmer and his wife, Jayne, are in production overdrive. Mr. Whitmer tackles the video side of things, while Ms. Whitmer takes on the stills. More often than not, the production centers on their 3-year-old daughter, Olivia. 
 The Whitmers are part of a growing contingent of audiovisual hobbyists for whom the holidays simply are not the holidays unless the memories of the year have been fully digitized and the holidays themselves have been shot and reshot, edited and re-edited, viewed and reviewed, posted to a Web site or sent out as e-mail or CD-ROM's or even DVD's to relatives and friends. 
 The Consumer Electronics Association, a trade group, estimates that nearly nine million digital cameras will be sold in 2002 in the United States, a 62 percent increase over last year. The group predicts that some 2.3 million digital camcorders will be sold this year, a 35 percent rise from 2001.
 Not everyone will use those gadgets to provide the raw material for a digital production to mark the holidays or other event. But those that do will often put a tremendous amount of work into their projects, sometimes weeks spent viewing, sifting, editing, and choosing and adding music and other effects. Yet many amateur film producers welcome the distraction from other demands. 
 And it's nothing like it used to be. As a teenager, Mr. Whitmer made movies with 8-millimeter film. "It was quite a long process," he said. "The equipment was very bulky -- splicing, taping, winding, setting up the projector and the screen." Mr. Whitmer even recorded music on a portable cassette player and tried to synchronize the recording to the film. 
 "It took forever to get the timing right," he said. "Now I do all of this on the Mac and burn a CD, and let everyone else use their computer as projector and screen." 
 It isn't usually until after he has finished that Mr. Whitmer, 45, who is creative director of a small advertising firm in Manhattan that he and Ms. Whitmer own, notices the amount of time he spent. "It goes by quickly because you're so focused on it," he said. 
 Besides, Mr. Whitmer said, it hardly feels like work. "It's more a labor of love, because you have the people in mind that you're making it for," he said.
 Mr. Whitmer's theme for Christmas 2001 was the Terrible Twos. The film was about five minutes long, "an eternity when you are talking about a video on a computer screen," he said. The five minutes were culled from about four hours of tape. 
 For the sequel this year, Mr. Whitmer is still in the concept stage, but he is considering using David Bowie's song "Changes" to produce a short piece about how much Olivia has changed in a year and how much life has changed as a response to her needs. 
 Ms. Whitmer, 42, provides the analog reinforcement, shooting stills with her film camera. Once the holidays approach, she goes from one roll a week to two. She scans the pictures, crops them, prints them out and makes photo albums to send as gifts. 
 The time spent on holiday productions is certainly impressive. 
 "People can't possibly know how much work goes into it," Mr. Whitmer said. "It's like sending a hand-knitted sweater." 
 And just as one gift sweater can give the knitter quite a reputation among family and friends, so too can one digital production cause expectations to rise. That's what happened to Ed Seidel, an associate curator at the Monterey Bay Aquarium in Monterey, Calif., who now finds himself in something of an expectation rut. 
 Ever since he made a digital slide show for his uncle's 60th birthday, it is expected that he will do the same for other major birthdays -- his grandmother's 90th, his brother's 35th. 
 Mr. Seidel, 36, also makes frequent short videos and posts them on the family's Web site. During the holidays, the site receives particularly close attention, especially if Mr. Seidel and his wife cannot be with family members on the East Coast. In that case, Mr. Seidel updates the site almost daily for several days. 
 Two years ago, when he was unable to be with his family in Maine for Christmas, he created a video postcard from California of his family sending greetings and posted it on a Web site. "The whole Maine family, all 25 of them, sat around the computer and watched it over and over," he said. 
 Mr. Seidel knows that producing digital movies and maintaining the family Web site can be time-consuming, so he has learned to save time by using his digital camera, which is limited to 30-second video segments. "It's already compressed," he said, "which makes it easy to put it up on the Web and share with people." Unlike Mr. Whitmer, Mr. Seidel didn't catch the videography bug until he bought an Apple iMac computer in 1999 and saw that the tools made the job enticingly easy -- time-consuming but enjoyable. 
 Mr. Seidel has found himself cast in the role of digital producer for his entire extended family, who often provide him with raw material, like old photos and slides. "They don't know how to scan, but they do know how to go through old drawers," he said. 
 In addition to the videos, Mr. Seidel usually makes holiday cards using Photoshop and other programs, then sends them out by postal mail. 
 Charlie Couch also sees his holidays through the lens of his digital camera. Mr. Couch, a 39-year-old sales manager at AT&T Wireless in San Francisco, has always enjoyed taking pictures, but when he started using a digital camera nearly three years ago, he became a devotee. With the holidays approaching, he is seldom without the camera. 
 For Mr. Couch, the holiday photography season starts around Halloween and reaches a height at Christmas, which he refers to as the Super Bowl of his photo year. By his calculation, he already has tens of thousands of digital images stored in his computer, many of them centered on holidays. 
 Mr. Couch said the technology had changed his habits considerably. He has just begun shooting pictures from a wireless phone and sending them by e-mail. "There is something about capturing an image and being able to tell a story with a fixed image," he said. 
 This year for the first time, Mr. Couch and his wife are e-mailing digital Christmas cards, featuring a shot of their two children.
 Mr. Couch waxes particularly sentimental when talking about the moments he captures electronically. "In today's economy and today's times you can lose touch with the important things in life," he said, "and this brings me back to that." 
 This holiday season is an especially poignant one for Sharon Emerson, a 33-year-old studio director for a small company in Chicago that makes games for the Web. 
 She is currently hard at work making a CD -- her first such gift -- for relatives that will largely be a memorial to her Latvian grandmother, who died last year. For the CD, which is structured as a large family tree, Ms. Emerson has gathered old 8-millimeter film that includes movies of her father's prom in 1958 and her parents' wedding in 1963, and a video tour that Ms. Emerson's grandmother gave of her apartment before she died. "I especially loved her pink bathroom," Ms. Emerson said. 
 Ms. Emerson's project began as a Web site, but when the videos began to stack up, she switched media. The CD will also include her grandmother's favorite recipes and digital versions of old letters. 
 Like others, Ms. Emerson finds that the technology has changed her ideas about what constitutes the perfect gift. "Ten years ago, I just would have distributed cool photos I dug up of my family, or created elaborate frames for pictures," she said. "Now, with a CD burner, I can wrap everything up in a nice package." 
 It was the relative ease with which the old videotape can be transferred to a CD that motivated her. "I've been sitting on those 8-millimeter films for years," she said. "So technology has absolutely allowed me to create this gift for my family." 
 Ms. Emerson plans to send the CD out to five family members. "I don't want just a map of names," Ms. Emerson said. "I want something where generations beyond me can get a feel for who these people are." 
 Even the most fanatic of holiday filmmakers recognize that there are limits. The Whitmers are on a campaign to reduce the stress in their lives, which means that Mr. Whitmer might not finish the movie in time to send it as a Christmas gift. In that case, he said, refusing to fret, he will make the best of it: he will end the movie with holiday scenes and send it out in time for Groundhog Day.

PERSON: Willa Appel 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
The Organizer in a Mission to Salvage Lives

BYLINE:  By JOYCE WADLER

 BODY:
TIME was when New York researchers in structural biology had to travel across the country for access to the most sophisticated equipment, and the city was in danger of losing some of its top researchers.
 The New York Structural Biology Center, which opens Dec. 16, is already changing that. It has six of the latest generation of enormous nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometers, the machines that probe the structure of the body's proteins, making it the most advanced laboratory of its kind in the country. 
 What's also significant, according to Willa Appel, the center's chief operating officer, is the unprecedented coming together of nine universities and research hospitals, which pooled their economic resources to create the center. 
"It's not just a time share," she says, in her temporary office at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. "Researchers who don't know each other are finding that they are working on aspects of similar problems. We have all sorts of collaborations that are already coming out of this." 
Another topic: Should we refer to you as Dr., doctor?
A horrified look.
"No, no!" and "It's so pretentious" and "I'm not an M.D.; my degree is in anthropology," and again, "No!" 
Ms. Appel's skills are organizational. She came to this project from the New York City Partnership Policy Center, where she had been involved in promoting the economic sector. She declines to give her age. She has been an editorial writer at Newsday, a college professor, an author. For her 1983 book, "Cults in America," she listened to 1,000 hours of tapes recorded by the Rev. Jim Jones, including the night when more than 900 followers took cyanide, many by force. Tough stuff, she says; you could hear them screaming.
She's a witty woman, but funny comments are often followed by modifiers or disclaimers. Glib is nothing one wants to appear when fund-raising for a serious research organization.
She is not enchanted to know that a reporter knows she sent a singing telegram to Warren M. Anderson, back in 1985, when he was the Republican majority leader of the State Senate and she was the executive director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council. It was sung to the tune of "Button Up Your Overcoat." "Button up those housing funds. Call a session now. Float some Battery bonds, Warren, you know how." 
She is also discreet. Her work at the biology center has ranged from overseeing construction at the site on the City College campus at 133rd Street and Convent Avenue to working with lawyers from nine institutions. If there have been problems getting those nine institutions to play nicely together, Ms. Appel is not saying. 
She does say that she believes the research will change medicine and how people are treated, that it will lead to drugs that will prevent the development of cancer and Alzheimer's, which she calls "my particular bugaboo." 
Why Alzheimer's?
"Because my mother had it," Ms. Appel says. 
Then she speeds away from the subject so quickly that you see skid marks hanging in the air.
MS. APPEL grew up in Roosevelt, N.J. Her mother, Sophie, was a science teacher, her father, Benjamin, a novelist whose work included a book about the rise of a labor union, and later, one about the corruption of labor unions. 
"That won him a lot of friends," Ms. Appel says, under her breath.
Huh?
"Nothing."
She graduated from the University of Pittsburgh, magna cum laude, with a double major in anthropology and fine arts; taught at Sarah Lawrence College and Bard, with the notion that teaching would give her time to paint. Then she decided academia wasn't for her. 
The trigger?
"When I was at one of the colleges. . . ."
What? You're not going to say which one?
"The faculty met every month to discuss an issue. The issue was whether students should get letter grades. And every week it turned into a rip-roaring debate of the Weimar Republic." The softening addendum. "It stuck in my head as what was sort of charming about academia."
Let's talk about Mom. 
No go. Ms. Appel changes the subject twice.
"This is like a bad shrink session," she says.
So how did she know when her mother was sick?
"She couldn't get a meal together," Ms. Appel says finally. "She could make a meal for a million people. My father's relatives always came at the last minute, and in two hours she had pies baked, everything done."
Ultimately her mother had to go into a home, where Ms. Appel did volunteer work. She saw people who seemed "totally gone."
"There were people who couldn't speak, who were shouting guttural sounds," Ms. Appel says. She makes a clawing motion with her hand. "They would strike out like this. I was afraid to go near them. There was a woman, tied to a bed, we had to turn over. I was doing my idea of helping, patting her, making soothing noises. And at one point she grabbed my hand and she laid the most delicate kiss on it. And I realized that" -- a long pause here, for Ms. Appel is now emotional -- "I saw that there seemed to be people who are or seem to be totally gone who are not." 
And, on the researchers who will be focusing on Alzheimer's:
"I hope they'll hurry up and be successful."

HEADLINE: For One Day, Trades Line The Pockets Of Charities 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
At CIBC World Markets, the day started with an order to buy 500,000 shares of Microsoft at a cost of a little more than $28 million.
 The commission that trade generated -- the firm does not disclose its commission on individual sales -- and all the firm's other commissions yesterday will go to charities devoted to children. 
 Last year, the same philanthropic effort, known as Miracle Day, generated $16 million worldwide. When the trades are settled, this year's effort is expected to have raised even more, although the firm would not provide any estimates. 
"It's electric," said Eric Ribner, executive director of institutional sales at CIBC, part of the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce. "It's very exciting to be doing so much volume."
Wall Street has had a tough year. The markets have been brutal, layoffs continue, and the scandals have heightened investors' skepticism. "People from Wall Street get a bad rap, especially over the last few years," said Gregory Fortunoff, a partner in First New York Securities, a hedge fund. "This gives us a chance to show a different side."
Mr. Fortunoff said his firm had directed all its trades yesterday through CIBC, with half the commissions earmarked for the All Stars Project, a nonprofit group based in New York that runs after-school and other programs for children. CIBC will distribute the other half to the 675 nonprofit organizations registered to participate in Miracle Day; it picks up all administrative costs.
All Stars, which has a $5.3 million budget for this fiscal year, received about $37,000 last year from Miracle Day, or roughly 4 percent of its annual corporate contributions. "It's very significant for us," said Gabrielle Kurlander, president of All Stars.
This year, she said, the event had even more significance. "Sometimes when the going gets tough, corporate philanthropy will be the first type of philanthropy to be cut," she said. "In this terrible economic climate, when earnings are down and people are being laid off, that's when you really see what people are made of."
Miracle Day started in 1984 in Canada at the suggestion of a broker in a CIBC branch, and it raised 123,891 Canadian dollars. Since then, it has raised $60 million. 
This year, it got a plug from Stanley Druckenmiller, founder of Duquesne Capital Management and a former associate of George Soros, during a breakfast held by the Robin Hood Foundation, the philanthropy whose events are star-studded affairs that raise millions.
Tut-tutting, Mr. Druckenmiller noted that $3 million of the $12 million that CIBC raised in the United States last year came from trading in New York. "Are you kidding me -- or as Paul Jones would say, 'Come on!' " he said, mimicking the Southern accent of Robin Hood's founder, the hedge fund manager Paul Tudor Jones II. "We didn't even beat Boston. And don't forget to earmark your commissions for Robin Hood!"
Wall Street has learned that Miracle Day is painless philanthropy, too. "It's a great opportunity to take an activity we would be doing anyway on this day, which is trading securities, and do it in a way that benefits our clients and, ultimately, a lot of kids," said David F. Lamere, vice chairman of the Mellon Financial Corporation and president of its private wealth management group.
Mellon planned to do more trading with CIBC than usual, earmarking half of its commissions for Citizen Schools, a youth services organization based in Boston. "CIBC has come up with a very creative approach to get a group of people across the financial industry, who are on some days fierce competitors, behind an easy cause to support," Mr. Lamere said.
This year, CIBC's competitors agreed to "give up" to Miracle Day the commissions generated on any trades CIBC could not handle. "And that," said Peter Feinberg, a CIBC managing director and chairman of Miracle Day, "is a real miracle."

HEADLINE: Food Emergency in North Korea Worsens as Donations Dwindle 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 4 

 BODY:
Just as the United Nations begins an emergency appeal for $201 million to help feed almost one-third of North Korea's 22 million people this winter, donor fatigue has turned to donor anger.
 Last summer, donor fatigue and competition with Afghanistan caused donations for North Korea to dwindle to 70 percent of planned levels, forcing the United Nations' World Food Program to cut off about three million people from food rations. 
 As North Korea's food emergency enters its eighth year, donors agree that the nation's chronically skimpy crops are not a result of bad weather but of gross economic mismanagement by Communist officials. On top of that, the top three donor nations -- Japan, South Korea and the United States -- have had their gifts of food repaid with vitriol from the North Korean state news media. 
Then, two months ago, North Korea admitted to embarking on an expensive nuclear bomb program in the mid-1990's, at the same time that an estimated two million people, or 10 percent of the population, were starving to death. In recent weeks, after North Korea admitted to trying to make nuclear bombs and to kidnapping Japanese citizens, food donors pulled back.
Last week, after a Japanese charity shipped dog biscuits and old rice to help feed people in North Korea, Shintaro Ishihara, Tokyo's powerful governor, objected, saying, "What nerve they have, sending food while Japanese people are really angry over the abductions."
Although the food program has trimmed its annual North Korea appeal by 16 percent for 2003, to 512,000 tons, pledges total only 33,000, all from Europe, said James Morris, the program's executive director.
Rick Corsino, the program's country director for North Korea, said that unless more food entered the pipeline soon, "hundreds of thousands more face ration cuts early in 2003." City dwellers devote 85 percent of their incomes to food, while the government supplies only 45 percent of minimum caloric needs, according to the food program.
Japan, which donated 500,000 tons of food as recently as 2000, told Mr. Morris when he visited here two weeks ago that it had no plans to send more food aid. The United States, currently the largest donor, has said it met its pledge of 155,000 tons for 2002 and will not send additional shipments this month to keep feeding stations open. Washington is expected to renew its donations next year, but Bush administration officials have not said at what level.
Administration officials have said that relief aid will not be tied to North Korea's compliance with demands that it dismantle its nuclear bomb program. But they have demanded proof that the food reaches civilians, and not soldiers.
Indeed, verification of food deliveries is now a major issue among human rights activists, an increasingly powerful group in setting policies on North Korea in Japan, Europe and the United States.
"North Korea plays a blackmail game: feed me or I will blow up the world," said Norbert Vollertsen, a German doctor who was expelled from North Korea two years ago. "There are weapons inspectors for Iraq. Why not food inspectors for North Korea?"
North Korean defectors say food aid is routinely diverted to soldiers, government officials and families deemed loyal to the government. About 20 percent of North Korea's 206 counties are closed to outside monitors. To further hinder monitoring, North Korea generally refuses to give visas to Korean-speaking inspectors from overseas.

HEADLINE: Kerrey Debates His Students on Changing Iraqi Regime 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT F. WORTH

 BODY:
Two weeks ago, a group of students at New School University marched angrily into the offices of the university's president, Bob Kerrey, to demand that he address their complaints about his public call for regime change in Iraq.
 Yesterday, they got what they asked for. Hundreds of students and faculty members packed a university auditorium on West 12th Street to hear a raucous, often bitter debate in which Mr. Kerrey was accused of betraying the New School's pacifist legacy and miring the school in controversy. As the hourlong debate -- in which Mr. Kerrey and a former United Nations official faced two students -- came to an end early yesterday afternoon, a group of students held up signs calling for Mr. Kerrey to resign. 
 Mr. Kerrey, who became the school's president early last year after more than a decade as a United States senator, refused. During an eight-minute opening statement and a lengthy question-and-answer session, he vigorously defended his views and his right to make them public, saying it was consistent with the university's history of openness and debate. In a line that drew loud applause, Mr. Kerrey said he did not want "to set a precedent so this university begins to be led, like so many other universities in America, by presidents who are so concerned by fund-raising needs that they have no public opinion on anything that matters" to ordinary people.
Mr. Kerrey's student critics demanded a public forum in which they could challenge him after learning that he had joined a well-connected group of current and former political figures called the Committee for the Liberation of Iraq. He has also written and spoken about his support for ousting Saddam Hussein.
At times, the debate bordered on chaos, with students groaning and shouting others down after questioners maligned Mr. Kerrey's ethics or changed the subject to his controversial record as a soldier in Vietnam.
"I was a little upset with how the forum turned into a Kerrey-bashing session," Joanne Strasser, a first-year graduate student in liberal studies, said after the debate ended.
Mr. Kerrey maintained his composure throughout, although he seemed angry several times and once chastised one of the two students debating him as being too closed-minded.
Many campuses across the country have become hotbeds of protest against a war with Iraq recently. But the New School's students have been especially active, in part because of Mr. Kerrey's public stand. 
To Mr. Kerrey's critics, his advocacy for military engagement runs directly against the New School's tradition of pacifism and left-wing social theory. The university's graduate school became a refuge for European intellectuals during the Nazi era, including Hannah Arendt and Claude Levi-Strauss.
"It is unacceptable to me that you use the name of this school" in advocating for military action to oust Mr. Hussein, said Colin Walsh, one of the two students who debated Mr. Kerrey. He added that the school's founding scholars would have been outraged by Mr. Kerrey's position.
Another student argued that Mr. Kerrey and his peers on the Committee for the Liberation of Iraq were more interested in securing Iraqi oil reserves and "world domination" than in the suffering of the Iraqi people.
Mustapha Tlili, who sat on Mr. Kerrey's side of the table in the debate and is a fellow at the school's World Policy Institute, objected to the uniformly negative tone of the students' arguments. He said that Mr. Kerrey had played an important role in encouraging dialogue between Muslim figures and the West.
For his part, Mr. Kerrey argued that armed intervention had prevented additional violence from taking place in Bosnia, Cambodia and elsewhere.
Some students tried to link Mr. Kerrey's stand on Iraq to earlier controversies that have clouded his tenure as president. Last year, Mr. Kerrey was heavily criticized for his role in the massacre of a village by a platoon under his command during the Vietnam War.
Mr. Kerrey steered the discussion away from that and other questions about his tenure. But several students and faculty members said they were impressed with his performance.
"I think Kerrey was effective and the students were not," said Anwar Shaikh, a professor in the economics department who said he disagreed with Mr. Kerrey's views on Iraq.

HEADLINE: Powell Says U.S. Will Increase Military Aid for Colombia 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN R. WEISMAN 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 4 

 BODY:
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that the United States would increase military assistance to Colombia, asserting that its war on leftist guerrillas and rightist paramilitary groups -- and on their narcotics trafficking -- was part of the Bush administration's campaign against terrorism.
 The aid, more than $500 million a year, would be used for drug eradication, support for military and police forces and renewal of support for Colombian narcotics-interception flights that rely on intelligence from American spy planes. Such flights were suspended last year after a plane carrying missionaries was shot down over Peru. 
 The new aid will put Colombia roughly on a par with Afghanistan and Pakistan as a recipient of American military and antidrug assistance, administration officials said. 
In a one-day trip to this Andean capital city, Secretary Powell met with Colombia's new president, Alvaro Uribe Velez, who was elected last summer after pledging a crackdown on violent groups that rely on drug money for support. Mr. Uribe is also pressing for a more aggressive campaign of eradicating coca fields than his predecessors.
After more than three decades of civil war, various antigovernment groups engaged in the drug trade control most of Colombia's vast expanse of mountains and farm valleys. But rights groups have accused the Colombian military of fighting those forces with too much reliance on rightist military squads organized by landlords.
"We are firmly committed to President Uribe and his new national security strategy," Secretary Powell said. "We are going to work with our Congress to provide additional funding for Colombia."
In all, the United States has spent $1.8 billion on antinarcotics measures and military and law enforcement aid to Colombia since 2000. 
The administration is asking Congress for $537 million in the current fiscal year, up from $411 million last year, according to the ambassador to Colombia, Anne W. Patterson.
In a reflection of the American economic interests here, the requested sum includes nearly $100 million to help secure a 500-mile oil pipeline in eastern Colombia that transports 100,000 barrels a day for Occidental Petroleum of Los Angeles. Guerrilla groups have repeatedly attacked the pipeline.
Next year, the United States will have 60 of its own Special Operations forces and intelligence operatives to help train Colombian forces to guard the pipeline, Ambassador Patterson said. 
Secretary Powell, saying he would seek even more money in the next fiscal year, expressed satisfaction with his visit, which included a tour of narcotics eradication equipment at a military airport here. He said it had given him "ammunition" to persuade skeptics not only in Congress but also within the administration's budget office. "I am very impressed by what I have seen," he said after his tour.
Addressing the issue of terrorism within Colombia, the secretary said it no longer made sense to insist on separating it from the battle against narcotics, because they were linked as threats to democracy. Asked if he worried that America's involvement in Colombia might lead to a Vietnam-like quagmire, the secretary, who fought in Vietnam, said there was no comparison.
"I don't see this in Vietnam terms," he said, adding that Colombia's antigovernment groups should not be "romanticized" as "some sort of charming freedom fighters." He did add, however, that the helicopters being supplied by the United States were "remarkably familiar."
The secretary's visit, though brief, carried symbolism for a region increasingly beset by instability and eager for attention from the United States, which is seen here as preoccupied by its efforts against terrorism elsewhere. Indeed, Secretary Powell was supposed to have visited Colombia last year, but his visit was canceled because of the Sept. 11 attacks. Another visit was canceled earlier this year. 
Colombia's importance for the administration is underscored by its holding of the presidency of the United Nations Security Council, where Washington has sought its support for the campaign against Iraq. 
Secretary Powell said, however, that he had been unable to persuade Mr. Uribe to exempt Americans serving in Colombia from any human rights prosecutions by the International Criminal Court. The Bush administration, which has refused to join the court, has sought such exemptions from countries where Americans are serving.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Colin L. Powell with Colombia's president, Alvaro Uribe Velez. (Associated Press)
