HEADLINE: Boston Church Panel Will Allow Archdiocese to Weigh Bankruptcy 

BYLINE:  By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Dec. 4 

 BODY:
A finance panel of the Archdiocese of Boston voted today to allow the church to file for bankruptcy as a way of dealing with the hundreds of lawsuits it faces over sexual abuse by priests.
 The vote by the 15-member Finance Council, a panel on which Cardinal Bernard H. Law sits that includes mostly lay businessmen, does not mean the archdiocese will definitely declare bankruptcy, a step that would require Vatican approval. But the vote signals a feeling by the church's financial advisers that Chapter 11 bankruptcy would allow the archdiocese to settle the abuse lawsuits as a single group, instead of through a parade of lawsuits involving frustrating settlement negotiations and civil court proceedings. 
 If the archdiocese does declare bankruptcy, it would become the first American Roman Catholic diocese to do so. Legal experts have said they would be stunned by such an action because the Boston Archdiocese is so large it could potentially liquidate assets for payments to abuse victims, which have been estimated to require about $100 million. And some legal experts suggested that the archdiocese could be using the specter of bankruptcy as a way of creating pressure on plaintiffs' lawyers to accept a settlement. 
The archdiocese issued a statement this evening saying that "no final determination to file Chapter 11 has been made at this time." Vatican officials have said that Boston has not yet sought approval.
Lawyers representing more than half of the 450 plaintiffs in the abuse lawsuits had said this week that they would quit settlement negotiations if the archdiocese did not agree to take talk of bankruptcy off the table while negotiations continued.
Tonight, one of the lawyers, Roderick MacLeish Jr., said: "We hope that the archdiocese does not file for bankruptcy. We think it would be cruel if that happens. We think it would be a form of moral bankruptcy. If they do exercise these options, we look forward to Cardinal Law explaining to a bankruptcy judge why he lives in a palatial mansion while our clients lie wounded on the battlefield."
But Mr. MacLeish stopped short of saying that the lawyers would pull out of talks. "We're calling on the cardinal by tomorrow to clarify that he will proceed in good faith in settlement negotiations," he said. "If he does not give those assurances, we will have to reconsider our options."
Donna M. Morrissey, a spokeswoman for the archdiocese, said today: "We believe a mediated resolution would be preferable to seeking Chapter 11 protection and remain hopeful that this process currently under way will be successful. However, we feel it is also necessary to carefully consider the alternative or complementary approach of a Chapter 11 reorganization."
The bankruptcy vote came on a day when many Catholics were feeling fresh torrents of anger over disclosures in more than 2,000 pages of church documents released Tuesday, which detailed how the Boston Archdiocese continually overlooked accusations of abuse against priests and allowed them to stay in ministry.
Most notably, leaders of Voice of the Faithful, an increasingly influential lay group, said today that the group felt so betrayed by what the documents revealed about Cardinal Law's actions that its members were considering calling for his resignation, asking the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops to investigate him, and starting a campaign for people who want to withhold donations from the archdiocese.
"What this shows so clearly is the fact that Cardinal Law and the bishops were perpetrating a huge hoax on faithful Catholics and parishioners," said James E. Post, president of Voice of the Faithful. "No decent Catholic could feel anything but outrage and a sense of still more betrayal."
Voice of the Faithful, which started in February with 40 people in a church basement discussing the clergy sexual abuse crisis and now claims 25,000 members in 40 states, has been careful to avoid stances that leaders felt might unduly antagonize or alienate the archdiocese.
The group, which seeks greater lay involvement in church decisions, has consistently emphasized its desire to establish a working relationship with the archdiocese. And just last week, the group logged what it considered a small success when its leaders were granted a two-hour meeting with Cardinal Law. At the time, Dr. Post, a business professor at Boston University, said there were "hopeful signs of progress."
But today, Dr. Post said that the documents, containing complaints, memorandums and letters about eight priests accused of abuse, were a "major setback to the development of any relationship between Voice of the Faithful and Cardinal Law." He added, "Relationships are based in trust, and these disclosures seriously undermine any basis for trusting the archbishop."
He and other Voice of the Faithful leaders, who read many of the documents themselves, said the disclosures were inconsistent with some of the things the cardinal told the group in the meeting, particularly the disclosures that priests accused of improper conduct continued to be kept in ministry after 1993, when a high-profile priest molestation case caused the archdiocese to put some stricter policies in place.
"Everything he told us is contradicted by the evidence," said Mary Scanlon Calcaterra, a group leader. "He told us since 1993 there were only two new cases of abuse. He had said that the archdiocese had a new policy since 1993, a policy of dealing with misguided priests, that a new policy was put in place with provisions that safeguarded victims, children, and families."
She added, "We see there was a very systematic and widespread effort to protect criminal behavior."
Dr. Post said the group would hold meetings of its leadership and members over the next few days and he said he considered it "highly likely" that members would vote to call for the cardinal's resignation.
Voice of the Faithful has already raised about $60,000 from people who did not want to give to the archdiocese's annual fund-raising drive, but the group has offered that money to the archdiocese for charitable programs, requiring that the archdiocese account for its spending and put none of the money into administrative operations.
Dr. Post said today that many members felt the need to register a stronger economic protest because the documents "highlight how hundreds of thousands of dollars have been used to support priests on administrative leave because of allegations, used to cover up these actions, used to try to suppress the documents."
He said members might decide to "cut off their donations entirely" or "redirect them by putting money into trust funds for benefit of particular parish."
In response to the Voice of the Faithful statements, Ms. Morrissey said: "The cardinal met with them in good faith. It was a cordial and respectful meeting as reported by officials of both Voice of the Faithful and the archdiocese. What they may or may not do is speculative, and I cannot comment on that."
Filing for bankruptcy would have certain advantages for the church, potentially allowing it to delay paying plaintiffs for years because under Chapter 11, creditors may not take steps to collect what is owed them while an organization takes time to get its finances in order. 
During that time, the bankruptcy judge would stop the progress of pending court cases and the filing of new cases. The release of incriminating church documents in the discovery process would stop, as would embarrassing depositions of Cardinal Law and other officials.
In addition, the archdiocese might be hoping that a federal bankruptcy judge would be more sympathetic to the church than Judge Constance M. Sweeney of Superior Court, who has ruled consistently for the public disclosure of church documents about abusive priests. And a bankruptcy judge might be more able to force the archdiocese's insurance companies to pay for much of the settlements. The church has nearly $100 million in insurance, but insurers are balking at paying some of the claims.
But bankruptcy would have pitfalls, too, opening the church's closely held financial records and giving a judge control over which church land or buildings might be sold to pay plaintiffs. And it might create the impression that the church was trying to avoid fully compensating abuse victims.
For those reasons, and the fact that archdiocese may well be able to afford paying for the settlements without filing for bankruptcy, plaintiffs' lawyers said they suspected that the talk about bankruptcy was mostly a negotiating strategy to lower the financial expectations of the plaintiffs. Even a member of the church's finance council expressed that view this week.
But one archdiocesan financial adviser said on Sunday that bankruptcy was attractive because "it would make all the plaintiffs come forward and treat them all equally." The adviser said Cardinal Law was "leaning toward" bankruptcy and added, "There are a lot of very, very practical reasons why it makes sense."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Federal Panel Rejects United Request for Loan Aid
A federal panel has rejected a request by United Airlines for $1.8 billion in loan guarantees. Union leaders said that United executives told them that the airline hoped to avoid an immediate bankruptcy filing, but analysts said the decision all but ensured that United would have to seek court protection.
 The Air Transportation Stabilization Board said that government assistance would not solve United's problems. "This is not just about costs," wrote Peter R. Fisher, a Treasury undersecretary who is on the board. "It's about a business plan that is fundamentally flawed." United said it was disappointed by the decision. Page A1. 

Gilead Moves to Expand Drug Line
Gilead Sciences, the biotechnology company, plans to buy Triangle Pharmaceuticals for $464 million to expand its line of drugs to treat AIDS and hepatitis B. Gilead already sells an AIDS drug. Triangle is seeking approval for its own AIDS drug. The acquisition could be one of several mergers that analysts say might occur because many biotechnology companies are running out of cash. C3.

Former Trader at El Paso Is Indicted
A former natural gas trader of the El Paso Corporation, Todd Geiger, 38, has been indicted on charges of falsely reporting 48 gas trades last year. C3.

France Telecom Proposes Overhaul
Moving to shore up France Telecom, the chairman, Thierry Breton, presented proposals that included a government loan of about $9 billion to help deal with $70 billion in debt. C3.

I.B.M. Will Add $3 Billion to Pension
In an effort to put the issue of pension-fund obligations behind it, I.B.M. announced that it planned to put $3 billion into its American pension fund. C4.

Markets Finish the Day Lower
The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 5.08 points, to close at 8,737.85. The Nasdaq fell 18.61 points, to 1,430.35. The Standard & Poor's index declined 3.18 points, to 917.57. C8.

Last year, trades through CIBC World Markets raised more than $16 million for charities devoted to children. This year's effort is expected to have raised even more. C5.

Shortcut Suggested in Sun Case
A federal judge suggested that Sun Microsystems, in its antitrust suit against Microsoft, drop some of its demands and go directly to trial on whether to force Microsoft to carry Sun's Java program. A lawyer for Sun said the company would consider the idea. C4.

Porsche Posts Record Profit
Defying an economic downturn and a stock market collapse that decimated the portfolios of many of its best customers, the automaker Porsche said that it posted a record pretax profit of $830 million on sales of $4.87 billion in fiscal 2002. Wendelin Wiedeking, left, the chief executive, said the German government helped Porsche achieve its record profit by reducing the corporate tax rate. World Business, Section W.

Factory Orders Increase in October
Factory orders rose in October for the first time since July, while the service sector continued to expand in November. C12.

T.G.I. Friday's Ads Shift Direction
In March, T.G.I. Friday's started an estimated $50 million campaign. But the irreverent "Eat What You Love. Love Where You Eat" campaign, featuring a character named the Friday's Guy, has turned off consumers and alienated franchisees. So Friday's has temporarily retooled the campaign. Advertising. C8.

An Age of Economic Enlightenment
Through most of history, periods of invention did not create sustained growth. That pattern changed in the 19th century. "The true question of the Industrial Revolution," one professor writes, "is not why it took place at all but why it was sustained beyond, say, 1820." Virginia Postrel: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: More Families Face Loss of Heat With Public Aid Scarce 

BYLINE:  By JOHN W. FOUNTAIN

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 4 

 BODY:
The living room of Anna Brown's wood-frame house on the city's West Side is toasty these days. The rest of the house is cold.
 Mrs. Brown, 75, keeps two electric space heaters in her living room during the day. Her natural gas was disconnected two years ago when prices soared and she fell behind in her payments. So she has erected the seasonal curtain of thick plastic that seals off the living room from the rest of the house, and has resigned to settle in for another long Chicago winter warmed by the red glow of space heaters. 
 In Chicago alone, the number of customers without natural gas service is 10,000, according to People's Energy, the utility company that supplies natural gas to nearly one million customers in the Chicago area. 
With the economy stagnant, social service agencies say people are seeking help in paying their heating bills earlier this year and the coming winter is likely to pose a chilling bind. It is expected to be colder than last winter, the price of gas is rising and the Bush administration has proposed cutting $300 million from the $1.7 billion federal program that provided energy subsidies for needy families in the last fiscal year. 
Such a cut would mean that 438,000 fewer families received aid from the program, the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program, which helped 4.5 million families last year, said Mark Wolfe, spokesman for the National Energy Assistance Director's Association, an education and policy group for directors of the program in states and on Indian reservations.
Michael Musante, a spokesman for a federal agency involved in the program, said of the proposed $300 million reduction: "You could call it a cut if you like. We're saying its a return to the normal level of funding that we found in 2001."
Mr. Musante said there was a $300 million emergency contingency fund that would be available to states for help in extreme weather of all types as well in cases in which energy supplies are disrupted or there are huge spikes in energy prices. He said there was also a supplemental fund of $300 million that could be tapped for energy assistance. States must request this money, he said.
Any cut in the budget of the federal program for energy assistance would have to be approved by Congress. Under the proposed reduction, the number of households served in New York State would probably shrink by 80,000, to 585,000, Mr. Wolfe said. That would be if, as projected, $38 million was cut from the state's $212 million in federal energy assistance money, he said. 
In Illinois, the proposed cuts, would mean that 35,000 fewer families would receive assistance. 
In New York City, the cost of heat is included in most rents, said Carol Abrams, a spokeswoman for the New York City Department of Housing and Preservation. But that does not mean residents do not have heating problems. From Oct. 1 to Nov. 26, the housing agency issued violations to 2,570 apartment buildings for insufficient heat, Ms. Abrams said, compared with 2,123 for the same period last year. Of the 2,570 violations this season, either the city or the owner restored heat to all the buildings. 
Whether the demand for heating assistance will actually turn out to be higher this year is not clear. But in Minnesota, local groups that administer the aid program said that more people -- many of whom have lost their jobs -- were asking for help earlier than usual, despite relatively warm weather. 
"We are seeing a lot more new applicants this year, especially early in the season," said Anthony Spears, chief financial officer for Community Action of Minneapolis Inc., a nonprofit group that distributes the energy-assistance money.
In the last 45 days, Mr. Spears said his agency had processed 4,000 applications, nearly double the number handled in the same period last year.
Officials in Detroit have also seen a growing need. Kathleen Walgren, executive director of the nonprofit Heat and Warmth Fund, said that since the agency began its early emergency program on Nov. 1, it had helped 330 households, mostly in Detroit, where service was shut off, paying $144,836 in utility bills. Mrs. Walgren said several hundred others had already inquired about help. 
In Chicago and some other Illinois cities, officials say, state money to restore service to households that have been disconnected is already exhausted for the winter.
With almost every state and city facing major budget cuts, it may be difficult to use public money to make up for any federal spending cuts.
Last week, community activists in Chicago demonstrated outside People's Energy as well as the mayor's office, demanding that the gas to homes that had been disconnected for nonpayment be restored. 
"It's a grim situation," said Bob Vondrasek, executive director of the South Austin Coalition, which participated in the demonstration. "People are living in the cold, they're trying to get by with kerosene heaters and charcoal grills, electric heaters. There will be fires, hypothermia. Strictly from the perspective of low-income households, it's kind of a third-world situation."
For some, there appears to be little immediate relief in sight.
"I couldn't pay the gas bill and keep my lights on," said Mrs. Brown, explaining that she receives about $1,000 a month in Social Security and that $700 of that goes toward her mortgage. "I just couldn't pay it. You've got to have one designated area where you can stay warm."
During the day Mrs. Brown stays in her living room. At night, she carries a space heater to her bedroom.
In Chicago this fall, People's Energy started a program called the Gift of Warmth, which allows people to buy cards worth varying amounts to give to family members for their heating costs. The utility also has a Share the Warmth program that provides up to $200 in assistance to low-income families.
"We make every effort to lead customers to financial aid and put them on payment plans as a way to avoid disconnections," said Elizabeth Castro, a spokeswoman for the utility. "A lot of the times, it's just about contacting us before it becomes a problem." 
John Howat, senior energy policy analyst at the National Consumer Law Center in Washington, said that only "a handful of states" compiled data on utility terminations for nonpayment and how long a customer's gas service had been shut off, making it difficult to measure the extent of the problem. But what is clear, Mr. Howat said, is that many terminations of service and utility company debts are concentrated in low-income areas.
"There continues to be a large gap in the rates of shutoffs and the rates of restoration," Mr. Howat said. "That means people are shut off for longer periods of time. There is a pressing need for a lot more energy assistance."
For some this winter, it could come down to making hard choices.
"A couple years ago we asked the people who get our assistance what they would do if they didn't have it," said Mrs. Walgren, of Detroit's heating-aid program. "A number of them said they would have to cut back on food. Heat or eat."
Mrs. Brown is now about $3,000 in debt on her gas bill, with two hot plates as well as two space heaters. She figures that she can keep her living room warm enough and keep heating water for washing until Chicago's winter breaks sometime in April, if she is lucky.
"You see this here?" Mrs. Brown said, pointing to her space heaters. "That's how I'm going to make it."

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
Taking a Shopping-Center Feud to the Shareholders

BYLINE:  By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

 BODY:
The brawl at the mall is on. Escalating an already bitter feud, the Simon Property Group will announce today that it is going directly to shareholders of A. Alfred Taubman's shopping mall empire, Taubman Centers, with a sweetened takeover bid of $1.5 billion, bypassing the wishes of the company's board.
 According to people briefed on the situation, Simon Property, the nation's largest shopping mall owner, is also planning to file a lawsuit today against Taubman Centers, its board and members of the Taubman family -- including Mr. Taubman, who is serving a prison sentence for conspiring to fix prices when he was chairman of Sotheby's auction house. The suit will seek to invalidate the family's control over the company and clear the way for shareholders to consider the new offer, which is for $18 a share in cash. 
 Taubman Centers' board had rebuffed Simon Property's initial offer of $17.50 a share two weeks ago, insisting that because of the family's ability to block any deal -- and its opposition to selling -- "any efforts to purchase Taubman Centers would not be productive."
In the suit, Simon Property will make a new contention, asserting that the Taubman Centers board deliberately broke Michigan law by giving the family effective voting control over the company in 1998 without a shareholder vote, these people said. Taubman Centers is based in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., near Detroit.
Both companies declined to comment.
Simon Property's latest salvo is likely to intensify one of the most-watched fights among the clubby world of wealthy real estate investors by putting pressure on Taubman's board to consider the bid or defend its position.
So far, Taubman Centers has avoided debating Simon Property's bid by taking a "just say no" approach.
Corporate governance experts and analysts suggest that the tender offer will force Taubman's independent board members to hire financial and legal advisers to consider the offer thoroughly, something they have been pressed to do but have so far resisted.
Earlier this week, Stuart Seeley, an analyst at UBS, wrote in a note to clients that Simon Property has "clearly thrown a live grenade into the lap of the independent board members such that they will likely feel compelled to be in a defensible position" and thus "should feel a need to affirmatively consider this, and any other offers, thoroughly."
Still, Taubman Centers has several defense mechanisms that could protect it from Simon Property's advances unless these are blocked by a judge. In some respects, Simon Property's effort to seek stock directly from Taubman shareholders is meant simply to put pressure on the board and to demonstrate to the judge that shareholders are possibly being disenfranchised.
Indeed, the company cannot be taken over without a two-thirds vote by all shareholders -- and the Taubman family has about 30 percent voting strength and enough friends and associates to give it effective veto power.
In its suit, Simon Property is challenging the way the Taubman family obtained its voting equity in Taubman Centers, which is a real estate investment trust that owns a stake in an operating partnership, the Taubman Realty Group. The partnership owns the properties, which include two dozen malls like the Mall at Short Hills in New Jersey and the Beverly Center in Los Angeles.
Until 1998, the Taubman family did not have voting control of the publicly traded company; its economic interest and voting rights were tied up in the operating partnership, a common structure to reduce taxes for the family.
As part of restructuring, the family received special shares in the publicly traded company -- giving it 30 percent of the vote -- apparently to align the interests of stakeholders in both the publicly traded company and the partnership. The arrangement was not disclosed in a news release at the time but was acknowledged later in a filing with securities regulators.
Simon Property's suit contends that the move was carried out without a required shareholder vote. Michigan law requires a shareholder vote if more than 20 percent of a company changes hands, a law usually invoked to prevent takeovers without shareholder approval. The Taubmans' stake in the publicly traded company went to about 30 percent from 1 percent.
Simon Property is also planning to contest more voting shares that were recently transferred to the Taubman family by friends and associates that gave it additional voting strength, these people said. 
Taubman Centers also has another defense mechanism in its charter that prevents any shareholder from taking a stake larger than 9.8 percent without the board's approval or a two-thirds vote by the shareholders to change the charter.
So far, the shareholders are betting that the family does not capitulate; Taubman shares fell 14 cents yesterday, to $16.46, still below Simon Property's original offer of $17.50 each. Shares of Simon Property fell 15 cents, to $33.55.
Simon Property has a long road ahead if it is going to prevail.
"Handicapping the outcome of complicated lawsuits, such as this one would likely be, is far from straightforward," Barry Vinocur, editor of The Realty Stock Review, wrote in a recent note to clients. "Nevertheless, we doubt that making the case advanced by Simon would be a slam-dunk. Of course, we suspect that Simon's primary goal is to win its case in the court of public opinion, and by all accounts, it seems to be doing that."

HEADLINE: AIRLINE SHOCK WAVES: THE TRAVELERS; 
In Short Term, Probably Business as Usual

BYLINE:  By JOE SHARKEY

 BODY:
Airline experts say they are fairly certain of three things if United Airlines goes to bankruptcy court: travelers will probably not see immediate drastic cuts in United flights; the carrier's frequent-flier miles will remain valid; and United's large rivals will lunge for United customers at the airline's hub airports.
 "There will be a void and in the moment of weakness we would expect the Northwests, Americans, Deltas and Continentals of the world to move quickly and go after the customers," especially in United strongholds like Chicago, Denver and Los Angeles, said Bill Oliver, vice president of the Boyd Group, an airline consulting company in Evergreen, Colo. 
 Mr. Oliver, a former executive with Braniff Airlines, which shut down in 1989 after twice entering bankruptcy and liquidating, said that new, widespread fare wars were not likely because leisure fares are already at money-losing levels. Instead, he said, United's competitors could be expected to add flights in hubs where they compete with United, while sweetening promotional offers like frequent-flier benefits to try to attract United's business travelers. 
"Short term, a United bankruptcy means nothing," said Joe Brancatelli, an air-travel consultant who publishes the Web site Joesentme. com. "Flights will continue to run, tickets will continue to be honored, and frequent-flier miles will continue to be acquired and used for travel awards."
"Today, tomorrow, January and February, you'd see very little," he added. "March and April, that's when they'd make any massive changes in flight schedules." 
Both business and leisure travelers are worried about United, the nation's second-largest airline. But in the last two years travelers have grown accustomed to hearing bad news about airlines and making accommodations to constricting schedules and deteriorating service, industry experts said.
US Airways had already severely reduced its schedule and work force had already severely reduced its schedule and work force by the time it sought Chapter 11 protection in August, for example, so post-bankruptcy customers "barely missed a beat," said Thomas Nulty, the president of Navigant International, the travel-management company.
Consequently, travel agents and others in the industry say, as of yesterday there had been no noticeable effort by people to return or transfer already purchased United tickets. Customers expressing concerns are being assured that United will continue flying during a bankruptcy reorganization, they said.
On the other hand, uncertainty about United's longer-term shape is worrisome for corporate managers who are now negotiating volume-discount contracts with airlines for travel through next year. They know that in Chapter 11, United will eventually reduce routes and service even more than it already has.
"United has been a preferred supplier for us," said Peter Buchheit, travel director at the Black & Decker Corporation, which spends about $15 million a year on domestic airline tickets. "But right now, making any kind of intelligent determination" to contract for air service with United is difficult, he said. "It's hard to make any long-term commitments." 
Ira Weinstein, an airport industry consultant, said that because United was "so skewed toward the business-travel market," it was risking further alienating those higher-paying customers, who already have shown that they will switch to smaller discount airlines with less convenient schedules.
If United does seek bankruptcy court protection soon, the consequences will become increasingly pronounced when travel picks up after the winter, said Kevin P. Mitchell, chairman of the Business Travel Coalition.
By then, customer service will probably have deteriorated further as anxious employees chafe at working harder for less pay while United "pinches every penny" under bankruptcy constraints, he said. "Deteriorating customer service will be the most notable immediate impact," he said.
Mr. Mitchell also said he thought it possible, if unlikely, that sporadic fare wars could begin -- despite the fact that airlines are expected to lose more than $8 billion this year. That, he said, would further damage the industry.
Longer term, industry experts see a potential for higher leisure fares as airlines settle into a more rational pricing structure and struggle for profitability.
A United bankruptcy filing would also portend a further overall shrinking of flights and capacity, probably including reduced service to regional markets. It would increase the likelihood that the United States airline industry will ultimately consolidate into two or three major worldwide carriers supplemented by four or five bigger players among the robustly growing discount carriers.
Internationally, a United hobbled by bankruptcy is disturbing news for Star Alliance, a worldwide network of 14 airlines that share frequent- flier programs and even flights on some routes, and whose major players include United and Lufthansa. Several industry experts speculated that Lufthansa might seek to replace United with a more stable global partner, like American Airlines.
United, whose main strengths are in the Midwest, Mountain states and West, had an average of 2,200 daily flights in 2000. It now flies fewer than 1,800, and recently announced a further 6 percent reduction in capacity and a plan to furlough 352 pilots early in 2003. In 2000, United had more than 10,000 pilots. It now employs about 8,500.
Now that a bankruptcy filing appears unavoidable as prospects for an immediate federal loan bailout disappeared yesterday, airline industry experts struggled to find lessons in previous airline bankruptcies. But a bankruptcy filing by a carrier as big and as dominant as United in the domestic and international business-travel market would be unprecedented, industry experts said.

Help on the Web For Frantic Fliers
For those worried about United flights they have booked, here are some Web sites for information on schedules and news about United and other airlines:

UNITED.COM -- United Airlines' Web site has flight information, including a downloadable flight schedule. Company news releases and announcements can be found under "about United" by clicking on "company information."

JOHNNYJET.COM -- A travel portal with hundreds of links to timely airline information and news. It has a link for current information about any scheduled domestic flight.

FLYERTALK.COM -- A comprehensive portal with forums, tips and live chats on frequent-flier programs, including complaints, warnings and the latest promotional offers.

FLY.FAA.GOV -- A map showing the nation's airports, with current information on air traffic, including delays.

JOESENTME.COM -- Views on air travel from a travel expert, Joe Brancatelli, and others, with a lot of links to industry news and travel tools.
 JOE SHARKEY

HEADLINE: City Gets Budgeting Tips, Down to Turning Off Lights 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER

 BODY:
Increase the workweek for city workers to at least 40 hours. Eliminate planned, predictable overtime shifts for police officers. Provide more preventive services to keep borderline students in regular classes, rather than more expensive special education classes. And remind all employees: last one out, turn off the lights!
 Those were some of the suggestions in a series of reports issued yesterday by a private budget-watchdog group contending that the city could save more than $1 billion a year with longer workweeks, restructured special education, overhauled staffing at the Police Department and energy conservation at city agencies. 
 The reports -- released by the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonpartisan research group backed by businesses -- came during a day of public conversations about the city's troubled finances. At Baruch College, veterans of the fiscal crisis of the 1970's discussed what lessons leaders should draw from that era. And at New York Law School, Mark Page, the city's budget director, gave a speech outlining the Bloomberg administration's approach to balancing the books in these hard times.
The backdrop to all these discussions is the money crunch the city has been struggling with for more than a year, as the weak economy, the attack on the World Trade Center and the unsustainable spending levels reached during the boom times of the late 1990's have combined to throw the city's budget out of balance.
The 18.5 percent increase in property tax rates that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed last week, along with another battery of budget cuts, should raise more than enough to balance this year's budget. But the city still faces a shortfall of more than $3 billion in the fiscal year that begins in seven months, on July 1.
The Citizens Budget Commission estimated that if the city's 70,000 civilian workers (a figure that excludes teachers and uniformed employees) who work fewer than 40 hours a week were required to do so, the city could use fewer workers to perform the same tasks and save up to $498 million a year. Changing staffing at the Police Department -- by eliminating nonemergency overtime and transferring duties unrelated to law enforcement from police officers to lower-paid civilians -- could save $251 million a year. Overhauling special education, they said, could save $267 million a year. And conserving energy could save the city up to $47 million a year.
The reports were received favorably by the Bloomberg administration, which is counting on $600 million in productivity savings to balance the budget next year, and has publicly endorsed several of the measures that were mentioned in the reports.
The labor unions would have to agree to an expanded workweek. Yesterday the Bloomberg administration began negotiating its next contract with District Council 37, the largest municipal union. A union official said that she had not seen the report and could not comment on it.
As the budget commission pushed its proposals, Mr. Page outlined the city's budget plan during a rare public speech at a breakfast at New York Law School.
Although some critics maintain that the city should lay off more workers to save money, Mr. Page noted that the city loses more than 12,000 employees a year through regular attrition. And he said that the city is looking for other ways to save money as its budget plan evolves.
"The fact that it doesn't, in fact, have wholesale layoffs in it shouldn't be a great surprise to people," Mr. Page said. "It doesn't mean that there aren't in fact substantial reductions in what we're planning to spend, which, at the end of the day, are not going to be totally fun."
But he did include a caveat. "Things may fall apart at the last minute," he said. "We may end up with substantial layoffs."
The Fiscal Policy Institute, a labor-backed research group, sounded a warning this week in a report that found that while the city has lost less than half as many jobs as it did during the recession of the early 1990's, they have disappeared at a much faster rate.
"It could be that we're in for more than a year or two of very weak economic conditions," said James A. Parrot, the group's chief economist.

HEADLINE: White-Collar Layoffs, Downsized Dreams; 
Losing Faith in a Limitless Future

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
Besides the obvious impact on wallets and pocketbooks, the prolonged economic downturn is leaving a profound and potentially long-lasting psychological imprint on a generation of midcareer professionals who have until now known little but success in the world of work.
 Years of progressively better jobs and higher salaries, for many solidly in the six figures, primed their expectations and shaped their lives. Now many of these professionals -- a broad range of college-educated managers, administrators and midlevel executives -- have been out of work for a year or longer, especially in the hard-hit worlds of finance, communications and information technology that are concentrated in the New York area. 
 They realize that tough times have pushed many blue-collar workers to the brink of bankruptcy and feel uncomfortable complaining too loudly. 
But on commuter trains and in coffee shops throughout the region, they take the measure of their unaccustomed plight. Though not on welfare, they have had to raid savings. Though far from homeless, they have had to halt big projects, like re-siding the house, that were begun when times were good. 
And most significantly, though they have no doubt they will work again, they have had to downsize their dreams.
"The way it is now, you look at everything and say, 'Do I need to do this,' " said Eric S. Feinstein, 40, a former high-tech manager and father of two from Ossining, N.Y., who has been out of work for 19 months. He and his wife, Lauri Nemetz, had long planned to have a third child. Now even that personal plan has been undermined. 
"When people say 'Do you think you'll have another one?' my knee-jerk reaction is that I can't even think about it until I have a job again," Mr. Feinstein said. "There is uncertainty about everything because the slowdown has been so prolonged. You just don't know how to plan for things." 
In the last two years, the rate of increase of unemployment among professionals has risen proportionately more than for the blue-collar workers, who are traditionally hit hardest in a recession. 
Having lost their jobs in part because the technology bubble burst, many professionals have had a harder time than most blue-collar workers finding new ones. The number of professionals out of work for more than six months has more than doubled in the last year, and on average they are going jobless longer than both crafts workers and laborers.
Recent polls show that the optimism and confidence that were a notable feature of this slump a year ago have started to wane. 
"Their sense of security has been shaken," said Katherine S. Newman, Malcolm Wiener professor of urban studies at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. "People will survive, but they won't generally come back to the standard of living they once enjoyed. For most of them, it means deferring a lot of dreams, and compromising aspects of life that are very precious to them."
Instead of snorkeling in Aruba, John Sampson, 58, of Wayne, N.J., will go to the Adirondacks for vacation -- if he takes a vacation -- because his position running all the computer operations of a large community development agency in Newark was eliminated a year ago. Lisa E. Rosevear, 35, had planned to buy a condominium in Manhattan until she lost her job at a global public relations firm last December. Now she does not expect to be able to buy a home for at least a decade.
Until he lost his job in April 2001 as director of technology for the interactive-services group at Viacom, Mr. Feinstein had a career trajectory that seemed to go one way: up. After graduating from Johns Hopkins University in 1983 with a degree in electrical engineering and computer science, he spent the next 18 years in a series of high-technology jobs.
Then in early 2001, after Viacom merged with CBS, the interactive-services group was disbanded.
At first, Mr. Feinstein believed another job would come as effortlessly as jobs had always come in the past. He was so confident that the first thing he did was take a vacation to Colonial Williamsburg with his wife, who was pregnant with their second son, Caleb. Mr. Feinstein did not even think about looking for a job until he got home.
One month went by. Then another. By July 2001, he was checking the help-wanted ads for the first time in his professional life. As summer ended, he was desperately firing off resumes and finding that he could not even get a callback. 
"This really gets your ego," Mr. Feinstein said. "You start thinking, 'How could I have been such a key part of an organization a couple of months ago when I can't even get a return phone call from anyone?' " 
Although his wife had not planned to work while the boys were so young, she took a job last fall as a dance-movement therapist with a Westchester County counseling service. That helped, but the family has had to siphon off about 35 percent of its savings.
They postponed all nonessentials. That included renovating the bathroom and replacing their wheezing 1989 Mazda.
Now, at home with the boys, Mr. Feinstein scours the help-wanted ads and job Web sites daily. He has taken up baking, and supplies cafes in Westchester County with brownies, biscotti and 11 kinds of scones. Maple pecan is his best seller. 
He has contemplated starting his own business, but realizes that he will probably have to return to the corporate world, provided he can find an opening. But he doubts that he will ever recover the optimism he had before.
"There probably will always be a shadow of a 'Don't get too comfortable' kind of thing," he said. "Some people think, 'What's the big deal, you just lost one job?' But that's not really the case. Your confidence in the system is shattered."
Professionals in the high-tech field expect to hop from job to job. The problem now, said Robert Larson, president of Berman Larson Kane, a large recruitment company in Paramus, N.J., is that they have never before had to survive a slump.
When people call to offer a resume, Mr. Larson said, "I don't have the heart to tell them that we're getting 60,000 to 100,000 people a month who come to our Web site for jobs." 
This makes it difficult for Mr. Larson to help even those people whose careers he has tracked for 15 years, like Alvin Blake of Ridgewood, N.J.
Mr. Blake, 58, lost his job as director of professional services at Qwest in January. Since then, he has regularly attended meetings of a Ridgewood support group for out-of-work professionals. When his unemployment benefits ran out, he began driving a limousine. 
"Pride is not one of my vanities," he said. He fantasizes about turning an executive passenger into a prospective employer.
Mr. Blake and his wife, Tommie, a flight attendant, have had to pull in their horns considerably. "My house is in disrepair, and the outside should have been painted last year," he said. They go to dinner or the movies only once a month, and vacations are out of the question. But he said the most difficult aspect of all has been telling his 17-year-old daughter, Allison, a senior in high school, that she probably will not be able to attend a private college like her older sister, Sawyer.
"The higher up you were," Mr. Blake said, "the tougher this is."
Prolonged unemployment can also nibble away at the foundation of any relationship, as Ed Krugman of East Brunswick, N.J., found out after he lost his job in May 2001.
Mr. Krugman, 58, had been director of international information technology for Block Drug in Jersey City until it was bought out by a large multinational corporation. He first put out feelers about eight months before his job disappeared, and he has searched for work since then to no avail. He joined a group of unemployed professionals called We Want Work, and in September he stood outside Grand Central Terminal wearing a sandwich board pleading with prospective employers to look at his resume on the Internet. 
"Before the company announced the merger, I thought I was going to stay with them for a long time and watch my responsibilities increase," Mr. Krugman said. He and his wife, Phyllis, had lived in their home for almost 20 years and had planned several renovations, including a new kitchen.
"Now, all of that has been put on hold," Mr. Krugman said. They have used up about 20 percent of their savings, and have not contributed to their retirement plans for 18 months.
Dashed dreams have a way of pushing people to the edge, even when they do not mean to go there. "She's awful," Mr. Krugman said of his wife, a nurse's aide. "She wants to know how come other people are working and I'm not. She's very upset."
Mr. Krugman said his optimism had dimmed considerably in the last 18 months. "All I can see is that the age at which I plan to retire keeps increasing," he said. "Now I picture myself working into my 70's, if I can find a job."
Sociologists are beginning to consider the long-term effects this prolonged downturn may have on this generation of workers and the next.
"These people don't ever recover the sense of complete confidence that the world is as it appears," said Professor Newman of Harvard. "In some way, they are always worried that the other shoe is going to drop tomorrow. It's a feeling that they transmit to their kids, and this can have ramifications through the generations."
Bernadette T. Lowthert, 40, already believes that these times have become the equivalent for her of what the Depression was for previous generations.
"You know there's going to be a crisis in your lifetime," said Ms. Lowthert, who was laid off in July 2001 from an Internet start-up that she joined after having spent 13 years as a microbiologist and project director with a large pharmaceutical company. "It was the Depression for my parents. This is it for us now."
She cannot afford to have her sister, who is mentally disabled, live with her, as she had planned. She has delayed the renovation of the bathroom in her New York City apartment. She still goes out to dinner every once in a while, but she orders just an appetizer.
Early last month she began a new job, selling laboratory services to doctors. She said that it was a setback, professionally speaking, and entailed a big cut in salary. 
Still, it is a job, and despite the hardship of the last 17 months, Ms. Lowthert said she remained essentially optimistic, though not the same as before. 
"This really tests you and tests your ego," she said. "Now it just doesn't feel right to look too far ahead. It doesn't make sense."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
REYNOLDS TOBACCO TO CUT MORE THAN 600 JOBS

BYLINE:  AP

 BODY:
 R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Holdings will cut about 635 jobs, or 8 percent of its work force, and sell two nontobacco businesses to try to cut costs amid growing competition from lower-priced cigarette brands. Reynolds, the maker of Winston, Salem and Camel cigarettes, also said its 2002 earnings would be at the lower end of its projection for the year and below analysts' estimates. 
The cutback program, which will involve laying off 520 workers and leaving 115 jobs unfilled when they become vacant, is expected to be completed by the middle of next year. The company estimates the job moves will save $50 million next year and $75 million in 2004. The company also said it planned to sell two units that specialize in packaging and botanical extraction.

HEADLINE: AIRLINE SHOCK WAVES: THE WORKERS; 
Daily Frustrations Grow for United's Workers

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA and MARY WILLIAMS WALSH 

 BODY:
Melanie Strahan has worked as a flight attendant for United Airlines for 40 years. She has logged thousands of miles and poured countless cups of coffee.
 She now flies the long route to Beijing from Chicago, and wonders whether she will make it to retirement next year as a United employee. She fears that the UAL Corporation, which owns United, will be forced to file for bankruptcy protection and become the latest casualty in an increasingly demoralized travel industry. 
 "I've been through a lot with United," Ms. Strahan said from her home in Chicago. "I worry about retirement benefits, medical benefits." 
With a bankruptcy filing looming after the federal government rejected United's application for a $1.8 billion loan guarantee last night, thousands of United employees, some 81,000 around the world, according to UAL, are bracing for the worst.
The airline is expected to continue to operate even if it files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from its creditors, but there could be lost jobs and health benefits, more pilot furloughs and a legion of shattered careers.
Through it all, United's employees will continue to work the ticket counters, to check in customers, service planes and land jets in more than 120 cities worldwide. But many of them said that even before the government's decision last night, employee morale had been plummeting. There is now an awful sense of foreboding about the fate of their once-proud airline.
"This is absolutely devastating," Sheri Meehleis, a United flight attendant for 31 years, said last night after hearing about the government's rejection. "We've worked so hard to prevent this."
Going to work at United is not so easy these days; for United employees, the everyday smiles and customer greetings are a little harder to muster. Pessimism is in the air.
"I realize the seriousness of what I do," said David Quinn, 42, a lead mechanic for United at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago. "But I'd be lying if I told you having your future on hold isn't having an effect on us. It's a constant sense of frustration that has bled over. It'd be inhuman to say this frustration doesn't come into play."
United employees are faced with the daily frustrations that typically come to a company on the verge of bankruptcy. Yet few thought that formerly loyal customers would also lash out.
Several customer service agents said that they have heard from frustrated travelers who said that the airline deserves to be in bankruptcy.
"We get no respect from management, and now customers are bashing us, saying we're going into bankruptcy," said Vanessa Reneau-Mack, 35, a customer service agent who works the ticket counters at O'Hare. "I'm with business travelers and frequent fliers, and so we're hearing this from even high-profile customers. What we want is respect. And we don't get respect from upper management. It's affecting us."
The people who work at United worried after Sept. 11. They changed their lives when new security measures were added. Now, they are bracing for the stiffest change of all -- the possibility that United will collapse.
In bankruptcy court, United would be free to petition the judge for much deeper cuts in pay and benefits than employees have agreed to until now.
Vivian Jackson, who also works in customer service at O'Hare, said that she worried about losing her health benefits. She is 30 and has a 6-month-old child. She's only been with United for three years, but she thought she had a future with the brand-name company. Now, she's not so sure. The company seems to be at war with itself.
"This is really personal," she said. "Before it was just the pilots or the mechanics. Now it's a tug of war."
Some United employees said that the company had not kept them abreast of the financial crisis, that they got their information from the newspapers or from watching television sets in the employee break room. They chatter while on the employee buses and huddle behind the scenes, whenever there is a lull in airport traffic.
Among flight attendants, the talk is of little but job security, said Ryan Murphy, a 27-year-old flight attendant who is based in San Francisco.
"It's very demoralizing," Mr. Murphy said. "People are very upset, or are trying to find out the information that they need, trying to make decisions about whether to stay or look for another job now."
Without the loan guarantees, United will almost certainly have to seek court protection from its creditors.
Ms. Meehleis, the United flight attendant who is also council president of the Association of Flight Attendants in Denver, said the union is "taking hundreds of calls a day" from flight attendants who want to know how they would be affected by a bankruptcy filing or reorganization. 
The most commonly asked questions are about who will be furloughed when the payroll cuts begin, and what the furlough will be like.
"Their questions run the gamut," she said. "What if we go on furlough and then the company goes into bankruptcy? Will the bankruptcy judge say United can't pay my unemployment compensation anymore?"
It is hard to answer, because the situation remains so fluid, she said. If United does file for court protection, which now seems inevitable, she said that certain contractual protections that United recently offered employees would no longer be binding. In that case, United could petition the bankruptcy judge to make drastic revisions to its labor agreements.
"They could wipe out our work rules," she said. "They could cut our compensation in half. It could be anything. Our work group stands to lose what we fought for 30 years to gain."
It may not come to that, but whatever happens, employees know they will lose ground.
Already, Mr. Murphy said United is scheduling his trips in ways that bring him home at the end of a shift, evidently to reduce lodging costs. When he has a coast-to-coast flight, United now tacks a short flight onto the beginning or end of it, lengthening his days.
"We used to do just one coast-to-coast in a day," he said. "It's like any classic work speed-up, just like in an auto plant."
These changes, and the sense that more are coming, appear to have prompted some employees to take early retirement, Ms. Meehleis said. One caller to the Denver union local mentioned that his "seniority number," which ranks the order in which employees can be furloughed, had fallen by 50 points since last week.
"That means 50 people have resigned, just earlier this week," she said. "There are people who are able to retire, and because of all this frustration, some people are making that decision. I think it's stress-related. A lot of people are saying, 'This is crazy. I'm done.'
"For me, as a 31-year flight attendant, if I had the opportunity to retire right now, I would," she added. "There's a lot of angst here."
Some of the angriest employees are mechanics like Mr. Quinn, who has worked for United for 17 years. He joined the company after serving in the Air Force. He now heads a mechanics crew that works on 737's and 747's. 
"We do seat cushions to jet engines to flight controls and automatic pilots," he said. "We do all that."
If he stays with United, he may have to wait out an ugly bankruptcy process; if he tried to get a job elsewhere, he would lose his seniority and be forced to take a huge pay cut.
"The difference between an American plane and a United plane is basically a paint job," he said. "But if I go to American I'd have to start at the bottom."
Some employees have nagging doubts about whether the pain of saving United is being evenly spread. 
Donald Cone, a baggage handler in Pittsburgh, said he was bothered by the feeling that the cost of keeping United aloft was being borne by employees more than executives. He recalled that in 1993, ground workers like him agreed to do without raises for seven years.
"We were promised that in July 2000, we would have a contract to vote on," he said. "It never happened."
Instead, he said baggage handlers went for nine years with no pay increase. One finally materialized last summer, but now the talk is of givebacks again.
"People from McDonald's, Wal-Mart, even newspaper writers -- everybody gets pay raises," Mr. Cone said. "We didn't. Not even a cost of living. So, my question is this: How in the world is United Airlines' trouble associated with labor costs?"
Like other employees, Mr. Cone spoke of the satisfaction he had once taken in his work and his association with an international airline. Baggage handlers sometimes ran races against the clock and against one another, Mr. Cone said, loading mountains of freight and luggage onto planes on schedule.
"An employee should have pride in their work," he said. "You try to keep that pride up. You try not to be angry. But you just can't keep taking a pounding in the gut. And it's not about money. It's about moral issues."
If United files for bankruptcy, it will be Mr. Cone's second experience. He and a number of other baggage and freight handlers in Pittsburgh are former steel workers who lost their jobs when that industry began to crumble a quarter-century ago. Mr. Cone worked for Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel from 1974 until 1986.
"I never thought I'd go through this again," he said. "That whole era, I just tried to wipe all that out of my mind. I never dreamed possible in my life that I would experience another Chapter 11."

HEADLINE: Putin, in India, Asks Pakistanis To End Support for the Militants 

BYLINE:  By AMY WALDMAN 

DATELINE: AHMEDABAD, India, Dec. 4 

 BODY:
The Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, joined Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee today in urging Pakistan to abandon its support for Islamic militants who strike India and to oppose the use of force to resolve the situation with Iraq. 
 At the end of talks in New Delhi, the two leaders signed an agreement -- the Delhi Declaration -- for the "further consolidation of strategic partnership" between India and Russia, whose cold war friendship has endured in its aftermath.
 They also issued a joint statement calling for Islamabad "to eliminate terrorist infrastructure in Pakistan and Pakistan-controlled territory as a prerequisite for the renewal of the peace dialogue" between India and Pakistan. 
Both India and Russia are facing Islamic insurgencies -- Russia in the republic of Chechnya, and India in the state of Jammu and Kashmir. 
"Such measures should be directed also against those states, entities and individuals who support, fund or abet terrorists or provide them shelter or asylum to engage in cross-border terrorism," the statement said, apparently in a reference to Pakistan. "There should be no double standards in the fight against terrorism." 
While both countries have expressed concern that Iraq maintain no weapons of mass destruction, their leaders today expressed reservations about the possibility of American military action there. 
"Both sides strongly opposed the unilateral use or threat of use of force in violation of the United Nations Charter as well as interference in internal affairs of other states," a joint statement released at the end of the talks said.
It continued: "It was stressed that the comprehensive settlement of the situation around Iraq is possible only through political and diplomatic efforts in strict conformity with the rules of international law only under the aegis of the United Nations." 
Mr. Putin said last weekend that Russia was concerned that Pakistan's nuclear weapons could fall into the hands of bandits and terrorists. He repeated the same concern today. "We should strengthen nonproliferation efforts, and then everything should be done to settle all disputes, including the dispute between India and Pakistan," he said. 
The India-Russia summit meeting focused on a range of defense, strategic and economic issues between the two countries, which were close during the cold war and retain strong military links. 
"The military and technology cooperation between India and Russia is acquiring a new quality," Mr. Putin said. 
He also said Russia would continue to cooperate with India on developing nuclear energy. 
The two countries signed seven other agreements in areas like counterterrorism and information technology.

HEADLINE: World Survey Says Negative Views of U.S. Are Rising 

BYLINE:  By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 

 BODY:
While people in most non-Muslim countries continue to view the United States favorably, negative opinions have increased in most nations over the past two years, according to public opinion surveys in 44 countries.
 The surveys of 38,000 people conducted by the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press indicated that, although there is widespread support for the United States-led campaign against terrorism since the Sept. 11 attacks, it was tempered by large minorities or even majorities in many countries who say the Bush administration is ignoring their nations' interests. 
 Moreover, followup polls last month in four countries -- Britain, France, Germany and Russia -- found substantial percentages of people saying they thought that the main reason the United States would go to war with Iraq would be "because the U.S. wants to control Iraqi oil." That view was held by 44 percent in Britain, 54 percent in Germany, 75 percent in France and 76 percent in Russia. A parallel survey in the United States found 22 percent agreeing with the war-for-oil theory. 
While polling could not be conducted in some important countries, like Saudi Arabia, and sensitive questions could not be asked in others, like China, the combined surveys appeared to be the largest simultaneous effort to gauge world opinion ever conducted, said Andrew Kohut, director of the Pew Center.
"The main lesson," Mr. Kohut said, "is that while there is a reserve of good will toward the United States, the most powerful country in the world has an increasing number of detractors." He said the post-cold-war reality was "how old friends who need us less, like us less," especially in Europe, while "the Russians have a better opinion of us."
Favorable views of the United States declined in the past two years in Britain from 83 to 75 percent and in Germany from 78 to 61 percent, while they increased in Russia from 37 to 61 percent. There were also striking increases in favorable opinions in Uzbekistan, from 56 to 85 percent, and in Nigeria, from 46 to 77 percent.
The United States-led campaign against terrorism was opposed by most people surveyed in several nations with Muslim majorities. The percentages opposed were 79 percent in Egypt, 85 percent in Jordan, 64 percent in Indonesia, 56 percent in Lebanon, 64 percent in Senegal, 58 percent in Turkey and 64 percent in Indonesia. Pluralities took that view in Pakistan -- 45 percent -- and Bangladesh -- 46 percent. 
The only other non-Muslim countries surveyed where majorities opposed the effort against terrorism were Argentina and South Korea. Argentina, in the midst of an economic crisis when the survey was taken earlier this fall, was critical of the United States on several other measures. In South Korea, Mr. Kohut said, relations with North Korea, a point on which the Seoul government and the Bush administration differ, may have been a factor. But throughout Europe, at least two-thirds of the public backed the policy, and in the predominately Muslim Central Asian nation of Uzbekistan, where the presence of American troops helps the economy, 91 percent supported it.
The findings on Turkey, where the Pentagon wants to use air bases and ports in case of war with Iraq, were singled out as important by Mr. Kohut and Madeleine K. Albright, the former secretary of state and a consultant on the project.
In Turkey, favorable views of the United States have dropped from 52 to 30 percent in the past two years. Only 30 percent said they supported the campaign against terrorism and 74 percent said the United States did not pay either much or any attention to Turkey's interests when setting policy. This week, Turkey's foreign minister, Yasar Yakis, cited public opinion in explaining to American officials why his country could not accept large numbers of American ground troops for a war with Iraq. Dr. Albright said this showed the difficulties in weighing "what we're asking countries to do in terms of leadership versus what people want us to do."
A delicate issue raised in the surveys was suicide bombing. In 14 countries in Africa, Asia and the Middle East, respondents were asked if they believed that "suicide bombing and other forms of violence against civilian targets are justified in order to defend Islam from its enemies."
Majorities said it was often or sometimes justified in Lebanon (73 percent) and Ivory Coast (56 percent). More than 40 percent found it justified it in Bangladesh, Nigeria and Jordan. More than 25 percent said it was justifiable in Pakistan, Indonesia, Ghana, Mali, Senegal and Uganda.
But in many countries the question was not asked. Mr. Kohut said that in Egypt, for example, "A question about suicide bombing is not only impolitic, it could get you thrown in jail."
He said in order to do any polling at all in China and Vietnam, certain questions had to be omitted. "In Saudi Arabia," he said, "you have to get permission to do a poll, and we didn't get permission."
Although in some countries the polling was conducted by telephone, most people were interviewed face to face. In most countries, the survey involved national population samples, but others were done only in urban areas. They took place between July and October. The margins of error varied, from as low as plus or minus two percentage points to as much as plus or minus four percentage points.

HEADLINE: Kenya's Democracy Prepares for an Important Test 

BYLINE:  By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: MOMBASA, Kenya, Dec. 4 

 BODY:
Daniel arap Moi, supreme ruler of Kenya for 24 years and one of Africa's longest surviving leaders, is ceding power this month in an election that many see as a test not only of this spirited if struggling country, but of the viability of democracy across the continent.
 Mr. Moi arrives in Washington on Thursday for a meeting with President Bush, one that is expected to touch on both the Nov. 28 terrorist attacks in Mombasa and the importance of the looming transition in Kenya. If all goes well and Mr. Moi steps gracefully aside, Mr. Bush is planning a trip to Kenya early next year, with one possible stop being the newly constructed American Embassy in Nairobi, which replaces the one destroyed by a terrorist bombing in 1998. 
 For Kenya, this is a campaign season unlike any other: while there is all the ferocious disagreement and sometimes deadly violence of past balloting, for most voters this will be the first election they have known in which the winner is not preordained.
The next president will be either Uhuru Kenyatta -- son of Kenya's first president, Jomo Kenyatta, and Mr. Moi's clear favorite -- or Mwai Kibaki, a veteran politician heading up an opposition coalition that increasingly appears to be the choice of a majority of Kenyans who are fed up with the corruption and crime that have eaten away at their country during Mr. Moi's rule. (Political experts say three other candidates, from minor parties, lack national reach and do not stand a chance.)
"We've never had an election this important," said John Githongo, a political expert who runs the offices of Transparency International, an anticorruption group, in the Kenyan capital. "Not many African countries have been able to handle democratic transitions. If we can do it, peacefully and without controversy, it's an achievement. Our economy will still be in shambles but this could be the beginning of our turnaround."
Despite severe economic woes and the steady decay of its once excellent infrastructure, Kenya remains a pillar of East Africa.
Relief operations to aid the suffering people of Sudan and Congo often being in Kenya. So do military actions to calm the killing frenzies of the region. United States Marines are currently involved in monthlong joint maneuvers along Kenya's coast. The country remains a banking and business center, a transportation hub and a zone of relative stability in a troubled part of the world.
The suicide bombing that leveled the Paradise Hotel here and the failed attempt to down a chartered aircraft leaving Mombasa for Israel only underscore the importance of Kenya. Many political experts believe Kenya, which has porous borders with largely lawless Somalia, has twice been picked as a terrorist target at least partly because of its pro-Western ways.
Still, it is not the country it once was or should be. "If this country were a car, we'd be pushing it," said Gordon Yagomba, 52, an opposition supporter who, like most Kenyans, struggles each month to feed his family.
Over the last quarter century, Mr. Moi's election victories were rather scripted affairs, with his name the only one of the ballot for much of his reign.
After reluctantly agreeing to multiparty politics in 1991, Mr. Moi and his Kenya African National Union party, known as KANU, still managed to manipulate the system -- by fomenting ethnic clashes, exploiting state resources and outfoxing the divided opposition.
As Kenya's economy has shriveled and its suffering has grown, Mr. Moi has found his popularity at an all-time low. He probably would not have won the Dec. 27 election even if the Constitution did not require him to retire.
"Any change of the head of state after 24 years is itself a major event," said Edward Clay, the British high commissioner in Kenya, which was a British colony until 1963. "The world is watching this election so closely because we all want Kenya to do better than it has been doing."
The campaign has generated a frenzy among Kenyans. Rocks are lobbed at candidates on campaign stops; election-related brawls are common. At a bar in downtown Nairobi known for its political banter, a police officer in the governing party recently fired tear gas at patrons who were too effusive in their praise of the opposition.
Already, there have been reports -- hard, as always in Kenya, to verify -- of voter cards being bought and sold, of the names of perhaps a million dead people still on the voter rolls and of thugs intimidating those who might think of voting independently.
The biggest fear, however, is a last-minute round of the ethnic violence that marred the last two presidential contests. In all, thousands of people were killed in the 1992 and 1997 campaigns.
With a first name that means freedom in Swahili, Mr. Kenyatta, 42, is a political novice who regards that term as a badge of honor in a political system so full of rot. Yet Mr. Kenyatta has surrounded himself with some of Mr. Moi's closest cronies and he has promised to keep Mr. Moi's recently chosen vice president, Musalia Mudavadi, as his own.
"We have to forget the past, however bitter we may be," Mr. Kenyatta said as he kicked off his campaign recently in Nairobi.
Mr. Kibaki, by contrast, is 71. He once served Mr. Moi as vice president, but formed his own opposition party in 1991, citing electoral malfeasance by the governing party as well as the suspicious killing of the foreign minister at the time.
Both main candidates are Kikuyus, Kenya's largest tribe, which has helped diffuse some of the ethnic tension that surrounds any political contest here. But political rifts still bristle.
When Mr. Kibaki's Range Rover went into a ditch this week, many of his supporters instantly thought of sabotage; but the accident, which killed two people, has since been proclaimed by the opposition to be just that. Mr. Kibaki, who suffered some broken bones, is expected to return to the campaign trail soon.
Mr. Kibaki finished a close second to Mr. Moi in 1997, and a distant third five years earlier. This time, he is given a better chance because the opposition has united into what its members call the "Rainbow" coalition. Recent polling puts Mr. Kibaki, who has made a big issue of the corruption under Mr. Moi, ahead of Mr. Kenyatta. 
"We don't want to be ruled anymore by those who dictate, declare orders and issue instructions," Mr. Kibaki said at a recent campaign appearance. "We want to be ruled by the law. The word corruption doesn't capture what's going on here. You have to use the Kiswahili word wizi, which means stealing."

HEADLINE: Chavez's Foes Plan to Extend General Strike In Venezuela 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 4 

 BODY:
Government opponents said tonight that they were extending a paralyzing general strike into a fourth day, possibly damaging informal agreements made earlier today between the government and its foes in discussions mediated by the Organization of American States, people involved in the talks said.
 The strike by Venezuelan businessmen and workers opposed to the left-leaning government of President Hugo Chavez threatens to cripple the Venezuelan economy, Latin America's fourth largest, and disrupt oil supplies to the United States. This evening, the captain of a tanker carrying 280,000 barrels of refined gasoline for the domestic market told a Venezuelan television network he was anchoring his ship in the middle of the Lake Maracaibo shipping channel, possibly blocking a key route for oil tankers. 
 "This government is pushing us into a situation like Cuba," Daniel Alfaro, the captain of the Pili Leon, told the Globovision network in justifying his action. Oil analysts also said tugboat captains who help guide tankers were walking off the job, while other state oil company facilities were reporting slowdowns. 
Government officials have called the strike a thinly disguised effort to overthrow Mr. Chavez, and they played down its effects on the economy and the oil industry, contending that few people have gone on strike. Still, the government had been pressing the opposition, in informal talks on Tuesday and today, to end the walkout, which began Monday.
The announcement by business and labor leaders that the strike would continue through at least Thursday caught the government and some anti-Chavez leaders by surprise, said those close to the talks.
The United States and the United Nations have urged both sides to return to talks.
In informal discussions, Mr. Chavez's government had said that it would not block a nonbinding referendum on Feb. 2 that would allow Venezuelans to vote on whether they want Mr. Chavez to remain president, even though it was fundamentally opposed to such a move. The government had also signaled that it would be open to talks about changing the Constitution to allow early presidential elections.
Opponents of the government had been pressing Mr. Chavez, whose four years in office have been marked by political unrest and a sliding economy, to enter negotiations about a nonbinding referendum or early elections in exchange for an end to the strike.
"They expected the strike to last just 72 hours," said one person close to the talks. "But now it looks like it is an indefinite strike."
Earlier in the day, Cesar Gaviria, secretary general of the Organization of American States, said "both parts have made important advances." Later, however, he appeared grim.
"We have to wait and see how this polarizes the situation between the government and the opposition," he said. "This can make the situation much more tense."
Indeed, people close to the talks said the government was taken aback when leaders of the Democratic Coordinator, an anti-Chavez umbrella group of business organizations, labor leaders and politicians, announced on national television tonight that the strike would continue. High-ranking opposition members involved in the talks had told reporters that the government had made enough gestures to warrant an end to the walkout.
Those included plans to return control of the Caracas police, which had been in the hands of the central government, to the mayor, and pulling troops off the capital's streets.
"The strike has achieved its objective," said Manuel Cova, secretary general of the Venezuelan Workers Confederation, who was involved in the talks. "For me it is enough."
Formal talks had broken off last Saturday, after the emboldened opposition refused to call off plans for its fourth general strike in a year. But on Tuesday, with National Guard troops firing tear gas at antigovernment protesters, discussions aimed at ending the strike began. 
Although the two sides had not discussed the referendum or early elections in a formal sense, people close to the talks said the government would not block an early nonbinding referendum, as long as the Supreme Court permitted it. 
Mr. Chavez had consistently rejected such a vote, saying it was unconstitutional. He has said the opposition should simply wait for a binding referendum on his rule in August -- halfway through his term, as permitted by law.
But on Tuesday the country's electoral board announced that it had voted 4 to 1 in favor of a nonbinding referendum for Feb. 2, overcoming an earlier Supreme Court ruling that would have banned such a vote.
