HEADLINE: Fever of Pitches at End of a Close Senate Race in Louisiana 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 6 

 BODY:
Vice President Dick Cheney is on the phone to hunters. Barbara Bush is calling elderly voters. Rudolph W. Giuliani is calling swing voters. Bob Dole, the former Senate majority leader and World War II veteran, is talking to veterans. Raymond L. Flynn, the former mayor of Boston and former United States ambassador to the Vatican, is on the phone to abortion opponents.
 This all-star cast has recorded messages that are being speed-dialed around Louisiana to prod voters to the polls on Saturday for Suzanne Haik Terrell, the formerly obscure state elections commissioner who has become the vessel for the White House's determination to finish its winning election season with a cherry on top. 
 Polls show the runoff, in which Ms. Terrell is trying to unseat Senator Mary L. Landrieu, a first-term Democrat, in a dead heat.
They also show that President Bush, who campaigned here on behalf of Ms. Terrell on Tuesday, increased her standing among voters and pushed her slightly ahead of Ms. Landrieu. If Ms. Terrell wins, she would become the first Republican senator from Louisiana since Reconstruction.
The question now is whether Ms. Terrell can keep that momentum going until the polls close at 8 p.m. Saturday. The White House and an array of allies -- Karen P. Hughes, the president's close adviser, campaigned with Ms. Terrell today -- are following the Republicans' now-famous "72-hour task force" get-out-the-vote plan to ensure that it does.
For Ms. Landrieu, the challenge is to inspire black voters to get to the polls. Trolling for votes on her behalf are student volunteers and union workers, including teachers, members of the building trades, dock workers and fire fighters. Donna Brazile, a longtime expert in Democratic get-out-the-vote efforts, is helping to organize that effort here while trying to wring money out of reliable Democratic donors for last-minute commercials.
If Senator Landrieu "can turn that base Democratic vote out, she definitely has a shot," said Wayne Parent, chairman of the political science department at Louisiana State University. "Terrell has the momentum and everyone knows that, but everyone also knows that Landrieu got 46 percent of the vote in the primary. I wouldn't write her off."
The turnout in that election on Nov. 5 was 44 percent. Forty percent of black voters turned out, while 48 percent of white voters did. Ms. Landrieu won 87 percent of the black vote and 30 percent of the white vote. In Louisiana, candidates who finished first on Nov. 5 but did not receive more than 50 percent of the vote have to face a runoff against the candidates who came in second.
Black voters have been cool to Ms. Landrieu in part because she did not help a black politician, Cleo Fields, in his race for governor and partly because, in an effort to hold on to white voters, she began this campaign emphasizing how much she has supported the president. She is closing it out emphasizing her "independence."
Inspiring black voters while not turning off whites is a tricky task. To reach blacks and low-income whites, she is emphasizing economic issues, highlighting what she calls a secret deal between the Bush administration and Mexico to allow more sugar imports in the United States, which could hurt the state's sugar industry. (Administration officials say there is no deal; Ms. Landrieu says they will not admit it until after the election.)
She is fighting for whites on the cultural front. With the Terrell campaign attacking her as too liberal, Ms. Landrieu is trying to highlight credentials that appeal to conservative whites, which include her support for various Second Amendment measures. Somewhat unnoticed in this race has been Ms. Landrieu's neutralization of the National Rifle Association. While the gun group is sending out mailings on behalf of Ms. Terrell, it is not campaigning against Ms. Landrieu, who supports immunity for gun manufacturers when guns are involved in crimes, and who has said she would vote to get rid of a ban on assault weapons.
The problem for Ms. Landrieu, said Ed Renwick, director of Loyola University's Institute of Politics, is that there is no natural Democratic majority in Louisiana. "A third of the voters are black, a third are Catholic and the rest are white Protestants," he said. "To get 51 percent, you have to put together disparate groups. If Suzie can get 70 percent of the whites, she can win without blacks. A Democrat can't do that."
Susan Howell, a political scientist at the University of New Orleans, said that there was a formula for figuring out how well a candidate must do among each group to win. "Assuming black turnout will be about 6 percent below white turnout, and assuming Mary gets 90 percent of the black vote, then she has to get 36 percent of the white vote to win," Ms. Howell said. "That's attainable."
Ms. Terrell has had an easier time bringing together Republicans, especially under the Bush banner. 
The party's "72-hour task force" plan, which started months ago, relies largely on identifying issues that matter to voters, adapting messages and messengers for those voters, and in the final 72 hours staying in touch with them and getting them to the polls. Voters and volunteers are culled from membership lists of groups of Christians, abortion opponents and hunters; donors are culled from White House donor lists.
The tactics worked brilliantly in Georgia, where Ralph Reed, the former head of the Christian Coalition who is now chairman of the Georgia Republican Party, engineered the defeat last month of Georgia's Democratic senator and governor. Mr. Reed was here earlier this week.

Black turnout is crucial for Ms. Landrieu; Ms. Terrell is concentrating on conservative whites. (Photographs by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
O'Neill and Lindsey Ousted As Bush Seeks a New Team
President Bush, wrestling with a shaky economy and criticism that his administration projects a muddled message on how to respond, dismissed Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill, left, and the director of his National Economic Council, Lawrence B. Lindsey.
 Administration officials conceded that Mr. O'Neill had lost the confidence of the markets and of White House officials, especially his initial champion, Vice President Dick Cheney. In coming months, as the White House rolls out a new tax plan, and other economic measures to show that the president is as focused on the economy as he is on terrorism, the officials said it was crucial that their team speak clearly and with one voice. Page A1. 

President Bush acknowledged that he could not ignore or escape the political peril of a weak economy. In ushering the leaders of his economic team out the door, Mr. Bush was making a deliberately dramatic if messily orchestrated statement that he now intends to focus on the issues that are closest to home for most Americans. News Analysis. A14.

I.B.M. to Buy Rational Software
I.B.M. increased its stake in the software business with the purchase of Rational Software for $2.1 billion in cash. C2.

Oil Markets Steady Despite Strike
Oil prices slipped to $26.93 a barrel as traders and analysts sought to gauge the fallout from the continuing strikes by oil workers against the government of President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela. The strikes, which have already disrupted production and shipments by Venezuela's oil company, come when stocks of oil, especially the types refined into home heating oil, are relatively low. A6.

Little Progress in Global Trade Talks
The new round of global trade negotiations, begun with great fanfare at Doha, Qatar, early this year, has bogged down, and trade diplomats are beginning to despair of making enough progress to justify holding an important interim conference scheduled for Cancun, Mexico, next year. The deadline of January 2005 for completing the whole round of talks is also in danger of slipping. C3.

Chicago Mercantile Shares Up 22%
Shares of Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings, the first major United States financial exchange to go public, rose 22 percent, to $42.90. The exchange raised $166.3 million through the sale of 4.75 million shares. The offering was priced at $35, above the initial expected range of $31 to $34. C4.

Shares End Lower for the Week
The Nasdaq composite index gained 11.69 points, to close at 1,422.44, but was down 3.8 percent for the week. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 22.49 points, to 8,645.77, after a five-day loss of 308 points. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 5.68 points, to 912.23, and lost 2.6 percent for the week. C4.

Credit Agricole Raises Bank Stake
Credit Agricole widened its stake in Credit Lyonnais to 12.2 percent from 10.5 percent in an effort to thwart a bid by its rival, BNP Paribas. Last month, BNP Paribas bid 2.2 billion euros ($2.2 billion) to acquire the stake owned by the French government in Credit Lyonnais, France's sixth-largest bank. C3.

Biotech Company Is Fined $3 Million
ProdiGene, a biotechnology company, was ordered to pay more than $3 million to the Department of Agriculture for failing to control test plots of gene-altered crops that threatened to contaminate the food supply. C2.

Two Merrill Managers Are Leaving
Paul Roy and Michael Marks are leaving Merrill Lynch, the latest senior managers to depart in E. Stanley O'Neal's first week as chief executive. Mr. O'Neal is overhauling management, a move he started when he became president 14 months ago. C4.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE TREASURY: THE CONTEXT; 
Paying a Price for a Shaky Economy

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 

 BODY:
After triumphing in the midterm elections largely on the strength of his performance as commander in chief, President Bush signaled today that not even a popular wartime president can ignore or escape the political peril of a weak economy.
 In ushering the leaders of his economic team out the door, Mr. Bush was making a deliberately dramatic if messily orchestrated statement that he now intends to focus on the issues that are closest to home for most Americans even as he leads the nation toward a showdown with Iraq. 
 "The economic news is mixed and the American public is concerned," said Frank Luntz, a Republican pollster. "This is the administration's way of saying, we hear you and we're doing something about it." 
But the changes seem likely to be limited to personnel rather than extending to a rethinking of the president's philosophy of lower taxes, less regulation and more trade. The departures of Paul H. O'Neill as treasury secretary and Lawrence B. Lindsey as chief White House economic policy adviser had less to do with a desire to change policy in the face of a troubled economic outlook than with a need to shed the considerable baggage taken on by the two men. A fresh team, administration officials said, should be better able to sell the president's pre-existing agenda. 
"This is more about perception than about policy," said Thomas D. Gallagher, a political analyst at ISI Group, an investment firm. "It's about putting a better face on the economic policy rather than on changing it."
Still, the move held considerable risks for Mr. Bush. Democrats, who failed to make an effective case in the campaign as to why the president and his party should be held accountable for the economy's sluggishness, immediately cast the departures as an admission of failure by the White House and stepped up their efforts to portray Mr. Bush as the enemy of the working family. 
"I hope this represents an acknowledgment by the president that his administration's policies have failed to produce economic growth and create new jobs," said Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York. "President Bush calls himself a compassionate conservative, but his actions on the economy seem more like indifference than compassion."
Republicans on Capitol Hill fretted that the resignations would complicate efforts to roll out a short-term economic stimulus plan in the next month and would undermine the administration's long-term plans to overhaul the tax code and remake the Social Security system. To the financial markets, the creation of a vacuum in economic leadership, however temporary, was one more thing to worry about.
But in some ways, Mr. Bush had little choice. Two years into his term and with his party assuming control of both chambers in Congress, political responsibility for the economy rests squarely with Mr. Bush. 
Since taking office nearly two years ago, Mr. Bush has effectively and with varying degrees of justification blamed last year's recession and the sluggish recovery on the bubble economy of the 1990's, his predecessor, Senate Democrats the terrorist attacks.
But he has also gotten all his major economic initiatives passed, including last year's tax cut, and is likely to win Congressional approval for new measures next year. Having prescribed and dispensed the economic medicine, Mr. Bush cannot easily blame weak vital signs on anyone else.
The patient, however, is not responding in the way the White House had hoped or expected. 
The unemployment rate rose to 6 percent in November from 5.7 percent a month earlier. The stock market, which rose after the resignations were announced this morning, remains jittery. Administration officials are concerned that a war with Iraq, especially if it drags on, will upset oil markets and undermine consumer and business confidence. 
"At this point, the president is so enormously popular that the only thing that can derail the George W. Bush express is a recession or something going catastrophically wrong in the war," said Stephen Moore, president of the Club for Growth, a conservative political action committee. "This was a precautionary measure. He was saying to himself, we've got to make sure the economy performs, and it's time to bring in some new people."
It has become almost a political cliche in Washington to talk about how the current president learned from the mistakes of his father. The senior Bush was defeated for re-election a decade ago in part because he allowed himself to be portrayed by Democrats as out of touch with the economic concerns of working people. In campaign appearances all this year, the current president has stressed that he will not be satisfied until every American who wants a job can get one.
But in announcing the resignations of Mr. O'Neill and Mr. Lindsey, the White House steadfastly denied any suggestion that the change was an admission that economic policy was anything less than it should be. And in making the shift, the president did not betray any preference for one policy approach over another. Mr. O'Neill and Mr. Lindsey, in fact, often found themselves at odds, with the treasury secretary concluding that the economy was basically in good shape and in need of little new fiscal stimulus, and Mr. Lindsey more focused on the economic risks and more willing to consider aggressive tax cuts.
After months of debate, Mr. Lindsey and Mr. O'Neill left on Mr. Bush's desk a set of options for a short-term economic agenda that the White House could still unveil within weeks.
In addition to Mr. Bush's longstanding call to make permanent last year's 10-year tax cut, the two main parts of the proposal are a reduction in the tax on stock dividends paid by individuals and a tax break for businesses in the form of a change in the way companies write off investments they make in new equipment. It could also include speeding up the individual income tax cuts that are scheduled to phase in over the next few years under last year's tax bill.
Mr. Bush has not yet signed off on the package, and many details remain to be worked out. But outside advisers to the administration say little is likely to change in the basics of the package no matter who replaces Mr. O'Neill and Mr. Lindsey.
"I don't mean to sound callous, but from a policy perspective I don't care about Larry Lindsey or Secretary O'Neill leaving," said Grover Norquist, president of Americans for Tax Reform, a conservative advocacy group. "It doesn't matter in terms of where policy is heading. There is unanimity on where Republicans want to go on tax policy."

HEADLINE: Young Stars of U.S. Fashion Can't Seem to Find Right Fit 

BYLINE:  By CATHY HORYN 

 BODY:
After designing surfer shorts and hibiscus-print tops, and T-shirts emblazoned with slogans like "Butch Buddha" for spring, John Bartlett became part of the latest American fashion trend: he closed his business.
 Young American designers like Mr. Bartlett are hitting an impasse, unable to penetrate the consciousness of consumers. In the last decade, no new American talent has shown the staying power needed to be the next Calvin Klein, Donna Karan or Ralph Lauren, whose brands generate billions of dollars in sales from products ranging from $6,000 suits to $6.50 cotton briefs. 
 Since 1998, when Isaac Mizrahi closed his doors, a succession of promising stars have gone out of business -- Daryl Kerrigan, Pamela Dennis, Todd Oldham and last month, Mr. Bartlett, who in 1997 was the industry's top men's wear designer. 
Without younger creative talent to replace aging stars, whose customers are also aging, the American fashion industry is in danger of losing the next generation of shoppers, experts say. 
"The lifeblood of this industry is new ideas," said Allen Questrom, the former chief executive of Barneys New York and now C.E.O. of J. C. Penney. "If we don't support the young people coming along, we're going to have a dead market."
Industry experts say the problems that thwarted them, including a shortage of capital and an increasingly unresponsive consumer, make it doubtful that the latest runway comets, Zac Posen and Miguel Adrover, will succeed in the long run.
"The reality is that it's more than difficult, it's unlikely," said Arnold Cohen, a senior partner in Mahoney Cohen, an accounting firm for about 200 fashion and apparel makers. 
Standing in their way is a surge of competition from discounters and the popularity of defiantly casual clothes by nondesigners, like the rap star Sean Combs, whose Sean Jean label has estimated sales of $100 million annually. Juicy Couture, a line of sweat pants and tops, is a big hit with models and socialites. "We can't keep the stuff in the store," said a Fifth Avenue merchant who is better known for selling $3,000 Chanel suits. "I guess, at the moment, $100 sweat pants are what people find fashionable."
What experts find alarming is that young people are entering fashion in astonishing numbers without questioning whether the Seventh Avenue powerhouse formula of the last 40 years is obsolete. "We'll never see another Ralph Lauren," said Allan Ellinger, whose firm, MMG, provides management advice to the industry. "It takes too long and too much money to get there."
If so, analysts say, it will severely limit America's ability to compete with large European brands, which have been aggressively developing new talents like Stella McCartney. 
Designers like Mr. Lauren, whose success came gradually, could once count on selling upper-class ideals to status-seeking consumers. But their preserve has been eroded as good design has become more widely available, and because upstart chains like Zara, based in Spain, can quickly duplicate the latest runway styles at low cost. 
"It took Pierre Cardin 30 years to go from couture to Wal-Mart, and Mossimo three years to become a Target brand," said Todd Slater, an apparel analyst at Lazard, the investment bank. "It now takes six nanoseconds for a brand to go from class to mass." 
In terms of dollars, the closing of Mr. Bartlett's 10-year-old business -- which at its peak had annual sales of $6 million -- scarcely represents a loss to the $142 billion industry. But in terms of the industry's ability to regenerate itself creatively, the loss of another promising star is seen by many as significant. 
Fashion has always been an optimistic undertaking, shaped by innovators as well as entrepreneurs. Both Mr. Lauren and Mr. Klein, Bronx natives, each started their businesses in the late 1960's with $10,000, and Mr. Lauren had the audacity to market his clothes around worlds he knew little about -- cowboys and English aristocrats.
But executives wonder if the new crop possesses the same entrepreneurial vision -- or the discipline to carry it out. Many executives believe that young American designers just aren't making relevant clothes. "A lot of these guys and gals want to get press coverage, but they're ignoring the fact that the big spenders are over 40 and want wearable clothes," Mr. Questrom said. "Even John Bartlett wasn't relevant." 
Mr. Bartlett, 39, acknowledged that, as with many young designers, his prestige had exceeded his revenues. He said he had believed that if he staged exciting runway shows and won media attention, he would one day have a successful brand. "So many of us are just riding on smoke and mirrors, hoping that the next season a sugar daddy will be sitting in the audience," he said.
Retailers say they yearn for new American stars to entice younger shoppers. "In our meetings, we're constantly saying, 'Where's the next Calvin?' " a department store executive said. 
Increasingly, the sugar daddies are luxury companies, many of them European, which can guarantee profit margins as an incentive to department stores to carry their newer talents. At the same time, stores are seeing tremendous growth from trendy, less expensive, anonymously designed labels like Theory.
"The American consumer is very different than 10 years ago," said Christina Johnson, the C.E.O. of Saks Fifth Avenue. "She's very fashion-involved, but she doesn't want to spend what she used to."
Loaded up on information -- from shopping magazines like Lucky to shopping networks like QVC to celebrity shopping tips in In Style magazine -- the consumer is also savvier. 
"She's buying things from Prada and H&M," said Candace Corlett, a partner in WSL Strategic Retail, a company that monitors buying habits. "The challenge to high-end designers is terrific, because there isn't this priority of 'I must have the designer look.' Loyalty is about 'What's good for me?' "
As it is, at least two Seventh Avenue giants are in flux. Mr. Klein, 60, and his partner, Barry Schwartz, are reported to be in negotiations to sell their company. Mr. Klein's brand generates an estimated $3 billion in retail sales, mainly through licensed products. And Ms. Karan, 54, after drifting away from her original formula, is trying to recharge her brand under its new owner, LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton.
Retailers worry that even if newcomers like Mr. Posen, the subject of flattering articles, can weather routine business woes like cash shortages and delivery delays, they will probably have to scale back their expectations. 
"If some of them end up having only a $10 million or $20 million business, maybe that's as good as it gets," said Julie Gilhart, the fashion director at Barneys New York. 
Lately, young designers have expressed a slightly disingenuous scorn for big brands and their homogenous look. "There's too much sameness," Mr. Adrover said. But even if they adopt an antibranding attitude, as the London chain Topshop has in ads featuring a young model in mismatched clothes, retailers say it still takes millions of dollars to promote that image. Mr. Adrover, who staged a comeback show in September, has not found a backer, making it doubtful he will have clothes in stores next spring.
During the most recent round of New York shows, some 25 new designers presented collections, the largest group in years. The challenge is how to support them when the economic conditions that favored the older generation no longer exist. 
Department stores, once exciting places to socialize as well as shop, contributed to the success of older designers. "Calvin Klein happened for a reason, as did Ralph Lauren," Mr. Ellinger said. "They're mainly department store brands." 
But fewer dollars are being spent in department stores, which face intense competition from discounters, specialty chains like Express and designers' own boutiques. According to Mr. Ellinger, the total amount of dollars spent in department stores for all products has declined from 35 percent in 1990 to just under 17 percent. And retailers say they cannot afford to carry an underperforming designer beyond two seasons.
Nora Lowinsky, 20, an actress in Manhattan, mirrors the disarray of modern dressing -- part flea market, part luxury trappings. On Tuesday, outside the Club Monaco boutique in SoHo, she said she pays close attention to what designers show. "But I don't necessarily buy the Prada jacket," said Ms. Lowinsky, who was dressed in a vintage shearling coat and knee-high moccasins. "If I like it, I'll buy the cheaper version at H&M or Century 21."
The older generation could also count on exploiting their names through licensing. Polo Ralph Lauren had revenues of $2.3 billion for its latest fiscal year. But more significantly, the brand generates some $5 billion in retail sales from licensed products like bed sheets and sunglasses. The pattern now, initiated by Gucci, is to eliminate licenses and more rigorously control product and distribution.
European luxury groups have aggressively taken the lead in developing new talent -- particularly because, as public companies, they have to show shareholders a means of growth. Gucci has built a stable that includes Alexander McQueen and Ms. McCartney, giving them managerial support. LVMH has pursued a similar strategy with John Galliano, Michael Kors and Mr. Jacobs.
Indeed, fashion executives say, without LVMH capital Mr. Kors and Mr. Jacobs, both Americans, would not be able to shoulder the costs of expanding their businesses as effectively as they have in recent years, with accessories, spinoff labels and their own stores. 
American retailers are not ignoring young talent, but their efforts often have a flavor-of-the-month quality.
This fall stores like Barneys and Bergdorf Goodman competed fiercely to get Proenza Schouler, a new label, whose designers, Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez, had just graduated from design school. 
And Neiman Marcus picked up Mr. Posen's playful spring line, helping to bring the total number of garments he sold for the season to 900, a threefold increase over fall. Although the number is tiny -- a moderate-size company like Nicole Miller sells 100,000 units a year -- there are still risks for stores anointing young talent so quickly.
Ed Burstell, general manager at Henri Bendel, a showplace for new talent, has received garments without armholes and with zippers sewn in sideways by celebrated but technically inexperienced designers. 
"Do we make money with young designers?" he said with a sigh. "If the sun and the moon are in alignment, and I'm not on the phone looking for a sewing machine, then -- yeah, there's some money to be made."

GRAPHIC: Photos: John Bartlett, all smiles at a 1997 show, closed his doors last month. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)(pg. A1); As models applauded, Isaac Mizrahi took a bow at a fashion show in 1997; he went out of business a year later. Among the other young American designers who have shut down their design businesses in recent years is Todd Oldham, who in a triumphant moment in 1994 was escorted down the runway by the model Cindy Crawford. Two more dropouts: Pamela Dennis and Daryl Kerrigan. (Photographs by Associated Press); (G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times)(pg. B6)
